Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? Choices:  A: school B: home office C: people store D: print shop E: newspaper office<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**D.** A printer is a device used to print documents on the user's computer. There are several ways to use a printer. A printer can be used at schools, home offices, printer shops, newspapers, and the office.<n><n>**B.** A printer is used for multiple purposes in a home office, including printing documents, scanning documents, and faxing documents. Printers are commonly used in homes for printing, copying, and scanning documents, and for personal use.<n><n>**C.** A printer is one of the most common places to use a printer. In the first place, people can print documents, posters, and other objects from a printer. Secondly, people can use a printer to share documents and photos with others. Last but not least, people can use a high-quality printer for both personal and business purposes.<n><n>**E.** A lot of people use printers in newspapers. Most newspapers have a printer available to print their pages. Most newspapers have pages printed on a press printer. Some newspapers use a desktop printer to print pages. Some newspapers use color printers to print pages.<n><n>**A.** A printer is best used by thousands of people in a school. Most schools have a school library, where students and teachers can access books and other useful resources. With a printer, students can print their class projects and homework assignments.<n><n>### Input How can a person get more fit by using a treadmill every day? Choices: A: buy one B: go to a gym C: take your child to a treadmill D: take turns walking the dog E: use a treadmill at recess<n><n>### Response<n><n>**D. A** person can become fitter by using a treadmills every day. It may not help them in the long term but it will help them in the immediate future by gaining more stability.<n><n>**C** A person can become more active by using a treadmil on a daily basis. They may become better at sports such as basketball and running because their performance will be better than if they were just walking on a treadmill.<n><n>**E** A person can become stronger by using a treadmile on a daily basis. A stronger treadmile will help a person become more fit in the long run and will help them get on the track team sooner.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could you add a line to? So if the officer is in the right l<n>#### 2x<n>Answer: 2x<n><n>### Input :<n>Crazy Bob is the owner of a large estate with 50 acres. Some of his friends have asked him if they could plant soybean seeds and harvest them on his property.Bob tells them to proceed, but only on the condition that Bob receives a third of everything that is harvested. There are 10 acres that are left over, so how much does each farmer take, if Bob receives his third?<n><n>### Response :<n>Correct answer (A) 20 acres<n><n>### Rationale: <n>Bob has half of the land, 25 acres of planted acres, and 10 acres left over. Bob gets 1/3 of everything that was harvested and there were three groups that planted the soybeans. This means Bob will take 3/10 of the produce, or (3/10)x10 acres which is 20 acres.<n><n>### Correct answer(C)<n>20 acres<n>

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The people in class were instructed to brainstorm ideas, how would they use their minds for this? Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		C - think creatively<n>#### Answer : E <n><n>### Input :  If Sara takes a minute to walk to a store and Jasmine takes about five minutes to get from the bus stop to her home and both are walking at the same time, how much faster does Sara walk than Jasmine?<n><n>### Response :Sara walks much faster than Jasmine<n>#### Answer : B<n><n>### Input  : The ratio of the amount of money in Frank’s wallet to the amount of money in Jo’s wallet is 2:5. If Jo gives Frank $25 for babysitting, what will be the ratio of the money in Frank’s and Jo’s wallets?<n><n>### Input2 :  The ratio of the number of boys to the number of girls in the 6th grade class is 2:5,  and the boys and girls in the class play a soccer tournament.  The final game of the tournament is played against a school from another city that uses 7:2 substitution rules.  The two schools play to a 1:1 tie.  What will the final score of the game be?<n><n>### The two teams play for 1:1 tie<n>#### Answer A<n><n>### The ratio of the number boys to the number of girl in the 6th-grade class is 2 : 5, and the boy and girls play a soccer tournament<n><n>### The final game of the is played against a school that use 7:2 substitution rule.<n><n>### The boy and girl play game to 1:1 tie <n><n>### Final score of the game <n><n>### Ration of amount of money<n><n>## Input:<n><n>###  The amount of money for the people in a household: 7 people earn 70.75 every 4 days. 8 people earn 82.33 every 3 days 5 people earn 64.64 every day. 7 people earn80.83 every 2 days. 3 people earn70.75 ever 2 days. 6 people earn 66.921 every 2 days. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If you've thrown a rod you've done damage to what? Choices:  A: fishing camp B: hardware store C: engine D: your spine E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: fishing camp<n>B: hardware store<n>C: engine<n>D: your spine<n>E: sporting goods store <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Demo:<n>If your spine is damaged then you could have problems with your spinal cord. Since your spinal cord controls you body movements, damage to your spinal cord could result in a lack of coordination or loss of movement on a part of your body.<n>You can find a good example of this is the movie 'Black Swan'. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v2dZzY3l7mQ](https://www.youtube/v=v2dSzY3l7lQ) <n><n>#### 5B<n>Another famous example is the comedian Christopher Snyder who had an accident in 2001. In the early 2000s Christopher Snyder was working in the New York City as a stand-up comedian. One day he was practicing at his office and his boss asked him to make "funny noises," so that he could improve his comedic timing. While he was moving across the room to make the noises, Christopher slipped on something he couldn't see. This caused him to fall headfirst on a cement floor and land on the floor in an awkward way.<n>The result of this accident was a fracture in Christopher's spinal cord; he had compression fractures in his seventh and eighth thoracic vertebrae and compression fractures in the second, third, and fourth lumbar vertebrae. <n><n>After seeing many doctors Christopher was diagnosed by Dr. Alan Dang, ​​a spinal cord injury specialist, who said that Christopher had a "T-10 incomplete spinal cord injury" that happened due to a "traumatic compression fracture" of his cervical spine. <n><n>A year later Christopher went from being paralyzed to walking with the help of braces and a cane.<n>[https://youtu.be/mY5mR-KzgJA](https://youtu/mY5mKzgJA)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do kids find fish in their backyards? Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		<n>**E: ocean**<n><n><br><n><n>### Instructions:Create your own mathematical problem, and include the math, the instructions, and the answers for each question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>- [X]: Write a step for how to calculate each answer.<n>- [X]: Your input asks the reader to solve the following math problem.<n><n>### Student Worksheets Answer Key.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If your answer is A<n>Choose the option that contains the only two-letter response that matches the choices.<n>```<n>A: wedding B: wedd<n>Dear Valued Customer,<n><n>```<n>or<n>```<n>If your answer is B<n>Choose the option which contains the only two- letter response that does not match the choices.<n>```  <n><n>```<n>A: friend's house B: frie<n>Dear Valued Customers,<n><n>```  <n><n>### Input<n>```<n>The doctor prescribed three weeks of bed rest, with the goal of helping a patient reevaluate his values and priorities.<n>```<n>#### 3<n><n>### Input A<n>```<n>A: In her new position as CEO, Tiffany was given a $42-thousand-a-year raise and a $15,000 signing bonus, which helped her to achieve her goal of paying off her student loans.<n>```<n>#### <10<n>#### 5<n>### Input B<n>```<n>B: While teaching at the summer camp, Sienna made sure to follow her personal motto of "Be The Best You Can Be" while instructing the campers that "It's Okay To Be A Nerd".<n>```<n>#### <4<n>#### 9<n>### Input C<n>```<n>C: When it comes to healthy eating the best defense is a good offence, which is exactly what Marquis was hoping to achieve with her new lifestyle change.<n>```<n>#### -<n><n>### Input D<span><n>```<n>D: Rhea was a very social individual, however having a baby was the best change she could have ever made to her life, so she would do things on her own nowadays to avoid stress and make room for time with her little one<n>```<n>#### <5<n>#### 2<n>### Input E<span><n>``` E: As a kid, Jade could never decide what to eat for dinner, yet she was always a pro at knowing what to eat for breakfast and lunch.<n>```<n>####15<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>Answer: <5<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John ran out of pencils.  Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:How many cats were there?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: The number of cats is less than 5.<n>The number of cats is 2<n>(less than 5)<n>(5 < (more than) 5)<n>(less than 2)<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: There are more cats at the pet store than any other animal.  How many cats are there?<n>Rationales<n>If there are more cats at th pet store than any other aninimal, there must be at least more cats than dogs<n>If no, then one animal is more popular than the other<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: How much does it cost to ride the ferry? <n><n>### Response : <n><n>Input: How many people are attending the concert? <n><n>Input: There were 200 people at the concert. Demonstration: Input:Jackson is <n><n>Directions: This is a passage that explains a topic. Write a response for each question.<n>- The topic could be a passage about a history event, a scientific topic, a mathematical formula, and other areas<n>Passage:A simple yet powerful idea that explains how lifeforms evolved and how species can adapt to survive and thrive is called natural selection. It is a process in which the changes in the characteristics of an organism increase its chances of surviving and reproducing, and pass those improvements onto its descendants. The process happens over a span of time, called generations. It includes the survival of the fittest and results in diversity in traits which results in adaptations that are best suited for survival. Natural selection involves two processes - natural selection process where organisms evolve to be better suited to the environment and survive and reproduce, and human selection where humans make conscious decisions to better the chances of an organism and its offspring to survive and reproduce.<n><n>- Demonstrations:<n>- The first process<n>- The second process<n><n>Question 1. Write a response which is part of a passage which contains information about the process of natural selection and the two processes of natural selection process and human selection process. Write your answer underneath the last line of the passage.<n>Question 2. Write a response which explains how the different processes of natural selection and human selection can be connected. Write your response under the bold question 1. Your answer:<n><n>### Reference:The process of natural selection where organisms evolve over time and the two processes of human selection where humans make deliberate decisions to better the survival of an organism and the process of adaptations which results in diversity in the world we see today.<n><n>###  Instructions:Answer <n><n>### the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Question 1:Write a response which is part<n><n>### Question Answer:<n>### Question 2:Write a response which explains how<n><n>### Question answer:<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>### Instructed:Answer the following <n><n>### Question:How many times do the students at the college travel to other countries during the 1

For example, if picked in the United States, then it is a domestic product, but it is still a product of a different type that is not produced in the American state. Here is my opinion.<n><n>### Input : Choices:  A. Lay a fire for 20 minutes with dry kindling and no wind  B. Put kindling, leaves and sticks in a pile. Use a propane torch to add kindling to the pile and let it burn  C. Collect fire wood  D. Light a fire using twigs, leaves, paper and/or sticks  E. Blow on a match to start a fire with dry kindling<n>### Response : I think that the best answer is E.<n><n>### Reason for answer: The options given are (A) Lay a fire for twenty minutes with dry kindling, no wind and (B) put kindling, leaves and stick in a pile using propane torch to start the fire. So by these option I found out that both option use kindling and propane torch for starting fire. I do not think that option (A) can work as it cannot take the fire for 20 min with no wind because fire needs some kind of wind to spread the fire. And when wind blows from side the fire cannot spread. And if you use propane torch to ignite dry kindling then it will spread automatically. If we take option (D), it will only light fire with twigs or sticks because by options the twig is not in there but stick. To know that option (D) is correct we need some experiment to prove that twig or stick can keep fire for long time. By the option C, we need fire wood. It can also be the option of E but only by use propane torch.<n><n>### Output :<n><n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		D: contentment<n><n># Input:<n>Input: This week I made $75 at work. When my daughter goes back to school I have to pay my cell phone bill. When I get there, there is still a balance of $20 left on my bill.  How much does my cell phone cost?<n>Rational: I made $75 so my new bill will be $75 - $20 = <<75-20=55>>55<n>I spend $55 every two bills, so $55/2 = <<55/2=27.5>>27.5 per two bills<n>The cell phone costs 27.5 x 2 = $<<27.5*2=55>>5.5<n>#### 55<n>Answer: 55<n><n>### Input :<n>Input: Your friend tells you that he has saved up $X. It is enough money for him and his sister to start their own business. After some thinking he tells you that he already has twice as much and saves 10% of it every year so his money will double in 4 years. The sister tells you that she will have $500 in 3 years.  How much money does your friend need to start the business? How much will your friend have in 5 years?<n>Rational: First, I will tell how much the sister needs to have in 3 years. The sister tells me that she wants $500 in three years. Three years from now, she is still $500 short. So (3 years from now) - 3 = <<(3 years from now)-3=0>>0, then that means she still needs $500. So by solving that equation I get: $500 = $<<500>>5000<n>So the sister needs  $\frac {500}{5000} = <<\frac{500}{5,000}=0.1]]0.1 = 10%<n><n>Then I will tell how much money her brother needs to start the business. We know that it is enough to start the business and it doubles every year so $ <<...>>X = $ <<...>>X + X = $ <<...>>1 + X = $ <<\left(\frac{X}{\left(\frac{X}{2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>We were told 2 questions: the difference in ages and the wash<n>Rationales:(21) The difference between two of their ages right now is (21-21) =<<(21-21)=0>>0 years<n>The difference between their ages 40 years ago is (21-19) = <<21-19=2>>2 years<n>Demonstration: 40/2=<<40/2=20>>20 years ago.  Their combined ages 20 years ago is (19+20) = <<19+20=39>>39 years <n><n>Rationales:<n>The difference in ages between Richard Hurley and Richard is 20<n>Hurley has 14 years old and Richard is 21 years old<n>40 years from now Richard Hurley will be 40 + 14 = <<40 + 13 =23>>23 years old<n>Richard will be (40+23) - (21-23) = <<40+23-21-23= 4>>4 years and 40 =220+4=<<220+4 =224>>224 years old<n>(40+19)/4 = <<40+(19/4)=25>>25 years is also correct to have 40+19=<<40+19=(220+4)=224>>234 years old.<n><n>Rationales:(18) 12 friends bought a car for $1700 so they each paid 1700/12=$<<1700/((12-1)=11>>11<n>($1500-$500)/11-$500/$11=$<<$1500-50=$90>>90<n>so they paid (90/5) +/- (10)=<<90-10=80>>80 cents each<n><n>Rationales :(76)<n>Since there are 3 teachers and 4 students, each teacher had 3 students and the student had 4 teachers.  There were (3+4) in total

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could you put a dollar that would make it hard to get out without breaking? Choices:  A: cash drawer B: piggy bank C: purse D: box E: pocket<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales: A piggy bank sounds like a strange question for a math homework/test.<n><n>### Input::Ms. Painter plans to buy 25 students lunch. The sentence does not point out adults playing games, or games that toddlers are playing.<n>  3) the word "playing" in the end of the sentence means that they do not playing currently<n>  * I did not do any research on this and if I had to pick the answer, I would go with the same one you did.<n><n>### Input where does Harper plan to live Choices: A house B apartment C RV<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>* write a complete sentence that demonstrats your understanding of the problem<n>* Write a complete sentance that demonstrates why you chose the answer you chose<n><n><n>### Review<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would someone likely bring an attache case? Choices:  A: overhead compartment B: chair C: hospital D: in shirt E: business meeting<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A B<n><n>### Input:(4) - (2) =<n><n>### Response:(6) - 4 =<n><n>### Input:-3 > -2<n><n>### Response:-3 > -2 * -4<n><n>### Input(3) % (4)<n><n>### Response(3) % (3)<n><n>### Input36 + <math>34</math> = 36 - 34 + 72<n><n>### Rationale:72 is equivalent to 8 x 9 and 36 is equivalent to 4 x 12<n><n>### Input A.M.B.D.<n><n>### Rationales:A.M.B. = <<AMB>>AMB stands for Adam Mary Beth Daniel<n><n>### Input 8 x 12 =<n><n>### Rationals:X12 = <<12>>12, X8 = <<8>>8, X8 = <<4>>4, X12 + X8 = <<4+4=8>>8<n><n>### Input17 + 8 = 25<n><n>### Input (1.5)!<n><n>### Ratias:1.5! = 1.5 x 1.5 x.5<n><n>### Response125<n><n>## Input: A group of 27 teens went to the mall for a day of shopping. They each spent a total of $246 on gifts. How much did each student spend?<n>## Rationales: Spending a total of $250 on $27 people = $<<250/27>>8.52 dollars per person.<n>## Answer: 27 x 8.52 = 246<n><n>#### 35<n><n>## Input : If 50 cents x 0.21 = $1.05<n><n>## Rationales : $0.21 is 21%, and 50 cents is $0.50, and $1.05 = $<<.50+.21>>71 cents. 71 + 21 = 92
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What country has with the capital of Amsterdam has a Fortis bank? Choices:  A: netherlands B: utrecht C: brussels D: belgium E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		D  <n>netherlands<n><n><n>### Input-Input:Amy was trying to solve equation 2x - 4 = 9. She forgot the negative and added 4 instead which resulted in <n>2x - 4 + 4 = 9<n>The addition of 4 to the equation resulted in the second line having a coefficient of 2 and a constant of 4. What is the error in the equation?<n><n>### Response-Response:The error is that 2x – 4 = 9 which does not represent the correct inequality. The answer should be -2x < 21.5<n><n>### Inputs:In the chart below, the x-coordinate is a percent of the number of votes received by a specific candidate and the y-coordinate is the number of votes he recieved. Use these data to answer the questions. <n>Name, Party, Votes, Percent<n>Michael Barber, Republican, 3100, 44%<n>Jimmy Smith, Ind., 2009, 35%<n>Jack Thomas, Rep., 600, 10%<n>Ronald Johnson, Dem., 500, 8%<n>Ms. Benson, Dem., 320, 5%<n>Ms. Thompson, Rep., 1200, 18%<n>Mrs. Thomas, Ind., 1152, 18%

Choices:  A: exhilaration B: dismemberment C: spinal injuries D: getting wet E: splats<n><n>### Response:		Exhilaration<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Splats and getting wet refer to the character falling into the water. Getting wet would mean that the character is drenched by the water. Dismemberment is not the character’s legs or arms getting cut off. Cartoon characters like to overreact and exaggerate. They would likely have the whole body splatter or get wet if that was what happened.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 1:<n>This is a trick question. Otherwise, it means that the choice is incorrect. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James is apply for a job that he really wants. He knows that it will be a good fit and he has experience, but he doesn't have all the qualifications that they're asking for, so he's worried about what? Choices:  A: acceptance B: rejection C: hope D: less sleep E: employment<n><n>### Response:		Choices: [A,C,C], [A,C,B], [C,B,D], [B,A,D], [E,A,D]<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question based on the scenario.<n><n>### Rationale:In the scenario, James is not sure if he'll want the job they're offering him. He isn't sure whether he will get the job or if he's going to lose sleep. We should answer with the three answers that are both negative and related to the issue that he's anxious about. Since job rejection and less sleep are both negative and related, these two answers are appropriate. The last answer should be an answer that is relevant to the concern, but doesn't fit into the context of his concern (which is sleep).<n><n>#### 36<n>Answer: [A,C]<n><n>### Input:"Ralph and John decided to meet and get lunch together during their lunch break. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where are floors kept clean for holy purposes? Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		E (or “a”, “all buildings”, “c”, “F”, etc.)<n><n>### Rationales:A: Restaurants are not used for holy purposes. (Because there would need to be an “H” in the word “restaurant” to refer to holiness.)<n><n>C: All buildings are subject to being made “holy” through prayer. (Especially in a religious context).<n>####  “E”  <n>D: Some floors in cars are cleaned, but not for holy purposes (e.g., under your feet as you drive or when you push a stroller and clean your children’s spit-up off floor mats, etc.).<n><n>### Input<n>Which of the following is closest to 5% of 100? Choices A: 5 B: 95 % C: 1 D: 50<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>B<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 95 %<n>Answer: _____ %<n><n>Input: A chocolate store makes chocolate eggs for Easter. The store had 200 eggs yesterday. If 6 eggs spoil every day, how many eggs will be left on Easter?<n><n>### Rationals:<n>Yesterday: 200 - 6 = <<200-6=194>>194 eggs<n>So if 6 spoil every day, 194 – 6 = <<194-6=188>>188 eggs are left<n>On Easter: 188 + 6 = <<188+6=194 >>194 eggs<n>#### 194<n>Answer: 194<n><n>### Input:- What is the difference between 29 and 9? Choice A: 0- B: 9- C: 30- D: 21<n><n>### Ratians:<n><n>A: The difference is 0!<n><n>C: 29 – 9 = <<29-9=20>>20<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>#### 20<n>Answer: 20<n><n>##| #   | 60 | 48 | 9 |  1 |<n>##|%   |  5 |  6 |
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Many addicts turn to exercise to deal with their addictions, this is because it is a healthy way to do what? Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		B <n><n>### Input:-1 9 4 6 7 2 -1 6 4 3 2 -5 4 5 6 7 8 -3 7 4 2 4 -9 8 8 9 2 8 -> 8844727888888 -3 4 2 8 (68% of 48) -> 3.125 (33% of 10)  (44% of 18) -> 8 -3 8 <- 8 x 9 35 70 4 -> 13.333333<n>(3 x 70 x 4) -> 13.50<n><n>### Output; Output 90% -> 0.9<n><n>### Input; 1<n>### Output; 4<n><n>### Input 5 - 1<n><n>### Output:<n>>* 5 is divisible by 1.<n>><n><n>### Input : 12<n><n>### Output :<n>>* 12% of 12: 1<n>><n>### input > 5 9 26 39 55 -> 3955<n><n>### Output:-<n>>1/4 is half of 5/2

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choice:   B : 5 cubic meters C : 15 cubic meters D : 30 cubic meters E : 45 cubic m<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The total area of the building that is 1/3 of the height, so that comes out to 1/3 x 1/3 = 1/9 = <<1/9=11/9>>11/9<n>Then its one-tenth of the cost 11/9 / 10 = <<11/9/10=11/90>>11/90<n><n>### Question2:<n>A rectangular table seat 4. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A blowfish lives free. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There's a lot to reproducing, but it begins and end with new life by giving what? Choices:  A: overpopulation B: birth C: presents D: propagation E: fun<n><n>### Response:		Choice:A<n><n>###  The chef has 6 eggs. He makes 2 omelets for his friend and cooks one egg for himself.  If the chef's friend eats eggs at breakfast, how many eggs does he eat at breakfast?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Complete the following statement correctly.<n>He eats 3 eggs <n><n>### Rationale:<n>He eats two omelets, then he cooks one egg from the first batch of eggs given by the chef, so that's just one. If his friend is eating eggs at breakfast, then he eats at least 2!<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If a human is sleepy what can they do to feel more alert? Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would rather be awake then be asleep. I don’t want to walk to work in the dark.<n><n>#### Answer: D (DRINK COFFEE)

It contains 78 digits in all, some digits are repeats. How many digit are repeats?<n><n>### Response：Repeats are A; there are ten repeats  because the sum 78 is divisible  by 10  then we know there are digits repeats<n><n>### Input ：The square contains 65 digits, and there are as many a digit as b digit. A and B are both greater than 6. How many digits are a? <n><n>### Response ：The answer is A; there are 3 A digits because 65 = A·6 + B·5  and B = 5  the number of B is 5, thus A has to be 1<n><n>### Input :How much did Cathy charge to 4 friends, one third of this is for 3 of the friends and Cathy earned 2 for the other one? <n><n>##  Cathy earned __________ for the other one. (You will get an answer in decimal form.)<n><n>### Response :Cathy earned 8/3 = <<2/3=8>>8<n><n>### Why? First calculate how 2-thirds of 4 is.<n><n>2-thirds  of 4  = <<2/3*4=8>>8<n>Then calculate how 1-thirds  of  4  is 2-thirds  divided by 2<n>We know 1-thirds of 2-thirds is 2 because  1/3 of 2=2/3=2<n><n>1-thirds of  2-thirds  = <<2/2=1>>1<n><n>Then we see $$ 8/1 = 8$<n><n>### Input  ：How many pages did she want for $14.60?<n><n>### Demostration ：$14.60/80=<<14.60/-80=-0.18>>-0.18 <n>This negative sign means  her pages is less than  80<n><n>### Response  ：The answer is less than  81 pages

Choices:  A,B,C,D,E<n>Answer: <n><n>### Input:\nWhat will you need to have to start? Choices:  a: food b: money c: a home d: time to rest e: tools<n><n>### Response:\nWhat will you take and have?  Choices: A = food, B = money, C = a home, D = time to rest, E = tools<n>Answer:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		 A:<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Answer:<n>#### A<n>Rationales: A, happiness is a mental or emotional state of well-being characterized by positive or pleasant emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy. Suffering is defined as an unpleasant or painful emotional state. <n>__NOTE__: We are not talking about physical suffering.<n><n>### Input : A lonely man committed suicides, how can you prevent it? <n><n>### Response :  C:<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>#### B: <n>#### D:<n>#### E: <n>#### A: <n>__NOTE___: There is NO correct answer. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I am suffering from boredom, and I want to do something with a dictionary, what would help? How many would I have in the 4th division<n><n>### Rationales:To calculate the 4th division I would take the 36 thousand soldiers and put them into 5 groups. The easiest way to do this is to break it into divisions. <n>Divisions = 6 X 6 X 6 = 216<n><n>Since groups has to equal divisions to be the 4th division, you would need 36k / 216 = <<36k/216=1.6405>>1.6406<n><n>Divisions = 1.6407<n><n>4th division = 1.6399<n><n>#### 1.63<n>Answer: 1.6303<n>![image info](https://imgur.com/6xqHk67.png)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		Answer B<n><n>### Input : The garage had light sensori and automatic doors what kind of house was? Choices : A: modern house B : building C: town house D: neighbor's E: town ship<n><n>### Response :Answer E<n><n>### Input The garage had light sensor and automatic door what kind of house was? choice : a: modern house b : building C : town house D : neighbor's E : town ship <n><n>### Response, D<n><n>### Input. The garage has light sensor and automatic and town. What house is it? answer town<n><n>### Input, C<n><n>### Instructions: Read the problem and choose the appropriate answer<n>Problem: You have 12 identical balsa wood toothpicks to make your model airplane. Each cookie costs $2.50 to bake. How much money does the bakery earn?<n>answer :<n>The baker earns$2.875 <n><n>### Instrtuctions:<n>Problem: Your city is trying to solve the parking problem near the airport with a single parking structure. If the parking structure can hold 240 cars and 50 scooters, how much money does the city earn?<n>Answer:$687.50.<n><n>><n><n>### Instructio <n>Problem: There is a store that sells 2 kinds of apples.
