He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a binder? Choices:  A: college dorm B: back pack C: class room D: backpack E: office supply store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>####  A<n>Answer: A<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>In each story, determine who or what each character remembers that helps him/her figure out or answer the question.<n><n>In a story, there is a monkey, tree, and pea. The monkey is climbing on the tree, and is looking for the pea, but he is having trouble finding it, because it is only a pea. The monkeys mother says “The pea is in the tree. Why can’t you find it, monkey boy.” Then she turns around and sees the monkey in the tree and says “Why are you in the tree, monkey boy?” The monkey boy doesn’t know the answer, he is still looking for the pea. The monsters mother says “Where are you boy?” The monkey answers “In the pea!”<n><n>The monster mother then says “In the pea?” and the monkey answers “Yes, in the pea!” The monster mother continues to ask the monkey boy if he can see the pea in the tree. The monkey keeps saying, “Yes, I can see the pea!”<n>He also says he is eating the pea, so they bring the monkey into the tree to help find the pea. The pea is sitting on a pea leaf. In the story, there is a tree and the monkey remembers the monkey climbed up the tree. The pea is on the tree.<n><n>####  A-C-D-E<n><n>####  A <n>Answer: Tree<n><n>The monkey is in the pea.<n>Tree<n><n>A. The monkey remembers his mother said the pea was in the tree.<n><n>B. The monkey remembers the pea was in a tree.<n><n>C. the monkey remembers that the pea was ina tree.<n><n>D. The monkey remmebered to look in the pea<n><n>####  B <n>Answer: Monkey<n><n>The monkey remembers that his mother said the peas was in the tree. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		Choice: A: Atoms and molecules are very tiny. They could be compared to a grain of sand. A grain of sand is in the hundreds of thousands of atoms. We can hold sand because our hands are made of molecules that are very large.<n><n>#### Rationale:<n>* Input:Collections of atoms called molecules makes up everything you can hold.<n><n>* Demonstration: We can hold sand because of our hands. Our hands are made of molecule.<n><n>* Rationales:  Atoms and molecules.<n><n>* Response: Choice:A-Atoms and molecules.They can be compared to a graind of sand because sand is very tiny.<n><n>### Input2:The students have 4 boxes of pencils. They give half to the teacher and the rest to the other classes. If they gave 5 boxes to each class, how many pencils did they have left?<n><n>### Response2:Each of the classes have to give 5 boxes but they have only 8 boxes left<n><n>#### Rationale2:<n><n>* Input2: The students have 4 boxes and they gave half to the teacher and they have the rest to the other class's.<n><n>* Demostration: The students only have4left - so that is5<n><n>* Rational:The students have 5 left.5 boxes*5boxeseach=5boxesand each = 5boxesleft<n><n><n>### Explanation2:<n><n>* The students gave  5 boxes to each class.<n>* However they have only 4 boxes left.<n>* So the students gave 1 extra box to each class for 5boxes per<n><n>*  so  <n>their left <n> <n>### Input3: 3500 bills are printed with an error.  After canceling the bills, the bank has 33500 left, and 150 remain that do not have the error. How many bills had the error?<n><n>### Rationale3:<n> <n>* Instarction: answer the questions. <n><n>* Incorrect answer : 150<n><n>* Demostaration:33500-150=33350<n><n>* Response:The error bills <n><n>###

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There are a lot of ways to relax, for this person it is simply opening one up and what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Mary was a bad girl, but she was always open about that.  People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n><n>### Response:		C<n>   <n>Input:<n>Ana ran 3 miles in 20 minutes and Ernie ran 2 miles in 24 minutes. At what rate did ernie run for the last three minutes to finish the race  at the same time as Ana? Choices: A: 1.5x B: 4x C: 6x D: 1.2x -E: 9.5x<n><n>### Response B<n><n>Input:<n>A:  13:40  <--13:40 is the time to walk 1 mile<n>B:  17:40  <---17:40 is the the time to walk 2 miles<n><n>### Response D<n><n>Input:<n><n>Brad and David are competing in a row boat regatta. The following conditions apply to the event:<n>1. Brad starts 500 yards and the finish line; David starts 100 yards and the line.<n>2. Their race will be 1 mile long.<n>3. David rows twice as fast as Brad.<n>4. After 15 minutes, David is 1400 yards ahead of Brad; David will win the race.<n>Brad plans to win with a 1 mile row in 36 minutes, which is 4 minutes faster than David. Should he do it?<n><n>### Response C<n><n><n>Rationales:<n>```c++;```<n><n>### Demos<n>Input:<n><n>```c++<n>char str[40];<n>while(scanf("%s", str)!= EOF)<n>{<n>    printf("%c", *str); // will print first character only -- in this case 'a'<n>}<n>```<n><n>Rationales/Demonstration:<n>```<n>//char str[40,]; --> if you have only one varibale, you dont have to use a character array<n>// char str[40] --> just use char<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>A bone of the same shape as a 100mm cube has a volume of 210 sq mm. What is the surface area of the bone? <n><n>## Solution<n><n>```c++(solution)``<n>int main(){<n>	<n>	int result = 210/6*6 + 210;<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A: hold is correct<n>D: lifted up is incorrect, use the verb "lift up" which is a command with two different meanings, or use "raised".<n><n><n>### InputA:  The restaurant closed 20 minutes ago, where is the waiter? Choices: 1. A: serving guests B: in his office 2. B: finishing paperwork 3. C: out to lunch<n><n>### ResponseA:  C: out to lunc is correct<n><n>B: finished paperwork is incorrect because it is an ongoing process.<n>A: serving guests is incorrect because it could have already been done earlier.<n><n>### InputB: The train left the station in 2.5 seconds, at a speed of 30 kilometers per hour. How far will it travel before the 10 second mark? Choices: A: 2.5 km B: 3 km C: 10 km D: The train will be traveling at 10 km per second at that point<n><n>### ResponseB: D: The train will travel at a speed of 10 km per seconds is correct<n><n>A: 2.5km is incorrect because that's half a kilometer<n>B: 3km is incorrect because that is a little short of a kilometer<n>C: 10km is incorrect, the distance is greater than a kilometer<n><n>### InputC: They were walking for about an hour, when they finally saw their destination. How much time is equivalent to an hour at a speed of 0.1 km per second? Choices: A. An hour is equal to 3,600 seconds B. The whole hour is more than 3,60 seconds C. An hour is equal t 60,000 seconds D. They were walking for 0.1 kilometer at a speed of 5.0 km per second<n><n>### ResponseC:  B. They were walking for more than 3,000 seconds is correct<n><n>C: more than 3, 000 seconds is greater than an hour<n>A: an hour is 3600 seconds is incorrect because they were walking for an hour<n><n>### InputD: The number of guests the restaurant can host is half the number of seats it can hold. However when 10 or

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		Input: The difference in heights between Jake and Gina is 4 feet. If Jake is 6 feet tall, what is Gina’s height?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input:(Multiple choice question)Choose the correct option.I am...A: going to the library.B: getting a coffee.C: reading a children's book.D: meeting my mom.<n><n>### Response:(Multiple choice question), Choose the correct option.The difference between _____ is 4. If the difference between _____ and _____ is 2 and _____ is 6, what is _____?<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the letters that correctly complete the blank.<n><n>### Input :There is a dog park in the city centre. It is near a high school, but it is not near a bus station.<n><n>### Output:A. The dog park is near the high school.<n><n>### Demo:<n>### Demonstraction output:<n><n>### Demo :<n>[![Demo](https://img.shields.io/badge/Demo%20-57.227-blue?style=flat-square&logo=github&logoColor=white&link=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DjJJjcLdJ9OY&label=Demo)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJJjcJdJ9OY)<n><n><n>### Explanation - Step-by-step :<n><n>**Explanation - 1st step :**<n><n>**Explanatin - 2nd step :**<n><n>---<n><n><n>### Instractions: Choose the option that completes<n>the sentence correctly.The _____ is _____ feet away from my<n>house.<n><n>### Answer: Option B<n>

You look in your bag to eat one of the apples. You have brought two bags. You know they are both the same size. You know that the red apple is less than one of the green ones. You also know that there is the same number of apples in the two bags. If you want to make sure you get an apple in each bag, which bag should you use for one of the apples?<n>Rationales<n>If the red apple is less, then it has to be the bigger.<n><n><n>```

Choices: A: May has 24 years old B: Mary has 22 years old C the 24-year-old twins D: May is in a play and May is in a play<n>### Response: May has 22 years by definition. Mary has 24 years. Mary is older than May.

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:During the brainstorming session there was a lot of talking and what? Choices:  A: obtaining information B: exchange of ideas C: sharing information D: conversation E: gathhering of information<n><n>### Response:		E<n>#### E<n>If they had a lot of information being shared that isn't going to work or help solve the problem. And if they are gathering information from the group then that isn't enough either. (A, B) What they really need is to keep the conversation going. (Giving and getting input).<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you see a mammoth in NYC? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: museum exhibit C: prehistoric times D: museum of natural history E: forest<n><n>### Response:		You can see a mammoth at the Natural History Museum on the west side of Central Park. They have fossils and stuffed mammoths.<n><n>#### Answer: A<n><n>### Input : If X is positive and Y is positive, how can you write the equation X + Y  = 7?<n><n>### Response :  Choices A:  X = 3 Y = 4 B:  X = 2 Y = 3 C:  X = 4 Y = 1 D:  X = 5 Y = 2<n><n>#### Answer: B<n><n><n>### Input<n>Input: The number of students in an advanced class in algebra is 3/4 of the number of students in an intermediate class in algebra. How many students are in the intermediate class in algebra? 95 students total are in both classes.<n><n>### Response<n>Choice A: Choose 2<n>Choice B: Choose 4<n>Choice C: Choose 24<n>Choice D: Choose 55<n><n>Rationales:If the number of intermediate class in algebra is 8, then 3/4 would be 2, since there is 8 students in the intermediate class in Algebra.<n>Since there 95 students in both classes, we know there are 85 students in the intermediate class and the advanced class has 10 students in them. <n><n>#### Answer: C<n><n>### Input <n>Input: Which of the following is true?<n>A. The total cost of a sweater is $4.56. The discount applies to the sweater. No discount applies to the shirt<n>B. The sale price is one-half the original price. The discount applies only to the sweater. The shirt costs half of the original price. No discount applies.<n><n>C. The sale price is $3.56. The sale price applies to the sweater and the shirt. No discount applies on the sweater.<n><n>D. The discount applies equally to the sweater and to the shirt<n><n>### Response <n><n>Rationales C. The sale price is "$3.56" It doesn’t say the discounts are applied to the sweater and shirt.<n>#### Answer : C<n><n>## Task:<n><n>You will solve simple problems and identify patterns and
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:How do you indicate that you agree wtih someone? Choices:  A: like more B: nodding C: by wearing rings D: concordance E: shake hands<n><n>### Response:		D,E<n><n>### <n><n>### Reference: https://www.thoughtco.com/grammar-rudiments-2694785

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		This question is about how many people you can fit into somewhere, such as a restaurant (seating 40 people), a country club (seating 60 people) or the lobby of a hotel (seating 140 people). In this situation, you can host as many people as is allowed by the place you've chosen for the reception, according to the number of people it can seat.<n><n>### Input :The bakery manager plans to display a cake so that 20 to 22 people can see it at the same time. They are short on display space. What is the maximum number of people that can fit into that display space?<n><n>### Response :A maximum of 22 people can line up in one row to be able to see the display. There can be 10 people in one row. If there are 5 in one row and 20 to 12 people see the cake on each side of that row, then 21 people are now in front of the display. But 20 to 32 people can still be in front of the display if another person would be added. Therefore, the answer to the question is 22.<n><n>### Rationales :<n><n>### Input:-In a classroom, 5 students can be seated at one table.  6 students get detention for talking too much.   8 students are going to a basketball game in the morning.  2 students are going on a field trip at 1:00.  How many more students can go to the game than were detained?<n><n>###Response : Students in the classroom minus students detained (5 - 6) = <<5-6=1>>1 available seat in the class room.<n><n>###Input:-There are 4 people in a room.  How many are not in the room?<n><n>###Rationales:-There are fewer people outside the room than there are inside. We are not counting the people who are outside too.<n><n>###Response:-There are 4 - 4 = <<4-4=0>>0 people who are not in the room.<n><n>## Exercise:Use the instructions and answer the remaining response questions.<n><n>## Exploration:

Choices:  A: sail boats B: question authority C: high fives D: share things E: learn from each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>Which answer would you give?<n>A: sail boats<n><n>You're a smart aleck.<n><n>### Justification:<n>You used an incorrect answer from the choices and did not provide adequate justification.<n><n>### Input:[The difference in ages between Richard]What did the instructor ask me to do? What did I do?How many answers did i give in total?<n><n>### Response<n><n>You can't change the past.<n><n>### Question:[The difference in ages]I guess i didn't read the whole question.<n><n>## Input:During their time together, which answer did the two groups agree on the most regarding the future? Choices: A: the best day of the week B: best time C: best activity D: who is to blame<n><n>## Response:<n>My friends got me out of a horrible situation, and i really owe them.<n><n>## Justification:<n>I did not choose the right amount of times.<n><n>## Input:[the two groups agreed on the most regarding]Which answer should I chose in this situation? <n><n>## Response:No. <n>The question seems to have 3 correct answers but it is really a trick question on the time part.<n><n>## Input:%<n>Who is to blame?<n><n>## Answer:<n>Answers should include all the choices.<n><n>## Justifications:<n>You used an answer that does not belong to the answer choices given.<n><n>## Input:-<n>Who is to blam<n><n>## Response:Who is to blame, my friends. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct answer is “D”. When a person wakes up they may experience the grogginess and discomfort. A person should first stretch and then get out of bed.<n>Answer: D: getting out of the bed<n><n>### Input : What is the best estimate of 2.394 * 5.342?<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>The best estimate would be <<2.394*5.342= 12.732>>12.73.<n>Answer: 13<n><n>### Input - The numbers 5 + 4 and 2 + 3 are said to be 9-digits long when it is written in expanded-form format and are said to be 6-digits long when written in standard form<n><n>### Demondation - What is a difference of the two numbers when each number is written in standard?<n><n>### How many numbers is the difference?<n>The difference between two numbers that are in standard form for 9-digit numbers is <<5+4-2+3=2>> 2<n><n>The numbers 5 + 9 must be in standard form to get -1. <n><n>The difference between 5 + 4 = 9 and 2 + 2 = 2 is <<5+4=9-2+2=2>>2<n><n>The difference is <<2>>.<n><n>There are two differences here, so there are <<2>> numbers.<n><n>#### 2, The difference is <<2>> number<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input-<n>The total sales for the month were $1575,  and the sales tax rate was 7%.  What was the amount in taxes collected?<n><n>### Output-<n>We have:  $1575 sales price, and a 7% tax rate = <<1575*.07= 116>> 116 as the tax collected!<n><n>### How did we decide this?<n><n>In our first step we did a ratio by division: 1575 /.07 and multipication by 116. <n><n>#### 116, Our answer choice is what is needed with division 1575:07. We want to get that answer with 15

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: B<n><n>Input: Masha was working during the week. She was able to buy something at the store. She bought $61 from the store and $63 from the bank. She bought the pizza for $6 and spent $12 on the ice cream. What is Masha’s favorite flavor?<n>Rationales:$63+6+12 = <<63+6+ 12=81>>81 from her bank<n>$61 + 6 = <<61+6=67>>68 total<n>So, $68 / 6 = <<68/6=11>>11 from her bank is saved, and $1 + 12 - 61 = <<1+12-61=5>>5 from her work is spent<n>Now, when combining $68 + 5, Masha has $73. Divide 73 by 6 to find her favorite flavor which is $<<73/6=12>>13<n>#### 12 <n>Answer: Blueberry<n><n>Input: The cashier received a $23.00 tip and his base pay was $300. She gave 40% to her boss and 10% to her babysitter. How much does she have left?<n>Rationales:# 	10% to her sitter, 40% to the boss = 50% total tips		<n>	$300 x 0.5 = <<300*0.5=150>>150<n>	40% + 150 = 190: Her tip totals = $190		<n>	190/40 = <<190/4=4.75>>4.75<n>	4.75 = <<4.75=13>>13<n>	# 	She has 4.75 - 23 = <<4.7-23=5>>5 more than she had before	<n>	# 	Her final total: $5 + 23 = >>5 + 23=28>>28 (She keeps all of the tips and then receives base pay as an added bonus)<n>#### 28

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen. Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Input: The jar was plastic, and John wished he was somewhere else, where does he want to be Choices: A: cupboard B anywhere else C: everything and D: own home E : garbage dump?<n>Rationales  The jar was plastic just like the stuff in the kitchen, and John wished he were someplace else, so probably he wants to somewhere else, he should choose C (everywhere else), because he cant be in any garbage or in any kitchen cabinets or kitchen cupboard or anywhere or everywhere only 1 place can he choose (and of course its not the garbage), and it should be (choices) C (everything)<n>#### 23<n><n>Answer: 23<n>```<n><n>### InputA group of 12 students was sharing a 900-page book. If each student read two pages each, how many students can read two pages at once?<n>RationalesIf each student read two pages, that's 24 pages for the whole book, so if 24 goes into 900, the answer will be how many students will be able to read two pages at a time?,<n><n>1 student will be able to read 25% of the book, 1 student will be able 24% of the book, and so on, the more the students are the more will be the chance for each student to read two pages at once<n><n>For example If the student will read 24 pages out of 90 pages with 2 students, if it is multiplied by 100 =24/90*100 = 0.2667, if this 0.26% is multiplied with the number of students, in our case 12, the result will be 0.31, 1 student will be the one that can be read one page at once.<n><n>In our example, the number of students will divide the whole number that we are dividing, with one one of each student, so the student with whom 900-90 = 810% was left will be the one that will read two pages at once.<n>####24<n><n>Answer: 19<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: It's probably some type of leftover since the forgotten leftovers got rather old and even moldy. It's probably a sandwich or pizza that was in the fridge. So answer A:Fridge.<n><n>#### E<n><n>Answer: Fridge.<n><n>### Input:"What's 925 + 5,035?" It was hard to keep my eyes open.<n>Rationales: 925 is + 150, to make 1075. (1075 is 5035-268)<n><n>```<n>925 + 150 = 1,075<n>5,035 - 268 = 4,767,<n>```<n><n>#### 4,763<n>Answer: 4,768<n><n>### Input"What's 18 - 24?" It was hard to look at the paper when I had it on my forehead."I don't know. That's 6. I think that means the question has to do with eyes."Rationales: 6 / 2 = 3, 18 - 12 = 59, 18 - (24-12) = 69<n>#### 69<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input "What's 6 + 9, divided by 3?"Rationales:<n><n>6 + 89 / 3 = 54 (correct answer)<n><n>Answer: 54<n><n>### Input When is it appropriate to use the verb 'to be'?"When the sentence is in first person, or if it's making a general statement".Rationales: I am. I see. You've seen me before. Are you there?<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input How old is Ben?Rationales:I say 85, he's like I said, I think I said like..."Rationales:Ben is 85.<n>Answer: 85<n><n>### Input What are you getting for dinner tonight, Dad?<n>Rationales:"Chicken."<n><n>#### Chicken<n>Answer: Chicken<n><n>### Input I like cheese
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A:  D:  E:<n><n>### Rationales:  The correct answer is D. When you are sad you cry, she is doing all the work, feeling sad = she is crying, so the correct answer is D.<n><n>**<n>### Input:The wife said that she was, <<what’s the correct word for “doing all the work”>> “who was doing all the work”<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Bill is stuck in marsh when a man comes up to him peaking Cajun, where is he? Choices:  A: low lands B: new york C: forest D: louisiana E: everglades<n><n>### Response:		<n>Bill is stuck in the marsh, therefore he is in Everglades. A marsh, which is part of the Everglades, is lowlands.<n><n>I hope this guide can be helpful for you.<n><n><br><n>Thank You for your understanding and support.<br><n>[<img src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32738164/46761267-b0831680-c6b8-11e8-98ac-e53f37a405a1.jpg" width="60" alt="Sad Monkey" />]<n>[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/A+PPLYS-Beta-375450?style=for-the-badge&logo=apples)](https://github.com/apples/A+PPLY)<n><n>## Contributing to this guide<n><n>First of all thank you for contributing to this guide. To better your contribution, be sure to do these following things.<n><n>* Run test<n>* Fill README with your contribution and provide a link to your github<n>* Write an instruction or an example that I will review to determine the content of the guide<n>* Add your information in the Contributors README<n><n>## Contributors<n><n>Contributors to this instruction guide are the following<n><n>* [Hemant Patel](https://github.com)<n><n>I hope to see you make a contribution soon!<n>Thank You for your help and support.<n><n>[<img src = "https://img.shivanshbansi.ca/logos/GitHub.png" alt="GitHub. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When eating everything on the tasting menu, what does one tend to feel? Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:Since you are having everything on a tasting menu, "on" means "a"<n>"taste" is singular, and "menu" can be both singular and plural, but the use of "a" tells us that the writer is taking "menu" to be singular.<n>##### D<n><n>### Demetri's t-shirt business is growing and he is constantly updating designs based on popularity. He is looking for a new logo to add to his shirts. A customer approaches him and offers his own designed logo. Demetri accepts, but wants to know how many shirts he would expect to sell with the new logo?<n><n>### Response<n>A logo that sells 5 of his shirts per month is reasonable.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Logo with 5 shirts per month = <<5 shirts per mont=5 shirts per mo=2/3>>2/3<n>Logo with 6 shirts per month could not be more reasonable because 5/6=.8 =<<6/5=.8>>0.8<n>5/6 = <<5/6=.8>>0.5<n>##### 0.8<n>##### 5<n>##### 5 shirts/per month<n>##### 0,5<n>### Input: You are going to a fancy restaurant and you are very hungry. At the restaurant you have the choice to eat one of the plates shown in the image. Which plate would you choose and explain your choice.<n><n>Input: You are going to the movies and you're very hungry. At a local cinema, there is a burger stand and you have the choice to buy one of these burgers shown in the image.<n><n>### Selection: The cheese and bacon one<n><n>### Selection Rationale: The only burger that looks big enough is the cheese and bacon burger<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The accelerator was controller via a hand throttle, and the foot pedals controlled the steering in the small what? Choices:  A: car B: fuel system C: accelerate D: boat E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demostrate<n>A gas pedal, used to accelerate your car?<n><n>### Answer<n>A<n>##<n>### Instruction<n>Pick the letter from the choices that best completes the problem.<n><n>### Input<n>A. He spent $12 on a suit and $15 on shoes. B. The suit cost $5.25. C. He spent a total of $32.50. D. He spent $1.25 more than he spent for the suit. <n><n>### Demonsstation:<n>A. Yes - he spent $12 on suit and $15 for shoes, therefore, $12+$15 = <<12+15=27>>27<n>Total: $27+12 = <<27+12=39>>39<n><n>### Answer:D<n><n>##<n>If a man's annual pay is $42,000, he'll have to work for 25 years.  How long will he have to work for a yearly salary of $12,000?<n><n>```<n>Input: $42000<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. $4200 x 25= $<<42000*25=105000>>10500<n><n>10500 /42= <<10500/42=251>>251 years<n><n>2. $420 x 25 = <<420*25=>1050>>105<n><n>105 /25= <<105/25=4.2>>4.2 years<n><n>3.  $4200/12= <<4200/4=105>>105<n>Or $4200*12= <<480000*12>>576000<n><n>So $105/12= <<37.20>>37.90 years<n>```<n><n>##<n>##<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You have enough fuel to fill the truck and fill each tank 3 times. You used the correct amount of fuel at the gas

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:He wanted a house that was gated off from other places, where should he start looking? Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: subdivision<n><n>Input: Sam’s uncle buys him a wrist watch because the Christmas holiday is coming. If he takes 4 months to pay for it, how much does he have to pay each month?<n>Rationales Sam’s uncle told him that he has to pay the total owed for a $<<=4>>4 months in 4 equal payments.<n>Since you already have the answer that you want for the $4, you just set up this equal equation:<n>The answer for $4 is $<<=4,4 months=<<=100>>100 divided by 4 payments = <<100/4=25>>25 dollars each<n><n>#### 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: A boy named Ben needs to go to the store to buy some clothes. If his father knows there is $114 in the wallet, and there is another $102 in the purse, would he have enough money to the buy clothes he wants?<n>Rationales There is a total of $216 in total between the wallet and the purse. If Ben buys clothes that cost $43, he would only have $173 left. To make $173 into $43, Ben would need $3 (173 ÷ 43 = <<173/43=3>>3) more dollars and would still have 88 cents left over<n>#### 0.97<n>Answer: 0.97
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Mark's semen was very thick, but after his vasectomy it was also what? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rationales:The cops will put him in jail because if jim doesn't do his job and kills people frequently then he will be a murder and if a criminal, he is in prison.<n><n>### Input:-23 + 99 = a, where 99 > -23 and 99 ≠ -23 <n><n>### Response:-23<n>Rationales:You should just use the difference between the two numbers.<n><n>### Response for the 4th and 5th questions (choose either one)<n><n>### Response (4):If a car's total production cost is $\$35,000$, what is the final price of the car?<n><n>### Rationales:We want to calculate the final cost of the car with the $\$35, 000$ as the total cost of production.<n>So we can write $\$35, $350 = <<35,350>>350 first, and then divide by 350 to find that 75 * 75 = <<75*75=562>>562 dollars.<n>This will be the actual price of the car.<n>#### 562<n>Answer: 562<n><n>### (5):What did the car make during the one minute time limit?<n><n>Rationales:We will divide one by the time limit to find out how many one minutes it made.<n>The final price of the car is $562 in one minute times 60 is $<<33,260>>33,261 dollars.<n><n>#### 33,262<n>Answer:33,263<n>### Input: A man’s age is twice the age of his son. In 3 years the son’s age will equal three times the father’s age at that time. How old is the man?<n>Rationales:-2 * 1= -2, 3 * -2= +6<n>His son will be 6 years old 3 years from now then he could go for 2+6= 10 years old.<n>From there 6+3 = 1 or 10-3 = 2.5 and man's age is 2.5<n>####
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a grumpy person likely to have? Choices:  A: headache B: understand themselves C: compliments D: own house E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		A:headache<n><n>### Input:"It seems that your work is very good.  You can improve it with a little work.  I can tell you it will 30.49 times easier" Choices: A: Be very excited B: Know more C: Sound more impressive D: Sound more intimidating<n><n>### Response:"A:Be very excited"I can tell you it will sound 30.4 =  >>>30.49*100=3049>>3049 times easier"E=30.4 times as easy<n><n>### Input : If two coalesce, the third one stays? Choices: B or C:  You can’t answer, its a trick question.   (D)  Yes, A and B coalesce, so C stays and A becomes C,  (E) No, A and B cannot coalesce, C becomes B (A) Yes, The order of the letters does not matter (B) No, C and A can’t coalesce, B becomes C  (C) Yes, A and B can’t coalesc

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? Choices:  A: under rocks B: manhattan C: toenails D: grocery store E: fallen tree<n><n>### Response:		<n>A fungus could grow in E.
