E is a fallen tree.<n><n>### Rationales<n>A fungus could not grow on manhattan because the sun is always shining on manhattan and the surface of the sun is hot. Manhattan could not be a good place for fungi to grow.<n><n>A fungus could no grow in B. The sun is always shining and the surface of the Sun is hot so the sun would not make a good place for fungus to grow.<n><n>C is not a good place for fungii to grow. It may have mold in it but because the surface of the Sun gets hot, fungii would not grow in the manhattan.<n><n>D is not a good place to grow fungui. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does sex often make happen in people? Choices:  A: making love B: feel good C: happyness D: wonderful thing E: cloud judgment<n><n>### Response:		D: wonderful thing <n><n><n>### Instructions:For each of the questions, write a complete sentence that addresses the topic. Use your own writing.<n><n>### Practice: A woman bought a car and paid in full. She had the car paid off in year 2, when she traded it in. How long did she have to pay for the car?<n><n>### Answer: She paid for the car in year 1, so how many years was that?  In year 2, she traded it in for a new car.  How long did she have the first car?  The answer would be year 2 - 1 = year 1.  The length of time she had the car would be total of years 2 - 1 (years she had car) + 1 (where car was paid off) <n><n>### Explain:How do you find the difference between two years?<n>Multiply 2 by -1 - 2<n>Multiply 1 by -2 (-1-2)<n>-3 - 3 => 0<n>- 4 - 4 = 0<n>The difference between two years in negative 2.<n><n>### Examples of multiplication:<n>3 x 6 = 18<n>2 x 2 = 4<n><n>### Expanded<n>2 x 6 = 2 x (2+2+2+2) = 8 + 8 + 8+8 = 32<n><n>Examples:<n>Addition:<n> 2 + 4 = 6<n>Subtraction:<n> 16 - 2 = 14<n><n>### Explanation <n>The addition and subtraction problem are based off the addition of the 2's value.<n><n>10,000+1,0000=11 000<n><n>### Exact <n>10,031 + 1,026 = 11057<n><n>### Expect the Unexpected<n>Add all of the two's value in a number to get the correct result.<n><n>Adding all value of a 2 in number is same as adding the value of the number.<n><n>### Question 3A:<n>What is greater:  0.999 + 0.499?

Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "D. A is incorrect "because there was no question mark after "attracting ducks". That is incorrect because there must be a question mark because he is asking you a question. You also need the answer to the question in that sentence, so in other words, you need to give him the correct answer in order for him to "attract ducks".<n><n>### Input : The doctor has diagnosed the patient with a form of cancer that has a treatment that has an 80 percent success rate. If the doctor has the option to give 10 percent of the patients a second treatment that has an 65 percent success rate, how many percent of patients must she give this second treatment in order for the average success rate for the treatment to remain at 80 percent.<n><n>### Explanation : First, find 50% of the 80% of success rate, 1 cancellation, to cancel the last 2 percentages, you have 80%-0.2 = 79.8.<n><n>79.8/100=79.8/50=159.6<n><n>Thus 50% of 159.6=159.8<n><n>Next, find 159.8 - 51.47=108.33<n><n>108.3 divided by the 100% success rate (of treatment option 1=0.1) = the number of patients that should be given 10% second option treatment = 1083/0.1=10830<n><n>#### 10830/100=1083/36% = 350/36=100/36=2/3<n><n>Answer 3/3<n><n><n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If someone is aloof and self-important, what is their experience when meeting people? Choices:  A: stress B: nervousness C: smile D: being bored E: making new friends<n><n>### Response:		If someone is alopecia, they likely have bald patches on their head.<n><n>### Input<n>How many square feet of carpet does it take to cover an area with dimensions 80 feet long and 40 feet wide?<n><n>### Rationale<n>80 x 40 = <<80x40=3200>>3200<n>#### 3200<n>Answer: 3200.1<n><n>### InputSix-legged animals have two pairs of legs, which are referred to as ___. Choices: A: fours B: eights C: pairs D: triplets E: two<n><n><n>### Rationalesix-legged animals do not have fours, as that refers to four legs. Similarly, their legs are not called eight, triples, or pairs because they don't use those terms for legs having two legs. So, the only logical choice is "two":<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n><n><n>### InputYou would like to make 43 cupcakes. If you used 2 cups of cake mix and 2 cups of frosting, how many cupcakes could you make?<n><n>### ResponseSince the 43 cupcakess are all made out of the same ingredients, we can equate that to the ratio of 43:2(in our problem 43 cupcaked:2 ingredients) and solve for x:x=432 or 43 x = 2<n>#### 2<n><n>### InputIf one person does something every 2 hours or 2 people do something every hour, how many people work that task compared to the other?<n><n>###Rationale2 hours is the same as every hour, so there's more than one person doing the task.<n><n>#### 2 or more<n>Given that<n>1. there are 2 pairs of shoes and 2 sandals at home.<n>2. 4 more pairs of shoes and sandals need to be ordered from the store.<n><n>Find how many pairs can be ordered.<n><n><n># HINTS<n>When solving the problem, always remember to<n><n>1- use math symbols<n>2- be accurate with input data<n>3- use your knowledge of common sense and rationales to solve problems<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would a person keep a book while it's being read? Choices:  A: closet B: library of congress C: classroom D: in bed E: desk<n><n>### Response:		If the book is being read by a person, then it is likely they have a bed to lay it on.<n><n>### Answer: 4<n><n>### Rationale:Bed<n>#### 4<n><n>## 3.<n>- [x] Write a response that appropriatley completes the request. Do NOT copy the example.<n><n>- [x] Use a rationale for each answer. Do NOT copy the examples.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? Choices:  A: no go B: unlikely C: unable D: cant do E: impossibility<n><n>### Response:		I think C<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a folding chair if you do not plan to use it and you do not have any large doors in your house? Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n><n>### Response:		<n>Put it at the closet because the school can be crowded so don't put the chair at School and beach may need money to park cars there so not beach<n><n>#### 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### InputThe math teacher gave homework due in 7 days. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:They were getting together for the big game, he wasn't hosting but made sure to bring pretty of food with him over to where? Choices: A: Rugby B: football C: Baseball D: Basketball E: soccer ***<n><n>### Response They were getting together for A: Football<n><n>***<n><n>#### Bonus Points:<n><n>## If, then (if condition, then choice):<n><n>  **A:** If he makes the basketball team, then he will ask his girlfriend to his prom.<n><n>## Else if, then (else if condition, then choice): <n><n>  **Else if**: If Pablo reads books that add up to exactly 150, then Pablo will get exactly $1.50 for every book.<n><n>## Else (else if condition, THEN choice):  **Else:** If they cannot figure out the problem together, then they should call the teacher.<n><n>##  Else if..then (else if condition, choice): <n><n>**Else if**: If he wants to eat lunch at the cafeteria, then he can bring his bag to school.<n><n>## If..then (if condition,then choice): <n><n>   **If**: If she is going to the party or on the cruise, then her dad will have to take care of her younger siblings. <n><n>**Then**: If she is in math class, then math will be a waste of time.<n><n>## If, else: <n><n>   **if:** If the score is between 70 and 79, then he made 100% on his test<n><n>   **else:** If the score was not between 70 and  79, then I have to retake your test.<n><n>## If then:   **if:**  If it is cold in the winter, then we can play hockey<n><n>   **then:**  If he wants to be a good hockey player, then he' ll need to work hard.<n><n>## If:  <n><n>  **If:** He is having a birth

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sam went to Paris where he ordered a blowfish at a sushi place. Choices:  A: books B: france C: fish market D: atlantic ocean E: cuba<n><n>### Response:		Sam went to Paris, France.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n>### Demontration:<n>Sam went to the sushi place in France, so he was in France.<n>The sushi place in Paris probably has raw fish. How many grandchildren does he have?<n><n>## Demostradion: One son's x, which is also one daughters, makes the man's grandchildren's number to 6, two daughters' x make the grandchildren's number from five to seven grandchildren. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n><n>### Response:		You committed perjury so you will face a number of different possibilities, such as arrests or even time sentences in jail.<n><n>Rationales: All the choices, A-E will result in a negative consequence. It's just a matter of how serious those consequences are.<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input and instruction: Your roommate asks if you would help them move their heavy desk. Write a response that matches the request.<n><n><img src="img/img_questions/680433_1740084821062458_174819063790878421_n.jpg"><n><n>### Demostration:<n><img src="../IMG/instructions/688789_1932780023852868_3267887521366787040_n.jpg">Answer: Yes, I will help you move this heavy desk from <a href="..\\..\img\img_questions\688786_1938561823813576_2813735279966559600_n.jpg" target="_blank">the school</a> to <a href="..\..\img\img-questions\688349_1806543715418690_1501747134936984992_n.png" target="_blank"><a href="..\img\img\img_question\4036246024691687633_p.png">my house</a>.<n></a><n><n>#### Answer: Yes<n><n>### Input Instruction:You've got your hands on 100 new textbooks for your school. You can donate them for $6 each or you can sell them for $15 each. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What might a kid do with his friend before going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: <n><n>### Rationale:<n>They are already playing together, they might laugh for fun. But they need to be entertained somehow before they can move to other more physical activities like games.<n><n>### Answer: <n>A<n><n>### Input 2: What might a kid do with their friend before going to play. Choices: A: laugh B: eat C: math  D: sit  E: meet<n><n><n>### Response 2:<n>B<n><n>### Rationales 2:<n>Eat food and drink water are the most important things to do before going to play, because it helps to keep your energy level and focus, also it makes you strong and healthy, but before you do anything, you always need to listen to your health teacher first.<n><n>### Response2 Answer:<n>B<n><n># Programming Task #1<n><n>Input:<n>```<n>Enter a string: "banana"<n>Enter an integer: -2<n>```<n>The string entered is banana, and the number entered is "-2".<n><n>output:<n><n>```<n>banana<n>----------------<n>banana<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n>This program was built using a for loop. It can be used to loop through an array or list, but that was not necessary for our example. It simply allows us to output multiple identical lines of text to the console.<n><n>We first begin by defining the variable ```i``` which is the index the program will use, and then define ```str``` as the string that will represent the characters we want to print.<n><n>```<n>i = 0<n><n>for i in range (0, 5,1):<n>  print(str[i])<n><n>else:<n>  continue<n>```<n><n>Now that we have defined the variable ```i``` (which is our index) and the string ```str```, it is time to define some simple if logic so that we can perform a specific task if the condition is met, otherwise skip that line.<n><n>```<n>if i == 0:  # if our index is 0, print zero<n>  print ("zero")<n><n>else:<n>   # if our index is **NOT** 0, skip the command<n>```<n><n>Continue adding statements to your for loop where all characters are checked for equality to zero, then the output is printed out with the statement in your code.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A soccer field that is not contained in a building would be where? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input<n><n>Which of the following is not an example of an open source software? Choices:  <n>A. WordPress   <n>B. Firefox   <n>C. Internet Explorer   <n>D. Google<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>Internet Explorer (IIE) is a proprietary web browser.  Firefox, WordPress, and Google are open source software. Open source refers to software that is freely available to anyone and anyone is encouraged to modify, share, and redistribute it. Proprietary software, which Internet Explorer (IIE) and the other closed platforms are, is protected as copyrighted property.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>B. Firefox<n><n>### Input  <n>Why does the teacher make the students sing the Pledge everyday?<n><n>### Rateoles:<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Teachers always sing along when students sing the pledge of allegiance and have made it a tradition, so some students started to complain to the teacher about always having to sing the pledge of allegeince. The teacher then made it compulsory until this situation get better.<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Rationals<n>A <n>### Answer<n>a<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n><n>### Response:		The above question is asking for an "Animal". So, this is an instance of an "Either/ Or" question, where "Either" would refer to A or B, and "or" would refer to C,D or E. This problem is easy because there is information missing from the data (the animal) so that we cannot answer the question directly. However, if we apply a bit of reasoning, we can come up with an answer, and then provide a rational answer. The key to solving this type of a problem is to find either a rule or pattern (if there is one) that can apply to the missing information, which will either (Animal and information provided, or Animal and no information given). Then, we choose an answer based on the rule or pattern.<n><n>Based on the question, I assume that this is meant to be asking where a real animal is likely to be caught (not in England, maybe?). The other answers (Tennessee, grassy field, or forrest) all have a ton of detail about where something might be or not be caught. The information in England feels like a "maybe" answer that would go with either option. So, with the data (animal, and possibly animal and no data) we have two options for the question: either and either, so based on that, answer is C or D as they include either the animal or no data about it. So the answer would be C  or D. So the rational answer would be along the lines of "the animal could be [Option C or D, and based on the data, animal is probably B and that data is missing]"<n><n>#### C <n><n>Answer: Grassy field<n><n>or<n><n>D<n><n>#### D<n><n>Answer: England<n><n><n>### Instuction:Input:Which is greater, 72% or 93%?<n>Output: Greater is 93% because there are 100 more percentages in 93% than there are in 72%.<n><n>Rationales:72% is 72/100 because % is decimal, and there are 10 units in 1%, 10 x 1/10 = 10/10 so 100 is 10/1.<n>93% is not 93/1.<n>In order to make 100

Choices: A: -4.1902968969 B: -1.6 C: 2 D: 64,E: 43.875.<n><n>### Response : B<n><n>### Input Where is likely to have more than 40 fire extinguishders?  Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Input What is the largest positive fraction that can be expressed as the reciprocal of another fraction using a number between 0 and 1? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What emotion does getting paid lead to? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Use the language used.<n>```<n># Task 2:<n># Instruction:What does it mean for a value to be prime? Explain.<n># Demonstration <n># A number is prime if it is greater than 1 and is not the product of two smaller whole numbers.<n>#<n># Prime numbers and factors<n># A prime number is a counting number that is greater than 1 that is not the product of the multiplication of any two smaller counting numbers.<n>#<n><n># An Example (1,000,000):<n># 1,000 000<n># 4 digits - 2,500,001 -> 2*500,0,01<n>```<n><n>#### What Does It Mean for a Value to Be Prime?Explain.:<n>### (I have left it up to you how you explain it but try to use your own words)<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>A number is prime if it's a number, greater than one, and is not the product or combination of two smaller numbers.<n>#### 0<n><n># Instruction: Answer as many questions as you can.<n>```<n># Instruction:Answer as many questions as you as can.<n># Demonst<n>#<n># ☐A. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James complained that Alexa's electric guitar was too loud and he couldn't get any work done at home,  so she decided that she should get an acoustic guitar.  Where might she look for one? Choices:  A: house B: music shop C: studio D: storage E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Input:The store has 3 identical TVs on sale at $1200,  but there are only 2 left in stock so the price has to increase to $1350.  If the extra tax of $30 for the sale of electronic goods is now increased to $35, will the price increase 10%?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Simply subtract the sale tax rate 30% from the sales tax rate 35% to see that the sales tax rate has increased 10%.<n><n>$$30 - 35 = -5$$<n>$$\frac{5}{100}=-\frac{5}{1200}$$<n>$\%$ is not equivalent to decimal, so 10% is not equal to `.05$$.<n>$10\% = \frac{\%}{100}$ = \$\frac{5}{1500}\%$\#<n><n>#### 50<n><n>Answer: no, because the sales tax will increase to 35%.<n><n>### Input:#A car accident happened on an icy road.  A group of witnesses saw what happened, but there are 9 in the group.  The first group told the authorities what happened, but only 90% of what they saw.  The second group did the same, but got 97% of the total.  The third group gave only 9 times less information.  After that, 83% of the witness gave statements, which was just less information than the third group.  Which group of witnesses have given most accurate testimonies?<n><n>### Response:#The second group of 9 witnesses provided 9% more information than the first.<n><n>### Input#:#A store sells chairs.  Each chair costs $40 and there are 4 in each shipment.  They get 2 shipments per week, one with 20 chairs and one with 60 chairs.  They have one chair seller and the seller earns $100 per week.  Which shipment should the seller look after?<n>### Rationals:There are 80 chairs<n>$20x2 + 60x1 = 80$<n>$60 > 40$<n>So that
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		A: complete sentence<n><n>### Why?<n>A person may feel angry if his or her money has been stolen, but he or she would feel disappointed and upset.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The phrase `whole amount` suggests that a money may have been stolen.<n><n>```<n>feel : emotional state<n>      A feeling may have been lost.<n>      What feeling may have been lost?<n><n>disappointment : emotional state<n>frustrated :  emotional state<n>  A feeling may have been broken.<n> angry : emotional state<n>    He may have been disappointed and angry.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: The difference in ages among the students in a class is evenly distributed among the students in a way that there 1 is fewer boys than girls. If there are 100 boys in the class, how many girls are there?<n><n>## Demonstration: If there is a 400/200 2/5 chance, there is the remaining 500/600 6/10 chance.<n><n>### 300/150<n>Answer: 300/50<n><n>### Instruct: The number of jellies in the store is a perfect square of the number of jellies sold. It took five and a half boxes of jellies to get to the next whole number. If there are more than 1000 boxes of jellies in the shop, how many boxes of jellies are there in all?<n><n>### Demostraton: If there are 18 jellies in each box, there will be 100 boxes of jelly, which equates to 2000 jelly boxes.<n><n>### If there are 14 jellies in each box:<n><n>### 2800 jelly boxes<n><n>### Rationale :<n><n>### 1200<n><n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following question.<n><n>## Examples:<n>- 14 x 9 = 126. The whole number before 126 is 125.<n>- 15 x 10 = 150. The whole number before it is 149

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>A is strongest, B is the opposite, and C is the weakest<n>```<n>*  Glass that hasn't treated to be extra strong?<n><n>    -> Glass that hasn' t treated to be extra strong = A<n><n>    Because Glass that hasn’t been treated to be  extra strong<n>        A has to be strongest.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Rationale:<n>*  Glass can be fragile, forceless, fragile, forceles, regular, and flimsy<n><n>    -> Gloss can be anything but strongest and weakest.<n>Fragile = B<n>Forces = C<n>Regular = E<n><n>### Input :<n>Fragile means ________ and regular means ________. If you wanted to make yourself less fragile, you would do what? Choices: A: treat the glass with a liquid<n>B: place your hand over the glass<n>C: place your hand on the glass<n>D: place the glass under running water<n>E: replace it with sturdier glass<n><n>### Response :<n>```<n>Fragile means forceless and regular means forceless<n> <n>     ==> Fragile means forceles<n>     ==> Regular means forceles<n><n>```<n>*  Fragile means forcikeless and regular means forcible<n><n>    -> Fragile means forcible and regular means fragile<n><n>*  Regular<n>Fragile<n><n>### Exlanimation :<n><n>### Rationa:l<n>*  Fraglie = Fragile<n>*  Regular = Regular<n><n>### Input<n>Fragile means_______ and regular means_____. If you wanted to be more fragile, you would want to do what? Choices : A: treat the glass wih a liquid<n>B: put your hand over the glass.<n>C: put your hand on the glass.<n>D: put the glass under running water.<n>E: use sturdier glass<n>```<n><n>### Rationales<n>Fragile means regular and regular means fragile because regular doesn’t fit in with this explanation<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>Regular means Regular<n><n>    ->  Regular means Regular<n>        ->  Regular means fragile<n>        ->  Regural

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: What is an area with no…<n>Rationales: Area with no grass means that the area has to have some surface that can support vegetables and fruits. These areas could be found in a supermarket, garden, state park, or rest area. Those places can be found on the surface of earth.<n>The choice is between <n>Supermarket, rest area, and state park.<n>The rest area is an area with no car parking zone. It is also located inside a highway. <n>Aside from being found on the surface of the earth, a rest area can be found inside the surface of the earth.<n>The supermarket is a building. It is a place that sells food and can be found on the  surface.<n>The supermarket has no grass, that is why we are looking for an <n>area with no grass where it can be found on the earth.<n><n>The only choices that are left are<n>Supermarket and state park<n><n>The choice has to be between <n>Supermarket and state <n>park because the state park is also not in an open ground. It is an area inside a forest, but it is not found on the surface of <n>earth.<n>#### A<n><n>Answer: Supermarket<n><n>### Input/Output:<n>Choose from options listed.<n><n>### Input Beneath Each Choice:<n>The choice is between:<n>A: surface of earth<n>B: rest area<n>C: supermarket<n>D: state park<n>E: garden<n><n>## <n>## Output<n>> Your answer<n>A or B<n>C<n>D<n>E<n><n>## How'd I Do?<n><n>### Instant Feedback<n>A: Supermarket<n><n>> Congratulations! You got it right.<n> <n>> 	 <n><n>### Reason<n><n>The state  park is also a parking lot, and it can be found in a forest. These areas can be found on the area of the earth where trees can be found.<n><n>### Source<n><n>[CodingBat C++](https://codingbat.com/prob/p292846)<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:They checked the weather one more time during the flight, they were on their way to paradise and wanted it to what? Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>The master of their craft will have a craft that is highly skilled.<n>Another way of looking at it would be that, the master will do things that no one else knows how to do in their craft.<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input 9:<n>Ravi has 833 3/4 coins.  If he sells them for 50 4/9 cents each,  then how much change does he get?<n><n><n>### Inputs 10,11,12:<n><n>Mrs. Waters has 2/5 of her hair colored.  Her son has blue eyes and her daughter has green eyes.  What are the other four eye colors?<n><n><n>## What did Harry win?<n>Harry won a game.<n><n>## What were the 2 questions about multiple choice questions?<n>The 2 questions were about multiple choice questions and how to give a mathematical explanation for the answer.<n><n>## What kind of ruler was found in a museum?<n>A logarithmic ruler.<n><n>## What is the 2nd question about multiple choice questions? <n>The 2nd question is about finding out the answer to a math question, and then explaining what that answer is. <n><n>## What is a logarithmic ruler?<n>A type of ruler that has a logarithmic scale <n><n>## What was the first multiple choice question?<n>You were asked to tell how many eggs a chef had to use to make cakes and the answer was 10 eggs<n><n>## What is wrong about using log lines in the museum?<n>The log lines that were in the museum belonged to a ruler that was used by a mathematician. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		<n>*A<n><n>### Input : <n>She had a rough time on the hike but was able to get past her? Choices: <n>*B: resume<n>*C: lighter<n>*D: snacks<n>*E: obstacles<n><n>### Response : <n>*E<n><n>### Input & Instruction:<n>Courtney’s dog, Hodor, can be distinguished from the other dogs by noting that she never lets her dog roam freely. What is the advantage of keeping Hodor contained?<n><n>### Response<n>*E<n><n><n>### Instructions:1. What rule does Mr. Matsudaira make  for his students when he corrects their papers? 2. What is a 5-minute rule? 3. What does the word “practice” in the  paragraph below mean?<n><n>### Instructed:1. To try something out d. Bad e. Mistake-making<n><n>### Answer:a,c,e<n><n>### Input<n><n>The Tale of Genj was written between 1000 and 1012 CE. It contains an excerpt with the following question:<n>What rule does Mr. Matusdari make for his students when he  corrects their papers?<n>Answer:<n>All errors must be corrected so that the mistakes on the paper are erased<n>### Answer<n><n>He had strict rules for correcting papers. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. Name this item? Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### E<n><n>### Input<n>The electric motor powered one of almost every electric appliances, including electric drill.<n><n>### Rationales<n>Since it says one *almost* every, it should be E.<n><n>### Answer:<n>#### E<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n><n>### Response:		<n>If I am a person I have a unique ability.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>For a person to be a person, it has to have a unique ability. If a person doesn't have a unique ability then it doesn't have the characteristic of "being a person"<n><n>### Input<n>I am a 9th grader attending a private high school. I have a unique ability which is A: to run a mile in <11 minutes B: to run a half marathon C: to read without glasses D: to make a paper airplane fly E: to have 426 teeth<n><n>### Exploration:<n><n>- I need to come up with a way to show that I have a unique ability (which I think I can do)<n>- I might get a paper and make some paper airplanes on there so I can explain why I can throw them and get them to go fast<n>- I can also use the paper airplanes as examples of why I'm awesome<n>- Also, making 426 teeth is really cool to say but I probably won't be able to use that because I probably won't have that many teeth<n><n>### Rationales<n>If I can do all of these then I must have a unique ability<n><n>My unique ability:<n>- I can run a mile in 11 minutes<n>- I can read without glasses<n>- I can make paper airplanes which fly<n>- I have 426 teet<n><n>Because I can do these things, I have a unique abilities which is A: to read without glass, B: to fly a paper airplane, C: to run a mile under 11 minutes, D: to have 432 teeth<n><n>### Demolission:<n>All of these are answers but maybe in different ways<n><n>### Output:<n>I have a unique ability to: read without glasses, fly a paper airplane and run a mile in less than 11 minutes<n>#### 426<n>Answer: 426<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>- I am a college student.<n>- My unique ability is speaking spanish.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>If I am speaking spanish, there is a good chance that I do that well.<n><n>### Outputs:Spanish.<n><n>####
