If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could you see an advertisement while reading news? Choices:  A: television B: bus C: email D: web page E: la ville<n><n>### Response:		The answer for this question is A and D.<n>#### A : Television<n>Today, we usually read online blogs, news sites, newsletters and magazines, watch online videos etc. In addition to those, we can also see an advertisement on TV while watching news broadcasts.<n><n>#### D : Web Pages<n>We can mostly find advertisements on websites such as blogs, news sites and so on.<n><n>### Input; Find 10 in the image.<n>![Find the number](https://i.imgur.com/oQxbNwL.png)<n><n>### Response; The answer for this image is 9.<n>#### 9<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Instruciton:<n>Write a response to the following multiple choice question that appropriately completes this request.<n><n>## Demonstration: Input: Which of the following best describes how many of the following events occurred in 2020: A: 6 B: 7 C: 8 D: 16 E: 20<n>Rationales: 8 events did occur in 2021: 2020 (new year), pandemic, COVID test, virtual meeting, COVID self-test kit, telehealth services, video conference and working from home<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Challenge<n>#### 2: I have four pieces of information. Which one is missing?<n>* The sum of the ages of my parents is 89 years<n>* My father is 10 years older than I am<n>* I am the same age as my sister<n>* My father is six years older than my sister.<n><n>### Challenge Answer;<n>The missing info is the age of mom.<n><n>The sum of the ages of mom, dad, and me is 89 years.<n>Mom is 10 years younger than her husband, so she must be the wife; and is 49 years old.<n>Dad is 49 years older than me, so he must be my father; he is 69 years old.<n>Sister is 21 years old, so my sisters age must be 9.<n>Dad must be 10 years older, therefore my sister is 6, and my brother is 9.<n>Because my d

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Jamie wanted to reduce her waist size, but all of her efforts failed miserably. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:She loved buying products, she was driven by her what to shop more than any practical needs? Music store has someone playing the cello.<n>4. Music store has someone who plays the cello.<n><n>### Input; What is the difference between 5/12 and 15/12?<n><n>### Response; Their difference is 15 - 5<n><n>### Rationales;<n>Start by writing how many times 12 goes into 15<n>15/12 = 1.25<n>Since 12 goes into it, 5 goes into 15/1.25<n>1.25*5 = 6.25<n><n>### Input : How many times does 48 go into 162?<n><n>## #Rationale:<n>1. Calculate how many times 48 goes into 162<n><n>162/48 = 3.43<n><n>## Output<n><n>### Response1:24<n>The first number is.375, the second number is the multiple of this, 8.75.<n><n>### Response2: 19<n><n>### Response3: 8<n><n>### Response4: 7.882<n><n>### Response5: 9.5<n><n>### Response6: 28<n><n>### Ratios:<n>- A ratio compares two numbers<n><n>- To write a ratio, write the second term over the first<n><n>- You can write a ratio in any equation with any set of values.<n><n>- If you want to find the ratio of a number to the second number (numerator divided by the denominator), it is the reciprocal of the second number (denominator divided by the numerator)<n><n>- Example #1: Fractions:<n><n>4 divided by 3/5 = 4/5<n>3/5 divided by 4<n>4 divided by 5/4 = 4/5\* 4/5 = 4<n><n>- Example #2: Percentages:<n><n>32%/10 = 32/10<n><n>## Input:<n><n>- $2.50<n><n>- $4<n><n>- $5<n><n>Find the value

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer-C<n><n>## What-If<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A person lived in my what? Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n><n>### Response:		<n>The person lived in a building<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n><n><n><n><n>

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. For each activity type, also write one whole number or fraction to reflect the number of weeks/days it would take to complete by 2 or 3 people. Use a different fraction from the previous line for "two" and three.<n><n>#### 3.  For each project type, write one whole number for the shortest amount of time it will take to complete the project under each type of activity. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sally lost her kite because she wasn't careful.  She thought that there was more string on the spool, but it slipped out of her fingers when she reached the what?. Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		Choice E<n><n>Rationales: Because Sally thought her kite string had more string on the spoo but, when she reached out for the string she slipped and lost the kite.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How much does each ice cream flavor cost at an ice cream parlor?<n><n>Chocolate: $3.75 Ice Cream: $4.25<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Answers:<n><n>Chocolate cost: $3.725 x <n><n>Ice Cream cost: $4.225 x <n>The total cost would be =<n><n>Answer: $8.95<n><n>###  Instructions:<n>If 15 pencils cost $10.50, how much does 75 pencils cost?<n>Answers: <n>How much does one pencil cost? <n>$0.07 A: <n>What number times more is one pencil than 70? <n>750 Answer: <n>What number would I have to multiply by to get.87? <n>8.7 A: <n>If 15.25 is 25% of how much the pencils cost, what is the amount? <n>$45 Answer: <n>What does 10.5 pencils cost more than 30. <n>$30.5 or 31 Answer: <n>What did 19.25 pencils cost when multiplied with.71? <n>$14 or 14 Answer: <n>What's 19.27? <n>$15 Answer: <n>If I multiply that by 6, what's the answer? <n>$0 and 0? 90 Answer: <n>75. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>1.The sun is 32400 miles away from earth.<n>2.When the earth orbits the sun in one day, how many times does the moon orbit the earth?<n><n>### Input Response<n><n>#### 4<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately replies to the above questions.<n>

What is that number?<n>Rationales There are 3 digits in the number, that means there are 3^3=<<3^3=27>>27 possibilities.<n>Third column 2 digit number(column3) =<<2-3-4>>2,3,4.<n>Therefore to find the number, column1, column4.<n>Column1, column4 =<<2+(56-367-2)>>2+(56-0-2) 54 -->54.<n>#### 54<n>Answer: 54<n><n>### Input Tap 3 times to change the song. Choices:  A: sights B: optical illusion C: optical telescope D: light microscope E: binocular<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Answer Explanation<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of jogging? Choices:  A: insect repellent B: heart attacks C: improved health D: shin splints E: being tired<n><n>### Response:		Input:What is a good reason to exercise? Choices: A: to lose weight B: to keep your body in shape C: to make your heart stronger D: for good health E: to protect your heart<n><n>Rationales: The options do not exactly match, but there are some connections between the two.<n>For instance, B and D both refer to making your body in shape. Similarly, B and E refer to making your heart stronger.<n>The only options that do not have similarities are A and C.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input:"Today is a very important day for me." says the prince. For which event has he been preparing? Choices:  the coronation the wedding his marriage his birthday his crowning<n><n>### Response:"Today I have the chance to be promoted in my job." how long has it been since the speaker has started work at the company?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sometimes fighting inflation isn't even what, because it is so negligible? Choices:  A: economic instability B: not noticeable C: spend more D: rising interest rates E: boring<n><n>### Response:		C; spend more.<n><n>### Input;<n>A: economic instability - When a certain amount of money in a nation doesn't have the same purchasing power as before, the term "inflation" applies. Inflation is a problem because the economy will not operate correctly.<n>B: not noticeable - Inflation isn't a problem when it's small. It does cause problems at certain levels, but it's possible to overlook inflation when it happens once in a while.<n>C: spend more - When there is inflation, it means there is too much money in circulation. When there is inflation you can't spend more. You need to spend less to avoid it.<n>D:Rising interest rates - When there is inflations, the Federal Reserve will raise the interest rate to get people to save more on loans. The lower interest rate the higher is inflation.<n>E: boring - The interest rate rising is important to people.<n>#### 2<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:Analyze the following situation<n><n>### Answers:D<n><n>### The two sisters spent their weekends working on their yard, when they were out their neighbours noticed that one of the flower beds was overgrown and the grass was 14 inches high. This is because they hired a cleaning service to do the housework. They spend at least 7 dollars on gardening supplies, while they also spend 19 dollars on cleaning supplies.<n><n>### So if we take the equation 14 inches = $ << 7 x 14 = 98>>98, it means that cleaning the garden is not so effective. As far as the number of dollars spent to save more grass, they only spend $122.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is necessary for learning by yourself? Choices:  A: exposure B: patience C: study D: cooperation E: thought<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: Exposure: A is the right answer.<n>Cooperation: B is the right answer.  It could be a friend or a sibling.<n>Thought: C is the right answer.  <n><n>Answer:  A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>What will each of the following methods show for the quotient?<n><n>### Method:<n>Input: 6 ÷ 2<n>Rationales: 6 ÷1 = <<6 ÷1=6>>6<n>and 3 ÷ 1 = <<3 ÷1=3>>3<n>So 6 ÷ 3 = <<6 ÷3=2>>2<n>Input: 7 ÷ 3<n>Rationales:  7 ÷1 = <<7 ÷1=7>>7<n>and 1 ÷ 2 = <<1 ÷2=1>>1<n>So 7 ÷ 4 = <<7 ÷4=1>>1<n><n>### Instructon:<n>What will the following methods show for 45 ÷ 6?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Rationales for Method 1:<n>45 ÷1 = <<45 ÷1=45>>45<n>and 6 ÷1= <<6 ÷1 =6>>6<n>So 45 ÷6 = <<45 Div6=7>>7 (Answer to 45 ÷ = 7)<n><n><n>### Instuctions:<n>What methods can you use to solve the following equation?<n><n>### Equation:x^2 + x − 3 = 0<n><n>### Method 1:<n>Method 1:<n><n>Input: x^2 + x − <<x^2+x-3=0>>3 = 0<n>x =  <<Root of x^2 + x−3=0 =−2>−2<n>Rationales for method 1:<n>Input: x = -2<n>x^2 + x -3 = <<x^2+2-3=0>>0<n>Rationales for x^2 + x - x.2 - x +3 = 0<n>( x + 2)^2 = 0.<n>X = (-2 + 2)/2 =  -0<n><n>### Answer Method 1:<n>-0

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a characteristic of thin glass? Who is the fourth person from the end of both rows?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The fourth person from the end is Shirley, since she was the third person from the last person in the row.<n><n>### Explanation<n>Shirley was 10 from the end of either row, and she is fourth from the end so there is one other person between her and the end. She had to be 8 from the last person in each row to be between the 2nd person from the end.<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		<n>The only choices that could prevent them from buying Christmas presents is Lack of money or Happiness. If they do not have money they would not buy presents. Similarly if they were happy, why would they need presents? They would not get relief from stress, they would actually get stress if money was an issue. In this case it is possible to buy presents as long as they are happy and have money.<n><n>### Input<n>- Write a code that creates a list where the sum of each element is 30<n>- The solution should be a list that contains five elements<n>- The empty list [[ ]] is not a solution<n><n>### Response<n>You can create a list that has 5 elements if the sum of each element equals 30. This can be done using the sum function which is predefined in python. For example, a list of 20 + 5 = 25 is a list that satisfies the requirements.<n><n>### Reference<n>https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Python_Programming/Lists

Choices:  A: family room B: tropical forest C: flower garden D: movie theater E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Detailed Solution<n><n>Joe bought a fico. He thought it would look great in what part of his house. Choices A: family room B, tropical forest C: flower, G:  flower E movie theater<n><n>### InputA:What is 689 subtracted by 36?<n>### Response:b<n>### Detailed Sol:653<n>### Input:what is 367-87<n>### Response:d<n>### DetailedSol:280<n>### Input:how many inches in 50 feet<n>### Response:c<n>### DetailedSel:60/8 = 720<n>### Input; what is 54 in feet<n>### Response;;a<n>### Detailed Ssol:<n>### Input:which is bigger 60 inches or 25 cm<n>### Response;60 inches<n>### Detailed:8 inches<n>### Input;what is.087 in feet<n>### Input:Which is 11 x 12<n>### Response;;g<n>### Detailedsol:12.12 <n>### Input10/15/17 10 15 1 12.10<n>### Response;;c<n>### Ds:10 15<n>### Input: 2/8 10 10<n>### Resp:4/8<n>### Ds:( 64)<n>### Input:1/5 divided by 1/8 10<n>##.# Rspc<n>### (.625 <n>### Detailed<n>### Input:5 divided by 2.5<n>##.# Resp<n>### A<n>### Dsp:2.5<n>### Input-4.84 divided by 2.89<n>Answer:0.87<n>### Ds/0.87<n><n>### Input61 divided by 5/8<n>### Response:42<n>### Ds.42<n><n>### Input.38<n>### Resp<n>##.# A<n>### Input<n>###.56 divided by 3/4<n>###.# Resp<n><n>###
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Traveling underwater has many dangers, such as low visibility causing what? Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		A: disorientation<n><n>### Input. A) Fill in the blank. After the test, Kyle left the desk. B) Rationales: The test is the desk and leave is the desk. C) Demonstration: Rationales: Fill in the blank After the test Kyle left <<Fill in the blank "the desk" "then the desk">> then the desk he can not left.<n><n>### Answer: B) left the desk.<n><n>### Input A. A car can go from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 11 seconds, but from 60 to 70 miles per hour in what time? Choice: A B 13 seconds C 17 seconds D 20 seconds E 43 seconds Answer: C 17 seconds<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A: gas stations B C: london<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input : There are four cashiers at a grocery store. 15% of the people in this area live below the poverty line.  How many people in the area are buying food at this store?  (Assume everyone buys groceries at the store equally.) Choices:  A) 9.5 B) 10.5 C) 13.5 D) 15 E) 18<n><n>### Response : Choices : D) 15<n><n>### Answer : A<n><n>### Instructions : Complete the following word problem<n><n>### The cashier was on break.  The new cashier is 17 years old.  In four more years, her total cashier experience will equal 22 years.  The current age of her superviser is 50.  He started working as a cashier at age 18 with 10 years’ experience.  In 17 years’ time, he will total 32 years’ experience as a cashier.<n>In how many years from now will the superviser retire?<n><n>### Instrction Response : Choices :  C) 11 years in the future <n><n>### Answer Choice A)11 Years from Now<n><n>### Insttruction:<n><n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n><n><n>### C<n><n><n><n>## <n>## <n>## A<n>## B<n>## C<n>## <n>## B<n>## E<n>## D<n><n># Question bank for 2021-2022.<n>## N.C. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C (insult)<n><n>### Rationale:Insensitive, perhaps, but, technically: (1) the leavee is not leaving, but rather (2) the leaver is leaving. It is the leaver who will be waving goodbye to the leavee, who is also staying. If a person is actually leaving for good, he should not expect any insults, as that will be an act of unfriendliness.<n>If a person is a leavee (that is, he is staying), it is rude to insult the leaver. Insulting someone who is not leaving does not make any sense, as that person is not leaving. That is, that person remains the same, whatever he does. It also happens to be one of the meanings of "non-moving", a word which means the same as "standing", from a verb which can be translated as "to remain". The person remains the same despite taking any actions, and the actions do not make him into a leavee.<n>More specifically, it is the leaver who is leaving (not the leavee). Therefore, it is an insult toward someone who is leaving, while the leaver remains.<n>We can also see that this is the only answer that does not use either the word "goodbye" or something that means "go away". The leaver is not meant to leave, but this answer does ask that he at least try to leave. It also contains insults, such as "effing dunce" and "f***ing b******", which are common insults.<n>On the other hand, if you are insulting someone whom you do not intend to insult (or rather, whom you are not even expecting to insult, or is not even planning to expect to insult), then this is just insular communication, or "speech about nothing", and is meaningless (because no one really cares about insults directed at people who are not really or actually present) and should be ignored.<n><n>#### 1000<n>Answer: C: attempt suicide<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: The answer is E<n><n>### Rationales: "They will probably all get arrested" is a good reason, but the correct version is also: "They are

Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		None of the above. Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>What I learned from this exercise is that you can find things that are similar by looking at the things that are the same and the things that are different.  In the past, I learned to look for things that I can do to help others but this exercise really helped me understand how a group of people needs to work together to help each other.<n><n>---<n>##### _Codesmith_<n><Link to Code Sandbox Code>https://codesandbox.io/s/stackoverflow-answer-questions-instrc-w70n3</Link>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>A,B,C,E<n><n>### Outcome:<n>The correct answer is A, B, C, E
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:He was in a cabin in the woods, through the window he saw a fox where? Choices:  A: indiana B: england C: outside D: on the wall E: picture<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n>he was in a cabin in woods through the window he saw fox  where?<n><n>Choice E  is the correct answer<n><n>### <n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you play a board game with your family? Choices:  A: toy store B: home C: school D: toy shop E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		The set of choices does not contain a home, therefore choose B or E<n>#### B or E<n>Answer: B or E<n><n>### Input<n>The number of questions on an exam for a class is a multiple of 4 plus 4.  The number of questions can be no less than 14.  After answering the questions, 25% of the class didn’t pass the exam.  What were the pass percentage and number of questions when the pass percentage was 98%?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>- First, find the number of questions.<n>  - From the questions, “After answering the questions, 18% didn’t pass the test”, is saying that there are 25 questions. Since you cannot pass less than 14 questions, these 25 questions are the 14-plus-4-multiple-choosing-to-have-no-fewer-than-14-possible.<n>  - Then, “The number of questions can be at a multiple of 4”, we can say that each set of 4 questions is worth 1/4 of the test.<n>  - Now, each set of 4 contains 25% of that set not passing (since the class failed 25%). So, you must make each set of 4 worth enough that 25% of it passes. “After answering the questions”, 18% of the 25% class failed, which is.18 *.25 = <<.18*(.25)=.0475>>4.75% of the class would fail a set of 4 questions.<n>  - This means that each set of 8 questions must work out to make up for 4 of those 4.75% failing.<n><n>  - “The number of questions is 16+4.16+4=20.”<n>  - 16=4*4.<n><n>  - However, 47.5% would not pass the 4 questions given per set, so 20/4.75 ≈ 4.16. Since you are given that 16+4 is 20, we can set 20=4.16*4 ≈ 4.<n><n>  “The number of questions needed to pass must be at least 14

Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n>__Answer:__  D <n><n>### Demorstion:<n>A) Burning: Burning will not get rid of the reflection.<n><n>B) Polishing: Polishing will not get rid of reflection.<n><n>C) Carving: Carving will not get rid of a reflection.<n><n>D) Composting: The reflection has nothing to do with composting.<n><n>E) Nailing: The nailing of a piece of wood could actually create a reflection, but it requires more than just nailing.<n><n>**D**<n><n>### Answer:<n>__Answer:______(Reflections don't just come from mirrors.)___<n><n>### Instructions:Use numbers and/or words to answer the question.<n><n>## #1<n><n>### Instuction:<n>Annie’s teacher made a tally chart showing the average student score each day. On the first day, there were 11 students and the average score was 83. For the second day, there were 20 students and the average score rose to 84. For the third day, there were 30 students and the average was 85. Finally, Annie’s teacher decided to stop counting the number of students on the fifth day. By this point, the average went down to 84. What is the median score by the time she stopped counting each day?<n><n>### Rationales: <n>Step 1: 11 + 20 + 30 + 35 = 106<br /><n>Step 2: 106/5 = 21.2<br /><n>Step3: 21.2*3 = 63.6<br /><n>#### 63.6<n>Answer: 63.6 <n><n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is microphone boom likely to be used to record an album? Choices:  A: radio station B: recording studio C: concert D: tv studio E: new york<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input : Which state is the headquarters for the national institute on aging located? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. He was not lookign for clean clothes. <n><n>### Input : The man was cleaning the house, what was he looking for? Choices:  a: a girlfriend b: girl c: his ex-girlfriend d: no one e: a wife<n><n>### Response  : The man was looking for  a wife.<n><n>### Explanation:The man was not lookign for any of the choices. But a wife would be someone one should be looking if cleaning the housde.<n><n>### Question: What should be the next letter in this series? d, r, o, __, t<n><n>### Input/Response : d__r__o__o__o__t__<n><n>### Examine: The input gives the letter order, but not the number. The correct solution should have a number so the order is not random. But if the first letter is random, then the tenth letter will also be. There fore we can replace the d with "a" which will form a new series where each number will change.<n><n>### Step 1: d, r, o and t and then A<n><n>### Step2 : Then the series will be dAo, rAo, oAo, which we can replace with dA, rA, oA<n><n><n>### Question 2: There were 2696 bags of flour and sugar in the super market, 2463 bags of sugar were bought by the customers and 2332 bags of flour were sold by the store, how many bags of flour remained in the store?<n>### Input: Total 2696<n>### After selling 2332, there are 2696 - 2332 = <<2696-2332=364>> 364 bags of flour<n><n>### Question : If a man has 20 children, and each girl has a sister, and each boy will have a brother, how many children will the man have in 10 years?<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. How many friends did class 1 have?<n>Rationales : Class 2 sent nothing, it would mean there are at least 500 students - 2 = <<500-2=498>>498 students in class 2<n>Since Class 1 - 2 = <<1-2=0>>0 students send gifts, so class 1 had 500 - 498 = <<500 - 0 - 490 = 10>>10 students, and if Class 2 has 498 students, then Class 1 had 10 more students, i.e., at least 508.<n><n>#### 508<n>Answer: 508<n><n>## Input: Write an expression to replace the highlighted parts in the story.<n><n>### Problem Statement:<n><n>#### Context:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input: The store manager is giving away $50 gift vouchers. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		<n>Because "in town" did not show up as a choice the response would either be E or B, but the correct answer is B, New York City.<n>This allows the least amount of travel for the customer and the most density of people in the area.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:I'm at a restaurant ans want a glass of milk, how do I find out if they serve that? Choices:  A: accompaniment to meal B: waitress C: cafeteria D: home E: menu<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>-The meal served at restaurant.<n>-Waitress to ask if they serve milk.<n>-Cafe if they serve milk to public.<n>-Home if he can purchase at grocery store.<n>-Menu if they serve milk.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: building B: friend's house C: classroom D: window E: front door<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Rationales: The dog ran to the front door and barked, so the answer is <n>[F](A,B,C,D,E): front door<n>#### F<n>Answer: F<n><n>### Input:"I should have listened!" is said by the dog after being mistaken for a bobcat. Choices:  A) The dog B) The bobcat C) The cat-dog D) The dog-bobcat E) The bobcat-dog<n><n>### Response:"I should have listened" is said by the dog. So the answer is D  (The dog-bobcat)<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input"Got you again!" is said by the cat-dog. Choices: <n>A) The dog after being mistaken for the bobcat<n>B) The dog after being scared by the bobcat<n>C) The bobcat after being scared by a cat-dog<n>D) The dog-bark after being mistaken for the cat-dog<n>E) The bobcat<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct answer is (C). As the cat-dog and the bobcat are both scared of one another, it's natural that a sentence as 'The cat-dog got you!' is uttered by the cat-dog to the bobcat. If the cat-dog got you or, the bobcat got you, it's natural to say, got you again as in the previous instances, where the word 'got' implies that the 2nd sentence is continued directly from the previous sentence.<n><n>If the dog got you in the previous sentence, then the next sentence is most likely to be 'The bobcat got me!'.<n><n>The dog after being mistaken for bobcat' is most likely to be uttered in the second scenario when the dog is really scared at the bobcat! <n><n>The dog after been scared by the babcat is the one that is mentioned in the text and this is the one that has been repeated by a lot of readers. It's completely wrong!!<n><n>Had the answer been, got you again in the previous sentence, the word 'again' wouldn't have had been mentioned in the next sentence. Then the cat-dog doesn't know which 2nd sentence is it
