Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:How can an artist commemorate a horse forever. Choices:  A: hoof B: kentucky derby C: race track D: painting E: triple crown<n><n>### Response:		A<n>**Reasoning and Explanation:** KY horse refers to a Kentucky Derby horse, so answer is A: hoof<n><n>### Input2: What does the author of a novel have to do before editing or publishing the book? <n><n>### Response2: Reread<n>*Reasoning and Exploration: You have to read the book to know what needs to be fixed and how to fix it<n><n>### Input3:In what order would the following letters appear in an alphabet? ABC, DEF, GHI, and JKL.<n><n>### Response3: JKL<n><n>### Reasoning : First letter in the alphabet is A, J is next in line to the alphabet than K and last is L<n><n>### Input4: How many apples, which cost $1.50 each, can you buy for $7 when you have $37?<n><n>### Response4: 21<n><n>### Reasioning: $37 / 1.50 = 25 x 25 = 625 apples<n><n>### Input5: How many liters do 6 tablespoons of flour fill?<n><n>### Reponse5: 1<n><n>### Response Reasoning: 1 liter is equal to 4 cups and a cup is equal to 2 tablespoons.<n><n>### Input6: How old were Javi and Jaden when the girls’ basketball team they play on was founded? <n><n>## Reponse6: 1<n><n>Reasoning: Javi is the youngest and Jaden is slightly older than Javi
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n><n>### Response:		Option C<n><n>[Solution](/home/r2solution/homework/coding-4/code-4-solutions/code4_coding_tasks_05.md)<n><n><n><n><n>### Input/Output:<n>### Output:<n>### Input:<n>```python<n># 3<n><n>### 6<n><n>### 2<n><n>### 7<n><n>### 1 & 2<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>Ryan took 90 cookies to the party on Monday and he ate 3. There were 55 left. On Tuesday he took 75 more cookies and he ate 13. There were how many cookies left on Tuesday?<n><n>He had 55+90 for Monday and then took 75+75 for Tuesday.<n>There were 25 for Monday + 75 for Tuesdays = 100 for entire day.<n>100/75 = 26/7ths = 3<n><n>## Solution:<n>```python<n>def main():<n>    with open("file") as infile:<n>       read = infile.read()<n><n>    answers = read.split("\n")<n><n>    for ans in answers:<n>        if ans is not " ":<n>            ans = ans.strip()<n>            answer = int(ans)<n>            print(answer)<n>main()<n>```<n><n>### Problem:<n>```python<n>1. The baker needs to bake cookies for the 1st of the month with 50 cookies. 4.  After the 2nd, he can eat 25 of the remaining cookies. 6. For all other occasions, 50 cookies will be used. What number of days will they last? <n><n>2. The first day of the month, 350, there are enough cookies to give 10 and baker gotta eat 20 himself. If he always takes 2 from the leftovers what day will there be no leftover? And if he always takes 3?<n><n>3. A boy is going to eat a number of fruit jelly, everytime he is going to divide it equally with his mom and dad, in the end he has gotta have more than enough to give to his dog
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The man needed balls of cotton, where should he look? Choices:  A: south B: georgia C: north carolina D: pocket E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		<n>> If he was north carolina, then what was his choice?<n>> It doesn't state where he is searching, I would say D, but it was stated in the direction of the word cotton (south) so that's why I am saying E<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Input B: Georgia, if someone was saying the letter B, they are probably saying the word 'balls'...and if a person was trying to say a word south of them, then most people would think about the south. The south is directly below Georgia, so people are most likely to say'south' when they see the word 'balls'.<n>Input E: Medicine cabinet, it may seem like an odd choice, because you would find cotton balls in the bathroom, the medicine cabinet.<n>I believe A is 'north'. I don't know what you would find south of the south.<n>#### south<n>Answer: south
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do people find bills with bread? Choices:  A: restaurant B: congress C: envelope D: mail box E: cheese store<n><n>### Response:		What is the total cost of a package of 144 cheez-it crackers and 12 cans of coke?<n><n>### Answer: E: 599/399<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instructions:Answer this multiple choice question.<n>Input:  The bakers made $112.95 for each large cake made and $113.00 for each small cake. What is the total cost of 120 small cakes and 120 large cakes?<n>Rationales<n>120 x $113 = <<120*113=13660>>13,660<n>Large cakes = $112.00<n>120 x 113 = 13,66 = 13,120<n>Difference is $400, so that is the total cost<n>## Answer: $13,664<n><n>## Instruments<n><n>### Data<n><n>|Instrument|Number of students|<n>|-|-|<n>|Test 1|15|<n>|Test 2|18|<n>|Test 3|14|<n>|Test 4|14|<n><n>### Data Analysis<n><n>1. Is there a pattern in the data?<n>Test 1: 15 students passed<n>Test 2: 18 students passed<n>Test 3: 14 students passed<n>Test 4: 13 students passed<n>There is a decreasing number of students who passed each test<n><n>2. Are there any unusual patterns in the data?<n><n>It seems like there is an unusual pattern in the number of students who passed. In Test 1, 15 students out of 15 passed. In Test 2, 18 students out of 18 passed.<n><n>3. What is the data?<n>Each test represents the number of students who took it.<n><n>4. What are the 2-5 conclusions you can make based on the presented data?<n>Based on the number of students who have taken each test and based on the number of students of the passed, I would conclude that the number of students who pass will decrease every test.<n><n>5.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>* The refrigerator is on a bridge because there are stairs that are red that lead to the refrigerator/fridge.<n>* The market is on the bridge because the market has red roofs.<n>* San Francisco is not on the bridge. However, since it is on the bridge, it could be considered eating fruit on a red bridge.<n>* The bridge is also a path that goes to engineering school, but it does not specifically indicate eating fruit on that bridge.<n><n>* Engineering school is a place. It might not indicate eating fruit because engineering is typically about math and science.<n><n>* Market has vegetables and fruits. The fruit is the only one that applies to your answer set.<n><n>### Input; There are 40 children in a room. They are evenly split between boys and girls. If the boys share their candy equally and the girls share their candy equally, by how much is the amount of candy each girl has less than the amount of candy that each boy gets?<n><n>### Response <n><n>* 16<n><n>### Rationale:<n>* Both groups of 20 split their candy equally, resulting in an equal amount of candy for each boy and girl.<n><n>* However, the boys are given 50 pieces of candy, while the girls are given 33.<n>* This means that each boy received 50 candy pieces, and each girl received 33 candy pieces.<n><n>* The total is then 16 pieces of candy for each girl, while each boy get 33 candy.<n><n>### Sample Input: One of your best friends just moved away and you're sad about it.  Luckily, your friend is planning a birthday party for a mutual friend.   How many of you are going to the party so that if two people go, you would each have 75% of the fun?<n><n>### Sample Response <n><n>* Let x represent one of the two people who is going to the party<n>* Then 1- x represents the other person going to the party<n><n>* Let x and 1-x represent 2 of the 10 people from your group who will be attending the party.<n>* x < y would mean that x is less than y
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n>> A : The correct answer is letter (b) :  Humor<n><n>    **Because** laughter is contagious. Laughing together, makes us happy. We feel closer to one another.<n><n>### Input : What is your favorite type of food? Choices:  Fresh A: vegetables B: fruit  C: meat D: fish E: spicy <n><n>### Response :<n>> D: Fish<n><n>My preference for fish :<n>- Fish has good nutritional value.<n>- Fish is less bad for the environment than meat.<n>- Fish is good when it is cooked lightly.<n><n>### 输入 : Choose the letters that are closest to the middle of the alphabet : <n><n>### 回复 :<n>> B <n><n>B<n><n>1st letter -> B<n><n>Mid = halfway<n><n>26 letter -> 13<n><n>Mid -> 1st and 14th => B would be the middle<n><n>### 题目 : What’s the difference between the average value of five consecutive whole numbers and the average value of nine consecutive whole numbers?<n><n>### 答案 :<n><n>1. The difference in the middle numbers<n><n>2. 6 <n><n>### Input<n><n>> Choose the number 30 times less than 59.<n><n>> 中间数1：9<n><n>> 中間数2：4<n><n>> 差值： <n><n>> 3<n><n>### 应答 <n><n>输入：中间数差值<n><n>> 3 < <n><n>   3
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The man took 3 hours every morning for grooming, what is the likely result with his job? Choices:  A: tardiness B: looking good C: injury D: vacation E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		Vacation<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1). Grooming takes 3 hours per day, therefore, in a week; it would take seven days of grooming with totaling the hours is 7* 3 = 21 hours grooming a week.<n><n>2). The man takes 3 hours per week for grooming<n><n>3). The man only wants grooming to 2 hours per week, so from what he is getting(weekly vacation), he would need work for only a 2nd hour grooming a week. Therefore, the results of a week from a man's work would be a vacation.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Input: Alice wants to go to 4 museums, each costs $11 per day. If she spends half a day in each museum, how much money will she save?<n>Rationales<n><n>After going to the first 4 museums, it would take Alice 4 days, each day she spends one day = 1 day/4 = 1/4 day and half a day is 1/2 day.<n>Alice spends 1/2 day in Day 1, 1/2 day on Day 2, 1/2 on Day 3, 1/2 Day 4<n><n>She spends 1/4 day for Day 1 and then all 4 days she spends 1/8 day = 1/8, so 1/8 x 4 = 1/8 x $11 = $$11/8=1.4$<n>The total for all days = 4 x $11 = $44<n>Alice saves the difference between the total cost of the four day tour and how much she pays to spend the same day in each place<n>The total cost = 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/8+ 1/8 = $11/8 = 1.4<n>The saved amount = $44 - $11/8= $44- $1.4= $42.6<n>#### 42.6<n>Answer: 42.65<n><n>### Input:(You can go over the quiz)<n><n>#### Input: When can Tom run at sea level?<n>Rationales :<n><n>From the question, we are told that Tom needs twice

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>Rationales:<n>D. Jukebox - Movie Musical.<n><n>The song was bollywood.<n>The dance was the napster.<n>The movie had a record/musical.<n>The movie musical was a record.<n>Answer: E<n>```<n><n>### Input:"A 4.6 liter engine  can make 18.98 horsepower."<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```<n>Answer 16.98 horsepower<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>Output: <n><n>### Instructions:Complete the sentence with an arithmetic expression.<n>Write a response that contains a correctly formed arithmetic expression.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>```<n>The difference in ages between Richard (16,90) and Hurley (14,21) is 20. (Answer: 36 [20]) If Hurley was 14, what are their combined (4,3) ages 4 years (6,8) from now? (Answer: 60 [40]) Forty (2,6) years from now, Hurly will be (11,6) years old and Richard 40 + 34 = <<44>>. (134 [74]) <n>(950 / 500) (3,23445876592) The combined age of 18 yrs 73 (2,83) from now? (133,5) (50 /100) The dog ate (8,7) of that burger. (2,556445873) (102+47)*2= (186)* (120) How many apples (13) = 175 (8,8). (677) How many minutes is 250 (40) minutes? (291) (30,2), (196) (75) <n>(2,2) (192,82) How many students were 40? (250,45) hours of basketball in the rain (19,9) The bicycle was 300 years old (36) (9,4) How much did 2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Provide an explanation on why the given answer is correct.<n><n>### Rationale: Choice answers from the list are always in CAPS.<n>B, D, E, and A answers are related to morality (“Good” vs “Evil”).<n>Therefore, it is wrong to kill or take a life, which means it is pure evil.<n>So the correct choice is A.<n><n><n>### Demoiselle<n><n>### Input 1:Choices:  Choices:<n><n>### Demi-<n><n>### Response 1:A<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Inputs to the questions are either one or two digits number(s), e,g, 120 or 350.<n><n>#### Input 1:<n><n>#### Response 1:<n><n>Answer 1: 120/2 = 60<n>Demoiselle - 350/2 = 175<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Demoiselle is just another word that means girl. "Demi" is half, and "dame" in French means lady. Therefore, "Demoiselle" just means half-girl or half-lady.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>#### Input:A: fraternity house<n><n>#### Response:A. B and D can be eliminated because fraternity houses don’t tend to be for science majors. Therefore A is the only choice that remains.<n><n>### Input : The billionaire donated a lot of money for a new science building A:  fraternity house<n>B:  bank C:  big town D:  big city E: building.<n><n>### Response : D<n><n><n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		C.<n><n>### Justification:<n>Learning Outcome:The learner will be able to explain the use of mathematical terminology to appropriately describe an equation or identity in different contexts.<n><n>### Learning Exercise:<n>In which of these containers would it be likely to find a food lorry?<n><n>### Instructions:Write a letter to answer the question.<n><n>## Notes:

How can this idea help in making the right decision when buying something?<n><n>### Response:"If it is too goof to be right, it is"<n>```py<n>"if you are unsure about something that can lead to a lot of questions you don't know the answer to, then go with your gut feeling by saying no, and if things do come up and if you really want it to be true, the seller can always give you the receipt when he buys it for you but don't let your emotions get in the way"<n>```<n>#### 1<n><n>## Reverse Engineering<n><n>### Input:\`import re\`<n><n>### Instructions:Create a program that asks the user to enter a string. When the program has finished executing the loop, the program should print the number of times the statement `If <string> in <string>:` is executed. What is one thing this program cannot do?<n><n>```py<n>#import re<n>#text = input()<n>#i = 1<n>#while i<=text.count(' '):<n>#  i+=1<n># <n>#matches = re.findall('(<string>.*)(\<string> in (\<string>\))(\s.*)', text)<n>#print(i)<n>```<n><n>#### 1<n>```<n>python reverse_engineering.py<n>```<n><n>### Input\`import sys\`<n>```<n>#i = 0<n>#while True:<n>#  i+=i<n>#  print(i, end='\t')<n>\`import sys <n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    #for i in range(1, 30):<n>    #    print(i, end="\t")<n>    print("")<n>  <n>#### 1<n>python reverse_engineeri.py<n>```<n>### Instrucation:The second-fittest person in a group of five is one who is able to do one of the five things on the list with just 9.5 more minutes of practice than the fittest person on the list. If an event takes one minute to compete

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? If the water level is 72 cups, how many times longer is the drain at the end compared with the start?<n><n>### Rationeles: The drain rate is 4 times the water coming in, so 4/72 = <<4/72=1/18>>1/18 times longer. Divide 1 by 18 and you get 1/18 times 55 = <<1/18*55>>55.<n>#### 55<n>Answer: C<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		There will be bleachers at the movies, the opera, and the lecture hall. There will also be bleachers at a hockey game.<n><n>### Input/Output:Where does the ball move?<n>Answer: The ball moves to the blue circle first then to the red circle then back to the blue circle<n><n># Python code<n><n>### Difficulty: Intermediate<n><n>### Purpose: Code a program that answers a multiple-choice question.<n>### Instructions:Complete the task for Problem 4.1.<n><n>### Solution:Use a while statement to repeat a specific set of instructions. For the question to “Where does the ball move?”, the ball moves from its original circle to that of the target shape. The program needs to loop until the ball’s target circle is found.<n><n>### Implementation:<n>### Part 1 – while loop – where to test the ball?<n><n>```python<n>from math import hypot<n>ball=1<n>while ball>=0:<n>    ball=(ball**2)+(ball**3)<n>    print ball<n>    ball=hypot(ball,ball)<n>```<n><n>### Part 2 – check if ball is the right color<n><n>```python<n>while ball1<85:<n>    ball=(50+sqrt((100-90)+cos(ball)*45))<n>    ball=(abs(25+sin(ball)))<n>    ball=(ball+5)<n>```<n><n>The solution runs on [Colab](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1vZGbx1JD4lY0QCW0i42L5RVw127yI1E)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		Because there’s a market, and the market doesn’t mean vegetables, it can only mean the market.<n><n>### Input :What kind of people can be in the market? Choices: A: vegetables B : people with money C: people with no money D: people with dogs E: old people<n><n>### Rationales :Market is something you would pay for, so if the people with money and the people with no money are in the market.<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n><n>##### Rationales :  Because both options A,C have money people which means both options are for A.<n><n>#### D<n><n>##### Rations: Dogs are animals so the only option left for the animals in the market is B.<n><n>##### Ratios: No people or dogs are in the E because there are only people in the E.<n><n>##### E<n><n>##### Ration: The market isn’t old people.<n><n>##### Answer: A<n><n>Output: The chef is making a cake. He puts 5 eggs in a large bowl with 5.5 cups of sugar, 1 cup of oil, and vanilla extract. He puts the mixture in 6 small baking dishes. He puts two strawberries on each dish. How many berries did he use?<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>##### Answer : 12<n><n>### Instructions:You will find an image below and answer the following questions. For clarity and easy reference, please write your answers directly beneath each question.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If an actor is said to be on the “silver screen" where would you see them perform? Choices:  A: play B: movies C: theater D: screen E: television<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice: **E**; Television<n><n>### Input2:Sonali is 50% faster than her brother. Last year she finished her homework 6 days prior to when her brother finished his assignment. How many days sooner than usual did Sonali finish her homework last school year?<n><n>### Response<n>Choice:**B**; 4; Sonali took 6 days and 50%. So she takes.025 x 4 = <<.025*4=1>>1 day less everyday than her brother.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Demand:Ryan is 50% slower than his cousin who works on the assembly line. The assembly line moves at a constant speed of 120 cars per hour. Ryan makes 80 cars in 8 hours. How long will it take his cousin to make 80 cars?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Choice: **C**; 10; So his cousin needs to use.025 x.120 = <<.02*12*.12=0.30">>30 of the cars per hour that the production line made.<n><n>#### 0.3<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input3:Maria works on the assembly line with his cousin. She is twice as fast as Maria. Last year, the assembly line made 120 cars in ten hours. How far behind his cousin will Maria be?<n><n>### DemoRtional<n>Choice: **D**; 480 Cars;So Maria's cousin made 120 x 10 = 1200Cars.<n>Maria's cousin should be 1/2(1200)=<<1/2*(1200)=600>>600 cars ahead of Maria since she is twice as fast.<n>Since Marias's speed is only 1/2 of his cousin's,<n>that means it takes her.5 / (1/2) = <<.5/1/2=2>>2 times his cousin to catch up, which is 2/1 = <<2/1=2>>2 x 600 = <<2*600=12>>1,200.<n><n>#### ���

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What's the nickname of the monster the beauty loved? Choices:  A: beast B: ugly C: ugliness D: satellite E: top of mountain<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Output: A: beast<n><n>### Input<n>Input: What time does school start? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a telephone booth likely to be red? Choices:  A: airport B: gotham city C: london D: city E: gas stations<n><n>### Response:		I agree with C<n><n>### Question:Why do you think so?<n><n>### Answer: All telephone booths are red because of Batman.<n><n>### Input<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Input：It takes the train 1 hour between each stop.  If he makes 5 stops, how much longer in total will the train travel compared to the previous question?<n>In total, the train's journey takes 1 * ( 5 + 1 ) = <<1*(5+1)=5>>5 hours.<n><n>**Input:** The train makes 1 stop every hour, and takes 1 hour between each one. How long does the train travel from one stop to the next?<n><n>**Input：** The train needs one hour between each stop. The train takes 1 hour from one city to the next. There are 2 cities away from each other. How long will the train take at each stop?<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is someone unintentionally hurting someone else but unable to stop likely to feel? Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationale: If the person was able to stop what they were doing, then it's not unintentional, so I would have to disagree with the question.<n>However, if the person was unable to stop, then the person would feel empowered because they were making the best of a bad situation, and even if that situation was hurting someone else, it doesn't necessarily mean they were evil or bad people.<n><n>### Input:[How to make a smoothie? Which of the following ingredients would be most important to add first? Choices:  Milk Banana Sweeteners Berries Oil]<n><n>### Response:[Oil]<n><n>## Rationale: The main ingredient you want to add first is the one that will have the thinnest consistency after everything else has been added. Oil, on the other hand, has the consistency of water, so it is the ingredient you would add first. If you were to add oil, then add berries, then the consistency of the smoothie would change. If you were to first add berries, then add oil, then you would also change the consistency of the drink. Milk has the consistency of cream and is pretty thick, and wouldn't change the consistency as much, even after you added sugar.<n>### Input: If you were to give a speech to a group, which of the following would you want to avoid? Choices:  Too many pauses Too much talking Too fast Too loud Talking too long<n><n>## Rationale:[Too much talking]<n>### Input: A box of toys contains six red toys, three yellow toys, and eight green toys. Twelve red toys, six yellow toys, and three green toys are placed in other boxes to keep each box from getting too heavy. If one of the boxes contains each toy type, how many of each toy type would be in that box? Choices:  Three of each red, yellow, and green toy Two of each red, yellow and green toy Two yellow toys and one green toy Two red toys and two green toys Seven of each red, yellow, and green toy<n>### Response: 2 of each red, yellow & green<n><n>### Rational: You say that if one

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this case she should be a member of A, assisted living facility. The other choices are unrelated.<n><n>### Input:"The sky is blue" is a correct statement. Choice A: This is NOT correct information. Choice B: This is VERY correct information. Choice C: This is NOT very correct information. Choice D: This is completely unrelated.<n><n>A) Since the sky IS blue then statement A would be correct, the statement is true, hence the information is correct.<n><n>B) In order to say this is very correct information, then the information would have to be mostly correct. For example: "Most of the time when it rains, the sky is blue."<n><n>C) This is NOT very correct is a factual statement. The information that the sky is blue, is completely correct in every circumstance.<n><n>D) This is completely unrelated should be left blank. This is a very basic and correct statement about the sky being blue, it is true, unrelated is just a frivolous answer.<n><n>### Incorrect choice:In which situation is the answer the number of zeros in the second digit? Choices: 1. the second digit if it were a fraction or decimal, 2.the first digit of the number, 3. the difference between the first digit and the second digit, 4. the number of places you start to count when subtracting the first digit from the second digit, 5. the second digit if negative and a fraction or decimal, and no choice 6. neither 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5<n><n>### Choice 6:Neither a,b,c,d, or e<n><n>### Difficulty level:Difficult<n><n>Input:In which situation is 371 a rational number? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>John lives in Texas. The north star or Polaris is located approximately 60 degree latitude above the earth's north pole. We will start our journey at Texas location at 30 degree latitude. If you were to walk due North and don't stop, would you end up in North Carolina?<n>Rationales:-if he was to walk due North and didn't stop, he would end up where? We have to remember that he is living at a south latitude because he lives in Texas. That means he is south of true North. So, If he travels due north and doesn't stop he would end up in Meica which is north of true north.<n><n>John lives at 30 degrees latitude and travels in a due north. By rule number 1, we are looking for his location to be north of 30 degree latitude which is Mexico. Therefore, the correct answer is E is Mexico.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: Mexico<n><n>### Input<n>How many apples were there in a 7 pound bag?<n>### Answer<n>14<n><n>#### Why?:<n>If you have a bag that is about 7 pounds, you can find out how many apples were in it by dividing the 7 by the 2.7 and multiplying the result by the 2.8. 7 divided by 2.7 equals 2.58. Then multiply 2.58 times 2.8. Finally, the result is 7.384. 2.58 + 2.8 equals 5.38. Adding 7.386 and getting 12.476<n><n>#### 2
