If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What happens when you take a shower after going for a run? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Discussion:<n><n>#### 1. RTF is a great resource for students to improve their computational thinking and programming skills. We created RTF as an online resource in order to reach a global audience. We were motivated to design a tool to make programming accessible for everyone no matter their educational or social backgrounds. While we do not believe every student should learn programming, we do believe that students should learn _mathematical thinking. RTF is a fantastic tool for improving students’ mathematical thinking skills, especially computational thinking skills which are crucial skills for computer science students.<n><n>#### 2. RTF is a learning tool that is designed to make programming accessible for all students. Since RTF is an open-source tool, we have made it easier for anyone to customize the code to fit their specific needs and/or goals. We have a library of lessons that teachers may use to help introduce students to the basics of programming. In addition to the lessons, we have 2 modes: the first mode is a free mode where students play a match against the computer and the second mode is a paid mode which allows students to learn from the coding exercises. The paid mode is currently in beta, and after beta testing it will be available for purchase.<n><n>### Input 2:How many more of the first number is 10 more than the second? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		<n>Where do you typically find a ______________ trash can?<n>#### Trash can<n>Answer: Trash can<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Follow these instruction and write a response which completes the assignment in the correct way.<n><n>### Input :<n>The difference in ages between Richard Hurley is 2 years. If Hurley 17 years old How old is Richard?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The difference in ages of 2 years Hurley is 17 years old. There fore Richard is 2 + 17 ==<48+2+24=27 >> 27 years years + 2 years old ==<39+2=41 >> 41 years old.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Richard is 41 years =<27+41=78>> of years old.<n><n>#### 78<n><n>### Input<n><n>The chef has 60 80 eggs. he puts 10 eggs into the fridge and the uses rest to make cakes. if he uses5 eggs to make one 70 cakes, how many cakes did chef .<n><n>### Demos<n>After putting 10 eggs into ine fridge, the he has 7=<60-80=10>>50 eggs for make eggs. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### B: parking lot<n>#### D: north america<n>#### E: park<n>#### Answer: B&D<n>#### Rationale: John would like to avoid:<n>B: pet store<n>because people sometimes treat their pets in cruel ways<n>so we need to avoid the parking lot because of the danger of people abusing pets.<n>D: north america<n>because the wildlife needs to be protected from those who mistreat animals.<n>E: park<n>because pets have been abandoned in parks and the park workers need to protect them from abuse, as well as the natural ecosystem<n><n>### Input-Output:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### 1. What is the next number in the sequence? 5, 16, 20, 30, ….<n><n>#### A: 45<n><n>#### B: 64<n><n>#### C: 94<n><n>#### D: 6<n><n>#### E: 32<n><n>#### F: 57<n><n>#### Rationale: Because 20 is the 7th number, the next number is the 7th + 1, which is 57<n><n>### Instructor's Rationale<n><n>#### 2. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would you tell ali to do if he bumps into you when you are walking? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? Choices:  A: read B: passenger C: land plane D: fly the plane E: buy tickets<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A: <<A=Read>>Read<n><n>Choice B: <<B=Passenger>>Passenger<n><n>Choice C: <<C=Land plane>>land plane<n><n>Choice D: <<D=Fly the plane>>The plane will not fly itself<n><n>Choice E: <<E=Buy tickets>>All passengers need to buy tickets<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input : The number x is a multiple of 2.  The number u is 6 more than x.  The number u does not need two ones in order to write it in order to express it in words (i.e. u could use the number 3 instead). Find the value of x.<n><n>### Response : Choices: <<u=6>>6 because u is a multiple of 6<n><n>choices: <<x  + 6 = 6>>x<n><n>Choices: <<u=2>>2 because u is a multiple<n><n>Choices: Choose neither <<2 u >>2u or <<u>>u<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Solution:<n>The book is $30 so to get the discount you need to subtract $14 which is $$30-14$$. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A, because it includes driving and getting tired.<n><n>### Input : In which of these two operations is each number increased by 4? Choices: A: A x D B: A x C C: A x D or C D: B x C<n><n>### Response : <n>A, C or B x C <n><n>### Input Choices: A car rental company rents two cars to a customer who pays an additional $40 for the cars. If the car rental company makes $90 per car, how much did the customer pay?<n>#### Choice 1 :  $230<n><n>### Response Choice 1 <n><n>###  Input :<n><n>Three students have to pay for a field trip. The toy costs $80 and each friend is going to pay $16 each.<n><n>### Choic 1: The number of friends remaining is: A: 1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 4 <n><n>### Response 1 <n><n>The final number is 4.<n><n>### Solution:<n>The sum of the remaining cess is $(5 ×5)+(5 ×5)+5 = 80 + 80 + 5 = 165 $<n>The total number of friends = 5<n>Each friend’s remaining cess = 165/5<n><n>The toy has 46 % more rubber than chocolate<n><n><n>### Choose from one of these options:<n><n>A : B <n><n>### Explanation :<n>The chocolate percentage is $100/33. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a binder containing homework assignments? Choices:  A: backpack B: bookcase C: office supply store D: office E: class room<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:  The question asks where a binder contains homework assignments.  We could find it in a backpack, but backpacks typically contain items that we wear while in class or outside.  The items found in bookshelves are not typically homework assignments or materials used for school assignments or projects.  Therefore, the binder would not be found in a bookshelf.  Similarly, neither an office supply store or a classroom would contain assignments that are completed in class.  The items sold in office supply stores and items that are completed in the classroom are not school assignments and would not typically be put inside a binder.  Therefore, neither an office supply stores nor a classroom would be the location to find a binder containing school assignments.<n><n>### Input 2: The cost of dinner for 10 people is $240. After  the bill is paid and a tip is added, each person pays $20. How much did the tip cost?<n><n>### Rationales:  After all of the people were billed for dinner, the amount was paid for along with a tip of $20.  Therefore, $240 + $20 = <<240+20=260>>260 was paid for the meal (eaten by 10 people).  Because the meal was $260 and the bill was already paid by the amount shown, the tip added to the bill made up the $260.<n><n>### Question 3:<n><n>### Question: How many bags of chips does Brianna need to buy for her 16-person party if she spends $25 on each?<n><n>### Answer: 14<n><n>### Rationel:  Brianna has to consider 8 bags for 8 guests, 2 bags for 3 guests, and 4 bags for 5 guests.  Therefore, she needs 12 + 4 + 2 = <<12+4+2=18>>16 bags to accommodate all of the guests at a combined total of 16 guests and their bags.  Therefore, with 8 bags left over, 16-8 = <<16-8=8>>8 bags, which is an

That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		E: daytime<n>### Instruction<n>Use the above response<n><n>### Rationale:Asking the time and asking what time it is are similar because they both allow someone to find an answer, however, asking the time refers to just the hour, while asking what time it is asks about both the hour and the day of the week. If the difference between the two concepts is too difficult, you can say ask about one item a time. (e.g., "What time do you want to leave?", "When do you want to leave?" )<n><n>### D: afternoon<n>

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone. Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>A: bookstore - If the bookstore, then some students will have to wait.<n><n>B: building - If the building, then the student will have to wait until the building is built<n><n>C: meeting - If the meeting, then the student will be unable to take the meeting until the time.<n><n>D: office - If the office, then the student will need to visit the office and that will cause a delay during his/her work.<n><n>E: coffeehouse - If the coffeehouse, the student will have to take a break for coffee and delay the class.<n>#### 1<n>Answer:C<n><n>## Tasks<n>1.  The task consists of one question and multiple answer choices.  The response should include all aspects of the question.<n><n>#### Input:The manager found a discrepancy on the time sheets.  She called all the employees in for a meeting and told them: I’ll be at 11:30 a.m. on Monday. If you were one of those who forgot to clock out, please come to my office then.  Which statement accurately explains how the manager feels right now? Choices:  a: disappointed b: confident c: proud d: worried e:  upset<n><n>#### Answer: A<n><n>#### Input: A teacher forgot to add 6 students to the attendance list. The students were in class.  What should the teacher do?  Choices: a: Remind the students to keep a close watch to make sure they are actually present? b: Mark the class absent and then check to make sure the other students showed up? c: Admit their mistake, apologize to the students, put down their names for present and correct the attendance list? d: Do nothing and just forget about it because they were in class?<n><n>#### Answer: B<n><n>#### Input: There weren’t enough chairs for everybody.  What might have been delayed?  Choices:  a,b,c, d, e<n><n>#### Answer: E<n><n>#### Input: The kitchen is having a meeting next Monday at 8 a.m.  The chef asked all the kitchen employees to attend the meeting by 8:20  so she can start her meeting on time.  If a kitchen worker is unable or decides not to arrive at the meeting until 8
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		<n>You would combine them by using the word "and" or "or."<n><n>input:<n>C:<n><n>D:<n><n>E:<n><n>#### Answer Choice C<n><n>#### Answer Choices B & D<n><n>### Input<n><n>```python<n>Input:<n>-5x1 + 4x2 + 3x3 + 2x4 + x5<n><n>Output:<n>37x1 + 38x2 + 39x3+ 40x4 + x5;<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>```python<n>37x 1 + 38×2 + 39×3 + 40×4 + x5;  <n><n>answer:<n>```<n>### Input:<n>Choose the option with a similar prefix to complete this sentence.<n><n>The word "unhappy" is formed by combining  _____ and "(y)".<n><n>### Response - Answer Choice:H-<n>The word "unfortunate" is formed by combining "un" (Latin adverb: "not") and "fortunate" ("a fortunate person" (the adjective form of "fortunate" = lucky, fortunate). "Un" means "not"; fortunate means a fortunate person. The prefix "un-" of the word "unhappy," which means "not cheerful." A prefix describes adjectives and adverbs.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>The word "hero" is formed by combining the word "hero" with the word "(i)".<n><n>## Instruction:Write the word with the word "hero."<n><n>### Response :<n>Answer Choice C -<n><n>### Input <n><n>```<n>input:  the book is very interesting<n>answer: interesting.very<n><n><n>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2723426/what-is-the-best-way-to-get-python-to-output-the-text-in-a-string-in-the-given#2723431<n>def replace_with_first_letter(val): " This is for your reference<n>    val = str(your input string)<n>    print(val)<n>    return val<n>print("Hello World!", replace_with_first(" Hello

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. Write a program that will print the value that is calculated as follows: if the sum is more than one then print the sum subtract one from the sum if the sum is equal or less than one then the program will exit<n>Your program must be exactly 50 lines of code.<n><n>#### 0 ≤ n ≤ 15<n><n>####  The value 1 is not used<n><n>#### 0 < n < 11<n><n>####  At least one 1 is printed.<n><n>####  n = 0<n><n>####  n is more than one so the sum = 1.<n><n>####  The sum is more than 1.<n><n>### Example<n><n>Input: 1,2<n><n>Output: 3<n><n>### Explain<n><n>After 2, you can only subtract it from 1 to get 0.  So you should subtract it from 3 to get 0.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>This is what you need to do:<n><n>1. read input(it doesn't matter what it is)<n>2. create a variable that stores the first input number<n>3. create a variable that store the second input number<n>4. if the both numbers are

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where should you find a school in? If $70+x=6y, what must be the value of x in terms of y?<n>Rationales:$186 = x²$186=x²<n>$256 = y²$256=y²<n><n>x^2 ⋅  6y $186 ⋅  70 = $256<n><n>$256$256 =   $y^2$y²;<n><n>Hence, x can be defined as:<n><n>$x = y ⋅  5$x=y⋅5<n><n># 4th block<n>***<n>Input :How much milk is in 3 gallons? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? Choices:  A: bookstore B: backpack C: abraham lincoln's grave D: desktop E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is  bookstore<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You are on Jeopardy! and there are $200 of the next clue! In your head, shout out the correct answer as you go to the restroom.<n><n>### Output: In your head, shout the correct answer out<n><n>### Rationale:<n>You do not know the category, but you can read a word and get in your head what the correct answer is. In this problem there are two possible answers, bookstore and classroom. The bookstore is located inside a "store" of some kind. The last answer that you gave was "bookstore", which was true.<n><n>### Input<n>Where is a notebook purchased most often? Choices:<n>A: Bookstore B: Backpack C: Abraham Lincoln's Grave D: Desktop E: Classroom<n><n>### Output<n>In your head, shout the category and the correct answer.<n><n>### Rationales<n>In your head shout bookstore and classroom and you will receive 200 points<n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>Input:<n>What are the words found in the dictionary?<n>Options: A: words B: definition<n><n>Output: <n>In your mind, shout out the option that contains a word<n><n>#### Word: Word<n><n>#### Option: B: Definition<n><n>#### Correct Answer:<n>Option A: Words (CORRECT)<n>#### Rationales<n>Your brain gets stuck on the option A, which does not include a word.<n>Instruction: Shout out the answer when you are using the urinal.<n>Answers:<n>Option 1:<n>Would the urinal hold its own weight?<n>A: Yes<n>Option 2:<n>Hmm, I'm not sure what this item does.<n>A: Does not fit in the restrooms<n>#### Rationales:<n>The answer is option A, "yes"<n><n>```<n>A:<n>Yes<n>```<n><n>```<n>B:<n>Does not fit in the restroom<n>```<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What has happened to a person's money after he or she has used the last of it? Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales for D is correct.<n>Dissipate means to disperse or scatter.<n>Flown means to go by flight.<n>Disintegrate means to gradually fall or break apart.<n>Fall apart means to separate and become individual parts.<n>Penultimate means the only one before the last.<n>https://www.lexico.com/definition/dissipate (dissipate: to disperse or cause to disperse or break up)<n>https://www.dictionary.com/browse/dissipate?s=t (dissipate : transitive verb: The act of disperse or spreading of something)<n>https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/flown (flown : traveling by air)<n>https://www:dictionary.cambrdige.org/dictionary/englisch/disintegrate (disintegrate : the act of breaking up into several pieces)<n>https://www::edictionary.cambridge.com/dictionary/english /fall-apart: (transitive verb : the act of falling apart)<n>https://dictionary :lexico.com/browse /penultimate (penultimate: the next to the last)<n>#### D (dissipate, flown, disintegrate, fall apart, penultimate)<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:"There is a little red bar right at the edge of the screen."<n><n>### Response:"What is little red bar right at edge of screen?"<n><n>### Instructions:Read and write a response that accurately paraphrases the words in italics. Follow the structure for writing a paraphrase.<n><n>Answer: The image in a rectangle shape in a small size which is close to the screen boundary.<n><n>https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/us/definition/english/paraphrase#:~:text=to%20transmit%20a%20sentence%20or,but%20which%20is%20written%20differently.<n><n>#### E (to write a response that accurly paraphrases the sentences)<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input"I told her that you were at home."<n><n>### Instructer:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Place to buy items<n>* B. Downtown.<n><n>#### Place to eat<n>* Any A. City.<n>* Any B. Downtown<n><n>#### A and B.<n>* A or B.<n><n>### Input:"What is it?" "It is _______."<n><n>### Answer:"What is it?"<n>* It is a _______.<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>* An object is _______.<n><n>#### A. a subject<n>* An object is that which you see when you look through the _______.<n><n>| *B. a verb |<n>* An object is something used when _______ is done.<n><n>#### C. a preposition |<n>* It is _______ of the _______.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		<n>I will read the letter from my friend overseas to get news. <n>Because after my friend wrote the letter and sent it to me, I need to know what he is doing now..<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:<n>The answer is 72.<n>I have some blocks, and I take away 3 blocks, and I add 6 blocks, what do I have?<n><n>### Response<n><n>When I took away 3 blocks, now I have 72 - 3 blocks = 72 - 22 = <<72-22=50>>5 blocks, then I have 72 blocks - 3 blocks + 5 blocks = 72 blocks – 6 blocks + 5 blocks I have 6 blocks.<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>### Input<n><n><n>### Answer:<n>1×2=2<n><n>### Instructon:<n><n>### Instruption:<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Answer<n><n><n>## Instruccion:<n><n><n>## Instructor:<n><p><n><n>## Input: I have a 16 pound sack of potatoes. <br/> How many pounds do I have left, if I take away 5 pounds?<br/> <br/> <br/> How many pound<n>s do I have left, after if I add 2 pounds?<br/><n><n>### Insturction:<n>Write a response that appropriately completions the request.<n><n><p><n>## Response:<n>I have a 16 pounds sack of potatoes<br/> How many pounds? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: cinema B: opera C: party D: stage E: dance<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationales: At a gathering of my friends, I would definitely see them at a dance.<n><n>### Answer: D (dance)<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input A: Write a response that appropriates completes the request.  Choose an appropriate response choice.<n><n>### Rationale: I would definitely join them<n><n>### Input B: Write a response that gives 5 to 10 sentences.  Choose an alternative response that gives 5 sentences to 10 sentences on this topic.<n><n>### What would my character be doing on the day you described?<n><n>### Renee is on the day of the fair. <n>It is a warm day and the fair is packed with people enjoying all the various attractions on offer.<n>The fairground is open for an additional hour after the scheduled fair-closing time to encourage people to stay on for the evening extravaganza (this is known as the 11th hour). <n><n>### What will Renee and her friend do at the fair<n><n>### Rules to follow: <n>* Be in the third person<n>* Speak in a formal manner, so you would have a more adult audience.<n>* Be in the order of the events (not in the order you wish something happened).<n><n>### Ratios: <n>* At least 5 sentences in which you describe an event that has happened in the past.<n>* At least 10 sentences in which you describe what Renee might be thinking and how she feels about what has happened.<n>* In your writing, use a combination of the verbs tell, think, wonder, suppose, conclude, assume and suggest.  Do not use words like know, see, feel.  That will distort the meaning of the sentences you are describing.  Use simple words or phrases whenever possible.<n>* Use a combination of the following grammar rules: apostrophes (quotations, possessives and contractions), commas, quotation marks, semi-colons, colons, question marks, dialogue, and parentheses.<n><n>### Response B:<n>Renee and her friend will head down to the fun fair together. She will take a walk with her friend around the market stalls first, admiring the beautiful things

The second choice is ‘may’. ‘Will’ is the correct word.<n>#### 7<n>Answer: will<n><n>You ______________(will/might) enjoy the movie.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: will<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Some stores trick women to buy products, the sales make it seem like if you buy more you what? Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does god want people to do for money? Choices:  A: houses B: bedroom C: istanbul D: open tress E: gym<n><n>### Response:		He didn't like getting of bed and stepping onto cold tile, so, he made the gym have carpets as floorings.<n><n>### Notes<n><n>The gym is an indoor sport stadium. It doesn't have a tile floor. <n>The question is ambiguous because one house can have carpets installed in its floorings and can fit within the wording<n>The question is ambiguos because all the buildings listed as options only have concrete floors<n><n>### Input : The man's grandmom has 3 grandsons who always eat at her house. She buys pizza for them each time because she doesn't like to fuss with cooking. Last week she served 2 pizzas and next week she is going to bring 2 extra pizza. By the end of 5 months, how many pizzas will be eaten? <n><n>### Response : The grandma needs to serve 2 pizzas with the next months and the pizzas eaten in one go. Therefore, the grandma needs to serve for 5 more months.<n><n>### Addition:<n>For every next month the grandma buys an extra pizza to feed the grandson each time.<n><n>### Remark:<n>The next month implies the current month. <n><n>### Input (The second part):<n>The girl's grandpa always wears a blue tie to go eat at her grandma's house. For special occasions, he wears a blue scarf to match the blue tie. So many months later, when his birthday comes around, his grandma and cousin both decided to wear a red dress to go eat at her house. How do they match the red dress to her grandfather's outfit?<n><n><n>### Response (The second part): Her grandpa always wears tie and scarf to eat at her grandma house, So, it's logical that he wears same tie and scarf. To match the red tie and scarf he wears her grandma and cousin both wear red dress.<n><n>### Note:<n>The word special occasion is ambiguous and can mean either birthday, graduation or anniversary.<n>The grandpa always wears same tie and scard to match to the red tie. Her grandma can be her mom or her sister.<n><n>### Input1: The

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  I: indiana II: illinois <n><n>### Response:'II'<n>Answer: II<n><n>### Instructions: <n>1.  Choose the correct answer. <n>    -  If the given number is divisible by 100: <n>    -  The remaining digits form the tens digit.<n>    -  The ones digit is the digit in the tens place times ten.<n>2.  Example:<n>    | Numeric                  | Divisible by 10           | Answer                              |<n>    | ------------------------- | ------------------------ | --------------------------------- |<n>    | 1000                      | Yes                       | 100                                 |<n>    | 2000                      |\[No\]                    | 20                                  |<n>    | 3000                      [\[Yes\]                   | 300                                  | <n><n>## Input:<n>* 756<n><n>##  Instruction:<n>Find the remainder when 756 is divided by 100.<n><n>## Rationales:<n>756 mod (100) = 70<n><n>##  Answer: <n><n>## Input:'How many ones are there in 162? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation: <n>The term, that you are looking for is, the ASTRONOMICAL. It refers to costly.<n><n>### Your Turn: <n>In your own turn after carefully reading the question, complete it and post your response that includes a rationale of your answer. Also, you should refer to what were given so that it will help you to understand if you are correct.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? Choices:  A: scars B: being born C: sorrow D: misery E: kill yourself<n><n>### Response:		D: Misery<n><n>### Demonsition:<n><n><n>### HOW?<n>

If the cashier rounded the price up when it was £3.91, and down when it was £3, why did the overall cost of 10 books not change if, on average, a book is £3.025?<n><n>Rationales:The cashier rounded up, so it was £3.89, so he rounded it up to £3.91 to add in an extra 0.025 more<n>So the answer is £3.91 x 10 = <<3.91*10=39.1>>39.1 The cashier did the same for the next book, £3.875 x 9 = <<3.875*9= 35.125>>35.12<n>So each book cost £3.02 for the cashier to start at £3, then went up to £3.89<n>This cost on average was £3.925 - £3.02 = <<3.925-3.02=0.90>>0.90<n>The overall cost did not change, because the cost of the book is £3.92, so the cacher had to pay 0.90<n><n>#### 3.92<n>Answer: 3.92 (10 books)<n><n>### Input<n>A store is selling 10 tshirts, some have prices of 31, some have 32 and some are 6, what is the cheapest item?<n>Rationales<n>Cheapest price is 31, so that is the cheapest item<n>#### 31<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input multiple choices:<n>Harmon uses £2532 to buy 600 pairs of trainers. He is charged £5.15 for his first 4 trainers then £6.60 for each pair. If he uses the same technique as always, how much does he spend as a total?<n><n>Rationalies<n>14 pairs was £4.93 each<n>He will spend £4.93 x 4 = 19.62 for the first 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Food must be freeze dried before it is taken on what vehicle? Choices:  A: fairgrounds B: friend's house C: space shuttle D: oven E: microwave<n><n>### Response:		Incorrect. You are using an indirect method that is equivalent to counting.<n><n>### Rationales:A freeze drier would work well because it's an airtight container.<n><n>#### Freeze Drier<n><n>### Correct:Freeze Drier<n><n># Challenge Task<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple answer question.<n><n>## Challenge Task<n><n>## Task 1: How to tell the time.<n><n>### Challenge Task 8: The time is displayed as 2:20.<n><n>### Task: 1.Write an expression for what time 1:22:45 is.<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n>#### Instruction:<n><n>## Challenge Task  12.6 : Inventory in the Supermarket.<n><n>###  What time is displayed as 1:22?<n><n>###  You are working in a supermarket. You've just realized they are running low on toilet paper so  you go to the storage room to restock the inventory. There are 40 rolls of toilet paper in your hand from the storage room. There are 581 packages of candy bars in the storage room. If you have a total of $$13_{77}$$ dollars and $.78_{78}$ cents then what kind of candy bars have the most?<n><n>### Instructoin:Write a statement to print out what kind of candy bar has the most based on your inputs.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Let x represent toilet paper and y represent candy bar.<n><n>### $80=\frac{581}{7 }$<n><n>### $78=\frac{40}{7 }$<n>Let x represent toilet par.<n><n>### $$ 6 = x $$<n><n>### $y=125$<n>## Solution:<n><n>## Solution: You are restocking 40 rolls x $80 = {t=7}\$ = $56\$  and $.78_{88}$ cents, $6\times 581 = 3443$

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What  might john order at an indian resturant on top of the space needle?
