He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Their strings are 2 meters long, 3 meters long, and 3.6 meters long.  If they measure side by side in a straight line, how long is the total string they share in meters? Choices A: 6.6 meters B: 9.6 meters C: 12.6 meters D: 15.6 meters E: 18.6 meters<n><n>### Response<n><n>B<n><n>Input: The table shows the number of minutes, hours, and dollars that an individual has earned. Find the total number of hours and dollars for the three individuals.<n><n>### Response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do you get for not moving your car during the required time? Choices:  A: towed B: accidents C: driving D: getting tired E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		Choose letter-based on answer options<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input::Which one is bigger? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		Choice D: way to much<n><n>### Input and Rationale: How much did it cost? Choices: 1)32 dollars 2)42 dollars 3)75 dollars 4)180 dollars 5)5 dollars 6)300 dollars<n><n>### Response and Rationale:  The question is "How much did it cost?" However, the choices include both a cost and a price. We must choose the cost.<n><n>### Input (no mathematical response required): 3 + 6 + 2 = ___ What do the __ show? Choices: A: minus 5 B: add up 23 C: add four times D: add two times E: subtraction F: multiply<n><n>### Response (no mathematical response required) and Rationale:  First we must read the question. It says, "add up 23." We must interpret it as "how can I add 3, 6, and 2 to get 23?" If you were to perform the operation, you would do 3+6+2. You would arrive at the result by adding one number, three, to two other numbers, six and two. The result you get is 23.<n><n># -<n><n>### Insta:<n>Input: It has often rained in August. A recent storm left 4 inches.<n>Rationales: There are 4 inches of rain that have fallen since "recent."<n>The first line says "It has often rained in Aug."<n>The answer is "recent" because we must interpret "it has often rained in august."<n>What time the rain falls is a "recent storm."<n>We conclude that 4 inches of rain have fallen this month so far.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instant:<n>Input: It must be a large house. Choices:  A: cars B: city street C: street corner D: fork in road E: at a red light<n><n>### Response:		The person will likely stand at a red light, because it is more obvious to stop at a red light, since the car is waiting for it to become green to be turned on. People will not stop at a fork in the road because the car is not on a street, but on a main road. As well as that, in an intersection, the car is trying to choose which way to go. They will go in the opposite direction on a corner, a street, a street corner, and at a fork in the way.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Your response:<n><n>### Additional Feedback:<n><n>

He was a bit upset that he had to do it, but he needed the job.  Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		The question asks what John preferred (in this case, he wanted to stay close to his family). In order to answer the question, we need to know what John could be closer by and which option has John leaving his family away. If John is to be closer by, then he wants to be further away. We know he wants to be further because he said that he would have preferred it that the job was the closest, rather than the farthest. The closest was what he was closest to, and the farthest was what he was farthest from.<n>Thus, we can say he is upset by having to go away from his family.<n>```<n># Answer<n># A<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:After his mother saw his report card he knew he was going to be doing housework, what could have prevented this? The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: names B: words C: naval D: bladders E: feelings<n><n>### Response:		C<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input :Renee is a 5'2 tall person. At 2 am, she has to stop and have a conversation with her 2 friends that are 5'10" and 6'0" tall. She wants to cover her blush with a 6" long make-up brush and her hair with a 4" long mascara. She has a 3" long red lipstick and her friends have 5" long blue mascaras. How many 3-inch blue mascaras can the friends share to cover their faces?<n><n>Rationales: Renee is 5'2.<n>She wants to cover her friend's hair with a 4-inch makeup brush and her friends have a 6-inch makeup bristle each.<n>Renee's friends have a red mascara of 3-inches long and Renee has a red mascara long 3-inches, which would be red. They have enough to use the remaining 3-inches that each of them has left.<n>Therefore the number of 3 inch blue mascaras that the friends can share to cover their faces will be  \<n>$$\frac{2}{3}$$\left(5 \frac{10}{12} \frac{5}{12}+\frac{5}{15} \frac{5 \cdot \left(3 \text{ "blue mascara"} \text{ \times 3 inch "blue mascara"}\right)}{17}\right)=0.45$$<n>So then 0.45 x 0.45 = 0.21, then 0.21 x (1-1/3) = 0.07, and then 7 goes to an integer in 2, therefore 2 is the number of 3-inch blue make-up brushes that the three friends can cover their faces. <n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Your Task:<n><n>### Demos:<n>### Your Task<n>#### Input: <n>Rationales:

Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Emotional distress is a common result of telling someone about a humiliating or embarrassing situation.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>The answer is C or E, because notoriety sounds like being famous for doing something good and bad dreams refers to nightmares.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Notoriety, C: The answer is C because notoriety is an awareness about a person or a specific issue that is widely known.<n><n>Emotional distream is B: Emotional distress is an unstable mental condition emotionally as a result of a recent incident.<n><n>Annoyance is A: Annoyance is a state whereby you are so upset because of something someone has done, or you have to listen to what someone is saying.<n><n>Riots is D: Riots D: Riots are a civil uprising against authority or a public disturbance that is usually connected with demonstrations or rioting.<n><n>### Input : One day, an elephant in the jungle became thirsty. She went to the pond and drank some water. Later, when she came back to the jungle, she said to her friends : “I’m thirsty again, and I’m going to drink the water in the pond.” <n>What was strange about her friends’ response?<n><n>### Response : <n>Answer by : A<n><n>### Ration 1: <n>There was no other choice. It is because the question is a riddle, and it’s asking us to compare the elephant’s response to ours. <n>There are 2 choices 1) I’m thirsty, and I’m gonna drink some water. 2) I’m thisty again, and I'm gonna drink the water in the pool.<n><n>### Answer : <n>The correct answer is A<n><n>### Input 2: The elephant told her friends that she was thirsty, and that she wanted some more. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James needed a garage because he spent a lot of money on what? Choices:  A: bike B: downtown C: building D: tool storage E: car<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: <n><n>### Input<n>>James needed a garage for his car. He had just saved $500 from cutting grass. He decided to spend $250 on a car and take a trip to Florida with the other $250. If it takes $200 to fly one-way and $175 a night to stay at the hotel, how much will he have left after he leaves?    Rationales: <n>> James spent $500 on buying a car, $250 on the trip, and kept $250.<n>>So 500-250-250 = 200 = <<$500-200-25=250>>250 is what he kept<n>> 250-200 = <<250-2=30>>30 left over<n>#### 30<n>Answer: <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you sit in a chair to watch four-legged animals complete? Choices:  A: bookstore B: house C: race track D: friend's house E: building<n><n>### Response:		I’ll sit in the bookstore because it fits four legs.<n><n>### Input : A group of teachers wants to use a large chalkboard to help teach class. A: If they use a marker, how many lines do they have if they need to make a 5 foot long line, use black ink, and it’s only a marker width? B: If they use a yellow highlighter, how many lines do use if they need to make the 5 foot long line and there are 1,780 lines to fit 3 feet of a line between the ends?<n><n>### Choices: (1. 1152 lines 2. 1165 lines)<n><n>### Question: How many yards is it to cover the 120 yards from the edge of the field to the goal post? <n><n>### Choice: (1. 327 yards 2. 328 yards)<n><n>### Answer: It would be an answer of a 328 yards because if there are 328 yards on a football field it would cover the 123 yards from the edge of a football field to a goal post.

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If the injury causes infections, it would be E<n>5. The outcome of the injury is death<n>6. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The person was looking up airline and hotel prices, what was he looking to do? Choices:  A: control computer B: separate things C: go on vacation D: cross street E: go out<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales: A) Control computer is not a correct option :  If he/she would like to control computer, they should be typing it in computer.  C) Go on vacation is also not an option :  This is because airline and hotel is only related to travel, so you cannot use it for going on vacation because the vacation place could be anywhere (you don't need to know it on the way or on the plane). <n><n>### Demostration: Choose A<n><n>### Input :  Which of the 4 shapes to the left is a rhombus? Choices :  A : square B : trapezoid C : rectangle D : rhombus<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>### Demos :  The answer C because rhombus is a type of rectangle, so is rectangle, thus all four shapes are rectangle. <n><n>## 4-Digit + A Number <n><n>* Each of the following problems use a 4 digits number, you can add a new digit to the number, and try adding different digits. Then count how many times the number is more than 7000.<n><n>* [ ] You can start with an example if you wish to<n><n>* [x] Try counting how many times 3456 + 7 = more than 70<n>* [ ] Counting the first few examples on your own if you wish to<n>* [ ] Try counting a range of examples<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>* Number : 6072<n>* Add : 7<n>* Number plus the digital : 6079<n><n>* Result : <7001><n>* So the answer is [A]<n><n>### Example:2<n><n>* Number: 2014<n>* Add: 8<n>* Number plus the digits : 2022<n><n>* Result = <7001>.<n>* The Answer is [A]<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n>The woman picked from an Apple tree which is in Indiana<n>

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to get a ball? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What appliance uses water and soap? Choices:  A: washing machine B: space shuttle C: blender D: disneyland E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>#### 180<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n>- 38 / 1/3 + 36<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>```java<n>38 / 15 = 2.5 => -1 and 3.5 => 4<n>38 x 0.5 = 19<n>```<n>#### 32<n>Answer: 32<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question asked.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: After running the 5K, the final scores were 240, 232, and 214. Aimee ran a new personal record, and Jack couldn’t even walk after. What is Aimee’s final score?<n>Rationales:# Aimee’s score after she ran the 5K is 240.<n># Jack has a time of <<232>>232 minutes.<n># The time is what's subtracted from 240. Subtracting Jack's score gives us 270 - <<232>>= <<58>>58<n># The difference is 58 minutes.<n># Now add in the score for their previous race.<n><n>#### 58<n>Answer: 58<n><n>### Insttructions:Answer the question.<n><n>## Demonstration:In the past week, the number of calls has been on a week-by-week trend of decreasing by the same amount every week. This week the call center has answered <<1,500>> calls, 700 of which were for insurance customers (which have the longest average wait time). How much longer does a non-insurance customer have to wait on average if they do not pick up? 520 milliseconds?<n><n># How is the above an example of a function?<n>A. A function is something that changes the state (for example: a state where the car is parked is different to where the car is driving)<n>B. A function is a set of rules to take and give things from place to place (for example: an air conditioner has rules about how the air in the room can be given to a place outside the room and how the temperature of the air outside can be given to the room).<n>C. A function is an
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The whole family was playing cards, they were full of joy and what? Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If they are angry, they are losing money.<n><n>I have no idea about the other answers.<n><n>### Input Choices:  A, B, C, D, E<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Because they are losing money. How many people were playing? Six. Since this question asks you to choose only one answer, so if the answer was A, B, C AND D, they would have been losing money, because A (all) means to include everyone, so they would be loosing all their money and all their money is money, and if you include everyone, then you have 7 answers, because every ones money means everyone.<n><n>###Answer:None<n><n>###Input :<n><n>What do two of the following five shapes have in common?<n><n>Chosen Options : <n><n> - A<n> - B<n> - C<n> - D<n> - E<n> - Others<n><n>###Answer :<n><n>The two shapes that are in common is A and B.<n><n>Other shapes are missing a point. Those are C, E, F.<n><n>###Input:<n><n>How do you find the area of a square when its length is 6 units and length is 9 units?<n><n>###Answer<n><n>S=Sq.unit=((6)(9)=6(9)=56<n><n>And it can be also said as<n>100=6(unit) =6(square)<n><n>###Input<n><n>Which of the following is the same as the following sum?<n><n>Sum:<n><n>-4<n><n>3<n><n>-6<n><n>-2<n><n>-8<n><n>###Answer <n><n>Choice E is the same as the sum. We can easily find it out by subtracting (-4) from each other to get (-3, -2, -1,0) to -4. <n><n>Answer:<n><n>E. <n><n>###Input <n><n>Choose the correct substitution for the equation<n><n>5*x=15<n><n>###Answer(E):<n><n>Choice D is the correct substitution of the equation. In this case (*) would mean times or multiplies, so the substitution is x=3.5.<n><n>###Additional Information:<n><n>This question asks for the correct substitution.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The king was to meet an ambassador, where would the meet? Choices:  A: court B: dinning room C: throne room D: monarchy E: castle<n><n>### Response:		A was correct<n><n>### Instructed response instructions:<n><n>### Input<n><n>The king was to meet with an ambassador. Where would the meet?<n><n>**A:** Court<n>**B:** Dining room<n>**C:** Throne room<n>**D:** Monarchy<n>**E:** Castle<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>**A: **The court is where the king would be meeting the ambassador.<n><n>---<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where does a person need to get when they have more kids? Choices:  A: compliments B: understand themselves C: life partner D: second chances E: larger house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>answers = ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E"]<n><n>### Demostration:<n>if answers[1] == E:<n>  return Answer_E(answers)```<n><n>***<n>### Demontration:<n>if answers [2] === A:<n>  return Answer A(answers)```			<n><n>### Demotstration:<n>if answers. [3] == A:<n>  return Anwer A<n>```<n><n>### Demosration:<n>if Answer. [4] == B: <n>	answers <n>	return Answer B<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Riding bike through rough terrain can be dangerous, one could find themselves what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Riding bike through the rough terrain can be dangerous.<n><n>Choices:<n>- pleasure: The ride through the rough terrain will be enjoyed.<n>- accident: There could be an accident during the ride.<n>- get somewhere: Riding through the rough terrain will get the rider to their destination.<n>- hurt: The rider will feel pain while riding through the rough terrain.<n>- falling down: The rider could fall over while riding through the terrain.<n><n>### Response<n>A<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the two questions below.<n>### Instruction<n>The total number of students in the class is a multiple of 3.<n>If the total number of female students is 4 times the total number of male students, how many male students are in the class?<n>The next year, there were 1 more males than females in the class. The class ended up with 9 more males than females. How many more males than females are in class now?<n><n>### Solution: Question 1<n>You know the total number of students in a class is a multiple of three.<n>16 x 3 = <<16*3=48>>48<n>16 is the number of males and 32 is the number of females.<n>32 - 8 = <<32-8=24>>24<n>24 is the number of male students from year to year.<n>24 + 1 = <<24+1=25>>25<n>25 is the number of students in the current class.<n>9 is the number of more males than females currently in a class.<n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Total number of students = <<48>>48 and the total number of female are <<24>>24.<n>Female: (24/48) = <<24/48=1/3>>1/3 and males is (48 / 24) = <<48/24=2>>2 times females and you know the total number of males and also the total number of females.<n>The females and males combined is (48 * 1/3) = <<1/3*48= 14>>14 and so males is (48 * (1/3 *

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where does a spoon go on one side of a plate? How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a virus primarily do to a person? Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		Input: The chef has 48 bananas. He peels off 3 bananas, and eats two bananas. How many bananas does he have remaining?<n>Rationales:/u/mynameisnopants /<n>#### 36<n>Answer: 36
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a place that might not always have a queen? Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		The correct Answer is: <n>A king is the ruler or leader of a country, but bees and honey are not countries.  A deck of cards does not have a queen.<n>The queen is the highest ranking female member of the royalty of each country, but chess has no kings nor queens.<n><n>If a castle is the ruler or the chief of an area, it is not a place that does not have a queen, but just like with a bee hive, it is not a queen who is in charge.<n><n>If England had a queen, it would not be a place where a queen does not always reside.<n><n>So, the only correct answer choice is A: bee hives<n><n>### Input<n>> The  sum of four consecutive even numbers is 90. How many<n> even numbers are between 39 and 67?<n><n>### Response<n>To be an even number, a number must end in 0,2,4,6,8. So, any<n>    number that ends with 2 or 0 must be even.  Then, any number <n>    divisible by 2 must also be even.<n><n>Starting with 72, the following numbers are also even:<n>   74, 76, 78, 80, 82, 84, 86, 88, 90<n><n>There must be two even numbers that are between 39 (ends with<n>2) and 67 (ends with 7). The first is 40, then the next is 42.<n>Therefore, the set of even numbers between 39 and<n> 67 are: 40,42,44,46,48,50,52,54,56,58,60,62,64,66,68,70,72,74,76,78,80,82,and 84.<n><n>So, there are a total of 17 even numbers between 36 and 68<n><n>### Input | Description<n>> What is 100 when you add 10 and then 100 again?<n><n>### Initial Response | Explanation<n>> Starting with 110
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What place is not interesting to children? Choices:  A: classroom B: toy store C: school D: soccer game E: dinner<n><n>### Response:		The place that is not interesting to children is: D -> Soccer game<n>Because,<n><n>if it is a soccer game, children will be able to see the soccer game more clearly with their friends.<n><n>

If hurricane is 12 years old what are their combined ages for 33 years form now?<n><n>### Explination:<n><n>The difference in ages between Hurley and Richard = 24.<n><n>Hurley = 12<n><n>Richard = 36<n><n>Ans. 48<n><n>### Input `A girl has 25 chocolate chip cookies and wants to give 4 cookies to each of her 9 best friends. How many does each best friend get?`<n><n>### Exlplanation:<n><n>The girl has 25 cookie. She gives it to her 4 friends each.<n>So each best friend will get 4 cookie each.<n><n>### Solution 1:<n><n>The girl gives a cookie to the first friend => Number of cookies = 4 because the number of friends was 4<n><n>The girl gives 1 cookie to the second friend => Total cookies = 5.<n><n>The girl gives the girl to the 3rd friend <n><n>The girl gives to the girl to the 4th friend therefore the total cookie 7.<n><n>The girl give the girl to the girl to the girl.<n><n>=> Total = 8<n><n>The girl gives her 9th friend only 1 cookie<n><n>Hence the total number cookies for each of her 9 friends will be 4+1+1+1+7+7+1+8+1=.<n><n>\<n><n>### Solution2:<n><n>Let x be the  number of cookies each friend gets.<n><n>The girl's number of friends= 9<n><n>In the first round she gives 4 cookies to each friend.<n><n>Therefore let  x= 4 and  y = 9.<n><n>In the

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does someone want when having fun with their friends and trying to fit in? Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n><n>### Response:		What does someone want whe having fun with their friends<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: What does someone want when having friends and trying to fit?<n>Rationales; To fit = do to be with their friends.<n>```<n>if being understood<n>Being understood is when it is the first time trying<n>Beer is not the right answer because beer is alcohol, but you can still get into parties even if you underage<n>hug is wrong because that is a sign of love, not fun<n>so play is the right one because when are hanging with our friends we usually do something fun (driving, swimming)<n>```<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The little girl was raised selfish, she didn't even care when she was doing what? Choices:  A: crack B: antipathy C: being mean D: disinterest E: unfeeling<n><n>### Response:		Answer:B<n><n>### Deminstration:If it didn't care, it would not do what it was doing, or in other words, the little girl was raised self(or anti-social).<n><n>### Input Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Demo Input:<n>```<n>A: 13 is 2 more or 3 fewer than 11.<n>B: 13 is less than 11<n>C: 13 is more than 11<n>D: 13 is neither more or less than 11.  <n>E: 13 is the same as 11<n><n><n><n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```<n>Answer: A<n>```<n><n>## Expected Output:<n>```<n>A<n>```<n>![image is here](img.jpg)<n><n>## Input A and B:<n>```<n>A = Input of Instruction A<n>B = Input of Demo Input<n>```<n>![image of A and B](img.jpg)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can happen to you when eating hamburger from someone that you do not know that does not happen when you usually eat a hamburger? Choices:  A: allergic reaction B: gain weight C: have fun D: heartburn E: food poisoning<n><n>### Response:		 A and B<n>Input: The total cost of shipping 15 packages is $30. The cost to ship an individual package is $25 plus 25% for a total of $30. What is the total number of packages shipped?<n>Rationales for Answer A:  Start out by subtracting the total cost when shipping one package from the cost when shipping 15 at a time. So $30 - $100 = <<30-100=70>>70 packages shipped<n><n>Rationales for answer B:  The cost to ship one package is also $30. In other words $25, plus a 25% surcharge. So the cost to ship 15 at a tine is $25 * 15 = <<25*15=375>>375<n>#### 375<n>Answer: 375<n><n>### Demostration Input:A restaurant wants to give free food to a certain client. However, if they give him the value of the food, the client will be given so much value that they could earn $3000 more than he can spend. They want to give free food which is roughly equivalent to his monthly purchases for a few months, but not so much that they can easily make so much more revenue.  How much money should they give if they want to keep this deal?<n>Rationales Answer:  The restaurant should give enough free food in a given month to make him feel happy, but not so much as to make him unable to spend it in a month. In other words, the restaurant will give him enough food so that 1 + $1500 * (1 -.5) = <<1+1500*(.5)=2500>>2500 is more than the $2000. Remember, we are looking for a number that makes it so they can make $3000.<n>$3000 - $2500 = <<3,000-2,500=500>>500 dollars profit.<n>#### 500<n>Answer: 500
