He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Having your marijuana in bags help keep it what? Choices:  A: entertainment B: neat C: happy D: intoxicating E: illegal<n><n>### Response:		The marijuana will not be in bags. It will be in containers. Therefore, the correct answer is `E`<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why would a company be going public? Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Input : A business is projected to get 300 customers in a year. How much do they make? <n><n>### Rationales:<n>They would make 300 in a year because that is how many they think there will be.<n>#### 300<n><n>### Answer: 300<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What eastern state is home to a mountain? Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		<n>Switzerland has the Alps Mountains.  It's located in Europe, not in the Eastern United States.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the sum of 6 and 4?<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is 10.<n><n>### Example: What is the sum of 5 and 1?<n><n>### Example solution<n>1 + 5 = 6.<n><n>### Note: This example will return the correct answer "6". For those who are unfamiliar with the concept of a summation of all possible number combinations using the concept of _base numbers:_<n><n>1 + 1 = _a base number_<n><n>1 + _a base number_ = _another base number_<n><n>_another base number_ + 1 = _another base number_.<n><n>#### Example:<n><n>1 + 5<n>1 + 5 + 1<n>6<n><n>#### This example could also start from 5 + 1, which could look like this:<n><n>5 + 1 = _first base number_<n><n>5 + _first base number_ = _second base number_<n><n>6 = _another base number_, _third base number_, or _last base number_ (pick whichever is easiest for you to remember.)<n><n>#### Example: Same Example, Without The Base Numbers...<n><n>1 + 2<n>1 + 2 + 1<n><n>### Note About This:<n>This exercise was developed to get you started on practicing what you already know about _base numbers_ to help yourself with this programming skill.<n><n><n>### Practice Questions<n>What's a base number?<n><n>Answer options:<n><n>1) zero<n><n>2) any number<n><n>3) one<n><n>4) none of the above<n><n>### Solution:<n>In Programming, the number that you add to an integer to get a number that is a different type (a lower) of number is called a base number. So, in the integer 15, 2 will be the base number used.<n><n>### What's 5 + 2?<n><n>### Solution 1:<n><n>5 +2<n><n>### Solution2:<n><n>_a base number_ + _a base number _<n><n>### Solution3:<n>_first base number_<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input If I need a ladder for my window cleaning, how would I find one without breaking my ankle? Choices:  A: restorand B: wedding party C: church basement D: corridor E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A group wants to decorate a locker room with 4-foot tall tiles. If one full tile equals 4 linear feet, how many tiles will the group need if they plan to create a 7-square tiled locker room?<n>Rationales:: The group wants 4 ft x 7 = <<4x7=28>>28 tiles<n>They need 28 full tiles to get 7-square room<n>#### 28<n>Answer:28<n><n>Input:(3x5^4)-4x5=96 - (-4)x5<n>3(5^4)-105=96-93=3+29=31<n><n>### Input Choices A: The value of every integer is <n><n>1) 0<n><n>2) -1 +1 -1 +1 -<n><n>3) 0 +-1 +-<n>4) 0 +-<n><n>### Instrucions:<n><n>### Demosstration:<n><n>### Instuctions<n>The group decided on tiles. Each tile costs $8. If it costs $62 to purchase each person’s locker, how many people will<n>share the locker room?<n><n>### Demosterions:<n><n><n><n>$4(104) + 62 = 62 - 162 = 140<n><n>Therefore 140 people can share the locker room.<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>The group decided on locker room tiles. Each tile has 104 sides. If each tile costs $8, how much does it cost for each person’s loocker? <n>####<n>answer:<n>$8 x 104<n>

She doesn’t have enough money for four main courses. Each entree is $16.5 and all of them eat the same entree, but the main course must cost less than $100. What kind of dinner can they have?<n><n>### Response/Output: They can have Shrimp Scampi.<n><n>#### Rationale: Beverly is going to have the same entree as her brother, mother, and sister. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John spent too much money buying products for his swollen testicles.  He did so because he was feeling what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: delight C: bankruptcy D: agony E: owning<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: John spent too much money buyer products for his swolens testicles.<n>He did so because he was feel what?<n>answer: C: Bankrupcy<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do people look for when competing against someone? Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales: <n><n>- [x] A: edge: The word edge here doesn't mean 'the edge of a picture frame' or 'the edge of the bed' that it means 'an advantage'. So C is out as it isn't about having an edge.<n>- [x] The question is asking us what people look for when competiting. So we look for this word in the question. I then looked to make sure we were looking in the right place. C is about friends.<n>- [x-2] B: desire to win: A desire to win is similar to rivalry. The question talks a lot about people competing.<n>- [x/-4] The other options A-E make the question seem like competition can be fun, especially if you know your friend is competing with you. However, as we know from this year, competitors don't do this because they don't want you to be the best. If they like you, they would just want that you would compete on a level playing-field. This is why C is out.<n>- [/-4] B: desire to: We want to be careful with this answer. If you aren't carefull, you could get this answer, but then lose and say that you had a desire to win for that answer.<n>We saw this in the first set of questions with Hurley. There, Richard wanted to be able to talk to Hurley when he was older and Hurley wanted to be able to share the information with Pablo when he asked. They both had rivalries.<n>- [/-5] B: friendship: When going into things, if it doesn't directly mention it or use language that makes us want to think about it then it has to be removed. I thought it was worth thinking about, but you always have to be careful. Remember: "When in doubt, cut it out!"<n>- [x/-6] B: desire to compete: "Desire to compete" is a phrase that includes desire to win but also desire to lose, or be the competitors of the other players. This wasn't the question so E is out.<n>- [-6] B: friends: Again, this doesn't say friend or anything about friendship or anything relating to people competing against eachother.<n>- [-6+1] B: friends: This is the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n><n>### Response:		Answers:<n>#### A: waterfalls<n>#### B: underwater<n>#### C: beach<n>#### D: surface of earth<n>#### E: river<n><n># Solution<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When people want to watch a new move, the often go see it at the? Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n><n>### Response:		B<n>#### 70<n>Answer:B<n><n>### Input : Choices:  A 50 degrees fahrenheit B 50 degrees celsius C. 170.46 milliliters D. 92.076 degrees celsius E. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do you need to run after ball? If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy treats for kids over a counter? Choices:  A: candy store B: butcher shop C: kitchen D: auto repair shop E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>Where do you buy treas for kids over a coun??<n><n>#### Choices:<n><n>A: Candy store<n><n>B: Butcher shop<n><n>C: Kitchen<n><n>D: Auto repair shop<n><n>E: Post office<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>Candy store<n><n>#### Instruction:<n>Find where the letter is hidden.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### #<n>#### #<n>#### $<n>####!<n>#### #<n><n>#### Instruction<n>Add up each of the clues to find the missing number.<n><n>#### Instruction 2<n>Find the number you added and its square<n><n>#### Instruction : Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n><n>### Instructions 3<n>Find the total of each letter.<n><n><n>### Demostrations<n><n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n><n>### Response:		<n>Correct Answer: E<n><n>Input: Which of the following is a multiple of seven?  Choices:  A : All are multiples of 7 B: Only 4 and 7 C: 3, 5, and 7 D: 2, 4, 6, and 7<n><n>### Response<n>Correct Answer: D<n><n>Input: Which number is 4 less than 12?  Choices: A: 9 B: 8 C: 11 D: 10<n>Response<n>Correct Answer: A<n><n>Input: Which choice is the odd number?  Choices: All are odd<n>Rationales:<n><n>### Detailed instructions:<n>The task is shown below. Select the correct response based on the prompt.<n><n># Instruction: Find the odd number<n>#### C<n>100<n>105<n>110<n>120<n>Odd numbers: 110 <n># 120 -> is even<n># 110 -> is odd<n># 100 -> is even<n>#### B<n>94<n>96<n>97<n>100<n>Even numbers: 100 (even) <n># 94 -> is even<n>#96 ->96 = 194 (even number), 194 is even<n># 97 -> is even (197 even)<n># 102 -> is odd<n>Odd numbers:  102 <n># 104 -> 102 + 2 is even<n># 89 -> 89 + 10 = even <n># 13 ->  13 +10 = odd<n># 11 ->  11+10 = even<n><n>### Instructions: Find the one that does not match.<n>#### 1<n>10<n>10+5<n>5<n>\<n>\<n><n>#### 1<n>96<n>72<n>96+ 9 = 105<n>105<n># 10 is not the number that does not match<n>### 2<n>#### 1<n>30<n>20<n>30+20 = 50<n>50<n># 30 is higher.<n>### 2  <n>#### 1<n>540

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices: 1: Jill invited ten friends. 2: There was a movie and refreshments.3: Jill invited her sister. 4: The party lasted two hours. 5: Jill's favorite color is yellow.<n><n>### Response:-1: Jill invited twenty friends because 10+10 = <<10+10=20>>20<n>-2: There were movies at a theater which has 10 screens. Jill wanted to see each of the movies available, so she needed to see each for 2 hours.<n>Movies x Number of screens = 10 x 2 = <<10*2=20>>2. She then needed to add 2 more to get to 20, so 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4<n>-3: Jill invited 20 guests, each worth double the value of a single guest. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a judge do when someone is convicted of a crime? Choices:  A: conduct trial B: arrest C: bring in verdict D: pass sentence E: serve justice<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>>Answer (Letter): D<n>>Source:https://wallethub.com/edu/common-responses-dream-jobs-8315838522/22<n><n><n>### Question:If a store offers a discount price on an item, is it marked down or on sale?<n><n>### Response:(Sentence): It is marked down.<n><n>>Answer (Sentence): It Is Marked Down<n>>Source:https :www.yourdictionary.com/question/what-should-be-the-correct-response-to-if-this-is-a-question-and-it-is-a-yes-no-question.html<n><n>### Question : How to say “Hey, what is up?"<n><n>### Response : What is up.<n><n>### Question  : What are two ways to greet a person?<n><n>###Response: Hello, Good Morning<n><n>### Question :- What do you use to greet?<n><n>###  Response: Greetings, <n><n>### Input :  The number of years that Mr. Green spent in college is 7. If the sum of the years and Mr. Green's age is 50, what is Mr. Green's current age in years?<n><n>### Answer : 30<n><n>###  Question : What do you do if you have 66 apples and you want to share them equally among 4 children.?<n><n>###   Response:  Divide 66 apples by 4<n><n>### Question:- how do you greet a person? <n><n>###Response:-   Hi <n><n>### Example :- <n><n>###Answer :- <n><n>## Input: How many dollars will you get if you buy something for $45.25 plus 10% sales tax?<n><n>##  Rationale :  <n><n>### A: $45.2<n><n>### B: $410<n><n>##  Answer: E) $502<n><n>## Input: What is the value of 15 plus 3 less 6?<n><n>## Rationale:<n><n>### A) 1 <n><n>### B) 6<n><n>### C) 4<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would humans do when their legs are tired? Choices:  A: sit down B: make mistakes C: have sex D: reproduce E: excrete<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Input<n>A soccer player runs 3 laps around a 3,000 yard track. If the first lap is 3.45 miles how many miles is each lap? Round to the nearest tenth.<n><n>### Response<n>The first lap is 3 miles + 0.45 miles. The first lap is 3 + 0.4 = 3.4 miles.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>### Input <n>You have $270 in your bank account and want to earn at least a 6% return on the money in the bank. If you invest $228 in CDs paying 4% per year and invest the remainder of the money in an account that pays an annual rate of return of 6%, how much money will you have after 4 years?<n><n>### Response <n>Since the 4% returns each year, your $228 investment is worth $234.24 at the end of year 4. Your uninvested $45.76 plus your 6% return of $45.75 = $91.52 after the return. <n><n>### Rationales <n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. A healthcare unit, such as a hospital should be a ghost town during the time of the pandemic.<n>#### Solution: E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction Demonstration<n>Input: How did the farmer grow the corn? Choices: A: using fertilizer B: using pesticides C: by planting only corn seeds D: using biodegradable products E: without using any pesticides.<n><n>Instruction Rationale and Demonstration -<n><n>* A: The farmer used fertilizer that would have killed the corn. This meant it would not be able to grow.<n><n>* B: The farmer used pesticides, which did harm the corn and caused it to not grow.<n><n>* C: The farmer grew corn seeds that would have killed the seed in the water and it would not be able grow.<n><n>* D: The farmer grew non-perishable products that weren’t able to grow because the weather was not warm enough.<n><n>* E: The farmer planted without using any pesticide. The pesticide would have killed the seeds and the plants, which would have caused it not to be able to grow anymore.<n><n>#### Solutions: A, E<n><n>### Demands<n><n>What do you want from an algorithm? Write three demands an algorithm should follow.<n><n>#### Demand #1:<n>* An algorithm should be able to be implemented correctly as a program, where any coding errors do not hinder the program from running smoothly.<n><n>#### Demands #5:<n>* Implement your algorithm to show how you implemented it.<n><n><n>#### Demand 8:<n>* If it does not work, add explanations with code annotations to show where exactly an error was made.

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n><n>### Response:		The Snake lives in [wyoming] because [wyoming] matches the pattern of [d]<n><n>### Demorstration<n>Input:Where is a snaik likely to reside?<n>Rationales:[A] is not a snake.<n>[B] matches the pattern of ['d'](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_D), because [nightmare](https://en.wordpress.com/tag/the-nightmare/) can also be 'the-d'.<n>[C] is not a snaik.<n>[D] matches the pattern of 'd'.<n>[E] is a feild (sic).<n>#### Snake<n>Answer: wyoming<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is a sentence from a letter (with some parts missing) written to a business. Rewrite the sentence to best match what should be there.<n><n>The first answer is wrong.<n>```<n>Dear (name of business),<n>I read that you will accept (name of product). It would be worthwhile to have you consider (describe how the product could be useful).<n>Thanks for your understanding.<n>```<n>### Demonstartion:<n>You may use a (word processor) (note taking program) (spreadsheet). Note: Do not submit handwritten documents.<n><n>Input: Dear (name of business): I read that you will accept [name of product] (product). It would be worth your while to have you consider(the product could be useful). Thanks for your understanding.<n>Rationales: The first answer is incorrect. It should be:<n>Dear [name of business], I read that you will accpet [name of product]. It would be worth your your to consider how the product could be helpful. Thanks for your understanding.

Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Symphony = a large orchestra.<n><n>Band = small orchestra.<n><n>Create music = play music for small gatherings etc.<n><n>### Input:"Jessica is one year younger than Mary and three years older than Ariel. If the sum of their ages is 74, how old is Ariel?"<n><n>### Response:"30"<n><n>### Explation:<n>Let's use a table to figure this out.<n><n>Mary: 1+3+1 = 5<n><n>Ariel: (1+3)+2 = 6<n><n>Jessica:  4+(1+3) = 8<n><n>Given: M(5)+A(6)+J(8) = 74<n><n>Answer: A = 6<n><n>Answer Explanation:<n>A + M + J = 74<n>A = 6<n><n>Mary age: 1<n><n>Jessica age: 8<n><n>Answer: Jessica age: 7<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: soccer game B: fairgrounds C: movie theatre D: countryside E: state park<n><n>### Response:		A:soccer game<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Input:When a student reads a fiction book, she’ll read the book 83 percent of the time. When she reads a non-fiction book, she’ll only read the book 74 percent of the time. Which books does the student most likely to read?  Choices:  A. None B. Fiction C. Non-fiction D. Both fiction and non-fiction E. Not enough information<n><n>## Response:D. Both fiction and nonfiction<n><n>## Rationales:If a student reads 83% of the time fictions and 74% of the time nonfiction, they will read fiction 83% of 100% = <<83%*100%=83>>83% of the year and nonfiction 74% of 10% = <<74%*10%=74>>74% of the year.  That means the student will read fiction 8.3 days / year and nonfiction for.74 days / year.  So her total time reading is 8.3+.74 = <<8.3+.64=14.94>>14.94 days / year<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input In war, you often run into your enemy, but it is important to remember not to do what? Choice: A: fear for your life B: fear for your life C: never run away D: never surrender E: fight for your country<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input How does battle strength affect the number of soldiers you lose in one battle? Choices: A: More is better B: More is worse C: Less is better D: Less is worse E: More deaths, more glory<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input If your soldiers are wounded, how well do you tend to your wounded soldiers? Choides: A: Poorly B: Very carefully C: Carelessy D: Not well enough E: Very Good<n><n>### Raisons:<n>#### A<n>Answeer A<n><n>### Instructions What skill does the soldier want to improve? Choices A: Fighting in large groups B: Leading a squadron C: Learning tactics D: Firing from the hip E: Weaponry<n><n>### Rationals:<n>#### B<n>Answeer B<n><n>### Instucions: What does the soldier do if the enemy attacks him from behind? Choices: A) Turns around and fires B) Stays put and waits for the reinforcements C) Scores a kill D) Fires at the reinforcements E) Fires at other enemies and the reinforcements<n><n>### Rations:<n>#### C<n>Answeer C<n><n>### Instuctions: What tactical ability does the soldier value the most? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? Choices:  A: diary B: city C: bible D: graffiti E: labyrinth<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationale:Labyrinths are used to pass from one point to another point, by people using their feet, not their hands<n><n>### Input :Fill in the blank. It takes 30 minutes for a train to travel from Denver to Salt Lake City. It takes 3 times as long for an elephant to go that same distance. In how many minutes is an elephant traveling from Denver to Salt<n><n>### Rationales:When there are times as the ratio of the train and elephant, 3:1 = <<3:1=3>>3:1.<n>We know that the train takes 30 minutes to travel Denver to Salt and it takes 3 times 30 minutes = <<3*30=90>>90 minutes for an elephant.<n>The elephant takes 90 / 3 = <<90/3=30>>30 minutes.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>### Instructions:In the next 4 examples, find the number of apples each person receives.  The person who receives 3 apples shares his number of apples with the person who receives 1 apple.<n><n><n>### RATIONALES:Start with the sum of all the numbers(3+1)<n>then substract 1, you have 2<n>Now 2 has to share 1 with 1 1 has to share that.02.05<n>####.025<n>Answer:.025<n><n>### Instincts:In the next 3 examples, find the apples each person receives after each person shares their number of apples.<n><n>### Rationals:Start with 3 again, and add 3 to the sum<n>#### 3+3<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Instructive:If the remaining apples are distributed evenly, each person would receive an apple. Which number of apples would each person then receive?<n><n>### Ratians:Start with 3 as the sum<n>Subtract each number and find the answer<n><n>####3 - 2 - 1 = 2<n><n>####2 + 1 = 3<n><n>####3 + 3 + 3<n><n>### Answer: 3<n><n>## Scenario 1<n><n>### Instance

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do all humans have on the side of their head? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What has highly criticized security? Choices:  A: university B: concert C: home D: terminal E: airport<n><n>### Response:		The choice of option that is highly criticized is A. university. This is the answer to the question because as you can see on the page shown above, it mentioned that the university needs to improve security to avoid dangerous incidents like these.<n><n>### Input 1 : The number of customers in the supermarket was higher than expected. The store managers decided to buy more eggs instead of cakes for the next day.  When does the store buyers decide to buy the eggs instead of the cakes.<n><n>### Response 1 : If the store is unable to predict how many people are going to a given event, then they need to buy more products to avoid a lack of stock. In this case, the store manager decide to  buy the eggs instead of cakes because they want to avoid not having eggs stock.<n><n>### Response2 The store managers make a bad decision because if the information is not analyzed before buying the products, they make a bad decision.<n><n>### Input2  How many eggs did the store buy?<n>### Response2 150 eggs The manager should know that he cannot buy as many eggs as customers.<n>

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James kept a clipboard where he could easily find  it.  Where might he keep it? Choices:  A: shelf B: place of work C: desk D: office supply store E: school<n><n>### Response:		Answer Choice<n>A:James might put it on a shelf  because he could find it so easily.<n>Answer:<n>Because he could easily find it, he puts it on a shelf. <n>#### B<n>#### C<n>Incorrect<n>Incorrect<n><n>### Input : There is a 3-digit number, n. n n  In this number, there is 2 3s and 2 Is. One 3 is in the middle digit place and the 2 3s make up $summand = <<summand=37>>37. How many different 3-digit numbers can this 3-digit  number be?<n>The answer key only has 10 digit combinations that I'm looking for. One of the digit number combinations is not the same as the 3-digit number I'm looking for<n><n>Rationales: We need to use all the digits to make a 3-digit sequence<n>We need to create different combinations of the 3 digits of the 3-digit number<n>There are 3 possible digit combinations for the digit in the middle<n>There are more possible digit combinations for the sum of the 2 3<n>The total number of 3-digit numbers is 10<n>#### 10 (Correct): There are 10 choices for this 3-digit number.<n>The answer key only lists 10 digits<n><n>### Multiple Choice:Write a response that appropriately solves each task for a 3-digit prime number.  <n>A: The number 893 is a prime number.\<n>B: Subtract 3 to create an even prime number. (1 odd and 4 even)<n>C: One that ends in 9<n>D: The number 839 is a prime number.<n><n>### Input<n>A: John is building a 4x4x4 cuboid. He has placed the 3 cubes on his desk in random order. What is the probability that he puts one cube on top of another on the wrong side?<n><n>### Demnstration<n>In this case, the answer is not given to me.<n><n>### Multiple choice: A group of 9 is made of 1 prime number and 8 nonprime numbers. The group of 9 is:  <n>A:  The prime number<n>B: 4,
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why shouldn't you walk barefooted after the rain? Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:Choices: <n>```<n>C: The ground was wet (1.7) <n>```<n><n>```<n>A: The other choices don't match this correct answer.<n>```<n><n>### Choices: <n>``` <n>B: The other choices don’t match this correct answer <n>```<n><n>## Solutions<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Rationales:The answer is E.<n>-E: The foot might slip because the ground is wet and fall to the wet place, it's dangerous and you can get injured.<n>-B: You need to wear shoes to avoid that the foot will fall.<n>-A: Walking barefooted is only good in the summer but not in winter because you will catch a cold and flu.<n>-C: Wet clothes might be heavy and be uncomfortable to wear.<n>-D: You shouldn't walk barefooted because the wet ground is slippery.<n><n>### Input<n>-Pablo's mother agrees to help him pay him one cent for each page he reads.  He plans to save the cash for a treat. Pablo always reads books that are exactly 60 pages. After reading the book he went to the bank and bought a $2.85 of candy and had 50 cents left. How many books did he read?<n>-Start with finding the total he got $2.85 + 50 cents = $<<2.85+50c=3.35>>3.35<n>-He read his book 60 pages<n>-Divide 3.35 by 60 pages he read = $<<3.35/60=0.0593>>0.059<n><n>### Answer<n>-0.059 of a book<n><n>### Input (Mrs. Jones is shopping.)<n><n>-Total -$1000 cost = $400<n>-Mrs. Jones's credit balance -$400 <n>-Sandra takes $150 and leaves the remaining cost.<n>-So, Mrs. Jones was left with $250<n><n>### Ratiocination: The credit account of Mrs. Jones amounting to

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a student about to do if they are sitting in front of a number of black and white keys? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: house B: den C: family room D: wood E: floor<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### answer: A <n><n>### Demostration:<n>If it is sitting on the wood  then  you  need it to sit  on  wood  or  the  floor.<n>But when you say it is sitting on the den it is contradicting itself.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The answer choice C is the best answer because it clearly states that it is sitting on a Wood or The Floor.<n>But answer choice E is not a correct answer choice. It is self contradicting.<n><n>**A**: Wood/Floor<n><n>**B**: Den/Family room<n><n>**C**: Wood/FLoor OR Den/Family room<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n>You make 16 quilts with a piece of fabric measuring 18 inches by 12 inches. How many yards does it take to make the quilt?<n><n>### Rationale<n>You use 18 inches of fabric for every yard. So it takes: 18 inches / 1 yard = <<18/ 1>>1/1 yards.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input 2<n>You have a 2 x 2 Rubik cube. A 2 x 2, has 4 sides.
