He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you get in shape and drink at a juice bar? Choices:  A: fridge B: limejuice C: square D: gym E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		<n>To get in shape and drink, go to the GYM.<n><n>#### <n><n>### Instructions:Complete the crossword puzzle below.<n><n>### Puzzle:The numbers in the puzzle represent a fraction. Solve the puzzle and answer the question.<n><n>#### 1 1 (1.6) 15 2.9 3 3 (1.1) 5 (1.9) 6 (4.45) 7.1 8 (1.6)<n><n>### Answer:<n>If the puzzled was solved correctly, then the answer is -<n>Into the __________ a ___________ to play. - (8,15)<n>#### 1 2 (1.0) 2.9 1 3 (1.3) 5 (1) 6 (1.3)??? 7.8<n><n>### Answer<n>If the puzzled answer was - Into the ____________ a ___________ to __________ your choice<n>#### 1 6 7 (12.3) 9 2.25 (1.2)???? 10 1.6 (8.05)??? (15) 13.7 (1.4) 14 (11.4) 8<n><n>### Installed<n>If the solution was a _____________, be sure to let us know at the ____________.- (8,15)??? (13.7)(14)???? (1.4)<n>#### 13 (6.5)???? (5.7) 14 (4) 12 6??? (9.85)?? (11) (15) 3.2 6<n><n>### The ______________ __________ out of your pudgy fingers.<n>#### 13 5 (25.2) 13.8 (15) 7 (25.9) 1.6 (4.7)??? (11).9<n><n>### Instructed<n>Now, it’s _______________’s turn to ________________________ and solve the puzzle.<n>#### 3.2 (22.5) 6 (28.5)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The museum made an odd choice for the koala display, they put the stuffed creature in what area where you'd usually find a panda? Choices:  A: jungle B: bamboo grove C: australian outback D: china E: child's book<n><n>### Response:		Answer A<n><n>### Rationale:I don't want to spend my whole day on this site. I just came here to use it one time for my task.<n><n>---<n><n>### This is a community maintained page to help you learn programming. Please do not edit this page.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where was the apple tree said to contain something forbidden? Choices:  A: north carolina B: washington state C: nil D: great outdoors E: garden of eden<n><n>### Response:		B: washington state<n><n>### Demanded:<n>#### 1977<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: The population of Seattle has been growing over the past 35 years and is projected to continue to grow in the future. The population of Seattle in 1977 was 525,000 and increased by 5.3% from 1976 to 1977. What was the population of Seattle in 2012?<n>Rationales<n>In 1976, there were 338,000 people, then the population grew by 5.3%, so there were 363,500 people.  <n>525,018 people would have lived in seattle in 1976.  <n>Then each year since then, there would be another 5.3% percent growth.<n>Therefore: 1976 + (5.3-7)*12 would equal 1976*1.053^(12-7)= 385<n>This is the population.<n><n>#### 385<n>Answer: 385<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal.  She yelled at him not to leave his things where? Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationale:The text suggests Billy's mother should've yelled at him not leave his things where toys are available to children.<n><n>### Input:"You left your clothes on the bed!" "I did no such thing!"<n><n>### Response:"Oh really?" "Where were they?"<n><n>### Rationales:The text gives two sentences:<n>*  "You left your clothes on a bed."<n>* "I did no such."<n><n>*In the second sentence, it states that the man is answering the question from the first sentence.<n>*This makes it clear that it's not he or she who is saying it but someone else.<n><n>### Example question<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Example Question:<n>Which of the following shows a function?<n><n>* $9$x<n><n>### Choice A:<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Input:$6$x + $2$<n><n>### Output:Choice B:<n><n>### Ratios:<n>### Input:$5$x + $4$y<n><n>### Output:$5$x + 8<n><n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What are adult people usually expected to do? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Dan said that getting in line was the best choice because it would lead to what? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. Choices:  A: table B: restaurant C: cupboard D: kitchen E: sink<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationale:A is incorrect because you could use silverware after drying it, but this is not indicated if you are still drying them.<n><n>### B is incorrect because you would never dry silverware or any cooking utensil in a restaurant.<n><n>### C is incorrect because you would dry utensils in the kitchen, and then store there. <n><n>### D is incorrect because you would use silverware that is dry. <n><n>## Output D shows correct answer<n><n>### Rationales:E is correct because you put silverware in the sink to wash it if it was dirty, or to soak if it was still wet. <n><n>## # 5<n><n>### Instructions: <n>A 36-hour airline flight travels from New York to London. If the plane only lands in London for refueling every 15 hours, how many stops does the plane make on the journey?<n><n>### Instrumental Variables:<n>Instrumental variables are mathematical constructs or estimates that represent an unknown quantity or relationship about a population. They are used to help with a situation where you have not access to the value that you want to determine. <n><n>This situation may be explained using a hypothetical example. Let’s suppose an employer would like to determine the salary of his employees according to their length of experience. He would need to ask his employees to provide personal information. Due to the sensitive nature of this information, he may lose employees, if they declined. <n><n>To solve this problem, the employer may not want to use age or job tenures as an instrument variable. The reason is that if the employer did not disclose all of his employees, he would know certain employees did not reveal their tenures. To make the problem clear, let’s suppose an employee does not inform the employer about his job tenure, if his salary is more than other tenures. <n><n>In this case, the employer does not possess the instrument variable that describes job tenures. However, by adding more employees in the company, he would eventually learn their job tenures and could then estimate the job tenures of the employees not in his company. He can also get this estimate using the instrument variable of job tenure. This information will allow him to determine job tenures without using the sensitive information.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do you feel from playing football? Explanation: The explanation that goes with A is less than a 95.<n><n>### Rule 1: All classes meet at 7:00 AM.<n>### Rule 2: Students with a grade-point average below 3.0 have to stay in class until 5:45 PM.<n><n>### The following two sentences can help you understand a rule. A student can have extra credit if he/she completes three more than the required number of problems on the math quiz.<n><n>### Incorrect<n>If the teacher gives the students extra credit if they turn in homework, they will have the chance to get extra credit.<n><n>### Correct<n>Since the students turn in homework, it means they get a grade (which means they can earn extra credit).<n><n>### Instructive Example: The student who is doing the lesson must be at home and complete all of the questions. Do not skip the lesson. The teacher will not make the student stay for an hour later.<n><n>Example 2: The students who fail the test a second time have to stay at school. If they score less than an 80, they will fail the class. If they complete a retake and score at least 80 points on the retake, they will pass the class.<n><n>#### Incorrect<n>If a student scores a 59 on the test but earns a 75 on retest, it means he passed it.<n><n>#### correct<n>For a student to pass the test, she must score at least 85 on the retake.<n><n>### Answer: A) and D)<n><n><n>#### Answer: A)<n><n>For each choice, the rule that explains the choice is A) students receive no more than one take home quiz per quarter.<n><n>#### Answer: D)<n><n>For each explanation, the rule that explains it is D) The student scores below 65 on the first quiz.<n><n>For each student, he/she must answer all questions.<n>The student who scores less than 65, on the first attempt, must redo the test and score at least

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: gorgeous B: handsome C: pleasing D: glorious E: pretty beautiful<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* If Hurley is 45 years old, how old will he be 20 years from now? (Hurley is 45 + 20 = 65 years) If Hurley’s mother is 45 years older than him, how old is she? (Hurley’s mother would be 20 years older than him = 45 + 45)<n>* The difference in age for 45 years is 20. Which is equal to 20-20 because the parents are 45 years older to Hurley.<n>* To calculate who’s older to the 20 years, Hurley or his mother; 45 is subtracted to 20.<n>* Since the answer is 25 (45-20) years old, Hurley’s mother would 55 years old, making her older than him by 20 years.<n><n>### Output:<n>* 150<n>```cpp<n>$ 200<n><n>Program.cpp<n><n>int main() {<n>	int answer;<n>	int amount_read;<n>	int leftover_cents; <n>	float total; <n>	float part_of_car_price;<n>	int total_friends;<n>	int part_for_brad;<n><n>	cin >> answer;<n>	cin >> amount_read;<n>}<n>```<n>* While Brad wasn’t included in the car wash at all, he still did contribute to the total cost that the rest needed to contribute.<n>* Therefore, the amount for each friend should be divided by 5, the number of friends minus 1.<n>* If the friends that washed the car raised $500 from a $1700 total, each friend would be able to split the cost of the car equally.<n>* From $500, subtract $1200 (the cost of the car), and each person would have to pay another $300 for the car.<n>* The amount of $300 will be divided by 5 to cover the cost of the car.<n>* When Brad was added as a sixth person, the friends still had to pay the $300, but now they have to cover Brad’s $40 contribution.

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Always wash your hands before eating, you don't want to get germs onto food and inside your what? Choices:  A: water B: doctor C: spread disease D: mouth E: ear<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your answer was: A)<n><n>###### Solution:<n>The question is asking you to choose the correct option to complete the instruction.<n><n>**Your answer: A means water, in this context.**<n><n>### Task: <n>In this task, you will look at the following series of multiplication sentences where you will find common properties.<n><n>### Example:<n>Productive<n><n>### Demand:<n>What is the product of 6 × 9?<n><n>### Explanation<n>What does this mean:<n><n>25<n><n>#### Properties to look for:<n>1. Commutative properties of multiplication: If we change the order of two factors we are still getting the identical product.<n>For example: 6 × 9 or 9 × 6.<n><n>2. Associative properties of multiplication: Group the factors together, but keep the same order.<n>For example: (6 × 9) + 3 (10 -3 = 7)<n>3. Distributive properties of multiplication: Multiplying a product by another number should not change the values of the factors.<n>For example:1.33 × 2 × 5<n><n>### 4. 25<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. There are four incorrect responses and one correct response. <n>* The first two responses are incorrect.<n>* The third and fourth responses are correct.<n>* The fifth response is correct.<n><n>### Correct response: C<n><n>#### Explanation<n>The only incorrect responses are A and D.<n><n>If the receiver is _special_ they would actually feel happy because they received a special gift.<n><n>If the giver gives something _personal_, the receiver could feel offended.<n><n><n><n><n><n>```<n>--- <n>```<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question on the second page.<n><n>### Input<n>What is someone likely to say after getting a letter that was addressed on the back because the inside could not be delivered?<n>Choices:  A: You can come and pick it up. If Ben turns 40 years old next year, how many years older than Ben is Tim?<n>**Demonstration**: If the difference in their ages is 3, Ben would be Tim's 40 + 3 = $$\textbf{ << 40+3=33>> 33}$$ years older.<n>Since next year Ben turns 40, it means Tim is $33 + 30 = $$\textbf{33+30=63}$$ years older than Ben.<n>#### 63<n>**Answer**: 63<n><n>### Instuctions: Write a program that will be able to read a phone number in various forms which may or may be not all following the same format. Choices:  A: jewelry store B: case C: hock D: watch store E: pawn<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C<n><n>In an attempt to pawn it, he was approached by a man who asked if he was trying to pawn a watch. The man on the street corner replied "sure". The buyer then asked for the serial number of the watch. The man on street corner, thinking he was smart, instead gave the serial number of a wagon that he had seen the day before down the way. The buyer saw through it by saying "hmmm thats not the serial number of your watch". The man on street corner replied saying "it is a watch, right?".<n><n>### Input What was wrong?<n>In response, I will find a serial number, and check whether it matched the serial number that the man on the street corner stated. If it does not match, then I will tell the man this. If it does match, I will offer him some drug money.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>While trying to pawn his watch, he was approached by the buyer. The buyer asked him what he was trying to pa for, and he claimed that he was trying to pa it for drug money. The buyer stated to the man on the street "hmm so youre trying to pa for drug money. Let me see what it is for".<n><n>The man on the street instead of showing the serial number of the wrist watch, he instead showed the serial number of a different item that he had seen down the street. This is because he is actually attempting to pawn the wagon's serial number by mistake. The buyer realized this and said "hmm that isnt the serial number of your wrist watch". With no way out, he tries to defend himself "Its a watch right?".<n><n>The buyer instead of allowing the man to pawn his watch in exchange for drug money instead, offers him a handful of drug money for nothing.<n><n>### Input Choices<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: own house B: better job C: win lottery D: save money E: feel safe<n><n>### Response:		Answer: B<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If I can't find a better job then I should own a house.<n><n>If I'm looking to make more at my job I should find a better job.<n><n>### Solution:<n>If I can’t find a better job than I should own a house<n><n>### Input The difference in ages between  Julia and  Alyssa is 26. If Alyssa is six years younger than  Julia, what are their combined  ages 42 years from now?<n><n>### Demontarion<n>If Julia is 40 years old, then Alyssa is <<40-6=34>>32 years old.<n><n>Julia will be 40 when they are 42 years old.<n>Thus, Alyssa is three years old.<n><n>### Rationale<n>If Julia is 32 years old, and the differences between their age is 26, Julia will be three years older than Alyssa.<n>If we know that Julia is 40, then her combined age will be 42 + 40 = 82 years.<n>When subtracting from 40, 40-6 = 34.<n>Julia is 40-Alyssa = 34-6 = 28 years when they are 40 plus 42 years later.<n>Alyssa is 32 when they are 46 years.<n>Since 9 + 40 = <<9+40=49>>49 is not the answer, we must subtract Alyssa by 34 again.<n>32-34 = -2. Julia was 32 in 40 years and she will be 33 in 46 years. Alyssa was 26 years old in 40 years.  Her age is 32 in 36 years. Subtract 32 from 136 = -104. Alyssa will be 104 in 136 years. <n>### The total cost of making a new toy is $355.  The factory has $125,000 worth of materials on hand.  If each doll
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Rationales: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you find fungus growing on something made from milk? Choices:  A: eyes B: biology laboratory C: shower stall D: old cheese E: decaying matter<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>Answer: D<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: airplane B: construction site C: shops D: engine E: broken bone<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:: What is the value of the remainder from dividing 6 by 5?<n><n>### Response:: 1<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input:// What is the value of (7 divided by 19)?<n><n>### Response:// 0.35...<n><n>#### 0.35<n>Answer: 0.35

Brad ordered eggs, toast, and something to drink. What might he drink? Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n><n>### Response:		He might have asked for wine.<n><n>### Explain why:Wine is a drink and he asked for something to drink<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:Fred has 4 different types of soda. The sodas cost Fred $1.50 each to make and $8 for supplies.  How much money do the sodas bring in if each container is sold at $3?<n>#### 2.75<n>Answer: 2.75
